full_transcript: earth ladies and gentlemen Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd time for a review earth angels of Darkness and demons of light to earth is an experimental rock band led by guitarist Dylan Carlson they've been putting out LPS since the early early 90s and over the years they have put out some of my all-time favorite records these guys are incredibly influential when it comes to the heavier side of rock music helping to pioneer the droney offshoot of doom metal drone metal their incredibly influential to drone artists like Boris like son and the sounds that they put out in their records are pretty much the precursor to the heaviest and newest sounds out there today in sludge and doom metal you could downplay the role that this band has played in music if you like I do know that the spans music is not for everyone but earth and in groups like The Melvins 2 are an undeniable part of why we hear so many heavy and low end frequencies in rock music today albums like Earth 2 or phase 3 as inaccessible as those albums can be they really kind of opened up new possibilities for how loud or how heavy and bacey a record could sound in a way that kind of sidesteps various styles of Noise music now over the years the band has been evolving its sound they made a big change after a short hiatus in 2005 coming back with a sound that was still slow still brooding pretty droney - but had kind of a country-western Americana style laced into the music the music had a lot of twang to it some banjo some pedal steel trombone and tubular bells mixed into the music to earth was definitely seeking out new ways to explore their love of a very slow and ambient music now that apex of this new sound for me was the 2008 album bees made honey in the lion's skull love that album one of my favorites in this band's discography it's to me the most melodic out of all the album's that was done in this style and features some fantastic musicianship from guest guitarist Bill Frisell that album just shines it sparkles it's just got so much sheen on it and you know it's it's hard for me not to turn this review into a review of this album so I'm just gonna keep going now angels of darkness demons of light one the follow-up to bees made honey in the Lions skull that LP started bringing things in a slightly different direction I'm kinda lukewarm on this LP nowadays and it's mostly because of not just the incorporation of cello on this album with Earth's new sound their new style but really the way the cello was mixed into the music the cello just had a lot of bass on it it just ended up muddying up the bass guitar and then the sixth string guitar - I feel like a lot of great things about this help he did not translate because things just felt so dull felt so opaque I guess this is the second installment of angels of Darkness and of course because I wasn't too hot on the first installment I went into this thing kind of worrying how many similarities is this going to have with its predecessor will it get rid of the things I didn't like and enhance the things that I did like right off the bat I did hear some great improvements on this LP the guitar and the cello they feel like they're mixed differently now in a way where they actually complement each other and they're not battling for the same spot in the mix they're not at odds now they really enhance one another in my opinion the guitars and the bass carry that low-end like they should and the cello kind of sticks to bringing these really pretty textures into these songs another another thing I liked about this LP was the first track it may just be three minutes but the guitar tone on that song is stellar if guitar tone was a precious metal then this is gold this is platinum it sounds so good it's like listening to I don't know just just a pretty beautiful stream or babbling brook or something it just feels so gorgeous very warm really shiny really resonant yeah I feel like that's where this album really stops amazing me Earth has definitely worked out the logistics of incorporating this new instrument and putting together music for this two-part series but stylistically and musically I feel like Earth is just kind of treading water on this LP nearly every song here just sounds like I'm listening to a slightly altered version of a song that I've heard played on previous earth albums these guys are pretty much just jamming on recycled grooves and guitar phrases and in a way I can appreciate that you know there are plenty of older jazz records that if you bought them they had alternate takes of songs on the album mostly because the solos the improvisation the interplay was so good that it made each take worth listening to however the stuff on this LP is being billed as as new material and while it is to an extent at the end of the day just kind of feels like a repurposed compilation of songs from Earth's previous releases the differences I do pick up on this LP I do like I love that weeping cello in the background on the multiplicity of doors and the guitar chords improvised around that track around the 849 minute mark are beautiful dylan carlson just improvises just in Bella's around this chord progression like a master I'm sorry to be pretty blunt about it but there's not much else I could say about this record because I kind of feel like I'm reviewing the same album again Adrian Davis's drumming on this record as usual is very slow patient and OnPoint love listening to her play under this stuff but despite these pluses I just feel like this album has a severe severe lack of new ideas for people who have been following earth up until this point I'm kind of feeling a strong five to a light six on this LP pretty lukewarm on it but what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana earth oh yeah Cal Church esta what do you think of Earth professor couch your chest to hear THC at your surplus here to tell you that after much research that I have done by myself I have found earth is where we live thousands of man hours poured into that research I'm sure forever

the p贸rtico quartet cortical quartet hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review the p贸rtico quartets new self-titled LP the these guys are a london-based band and this is their third full-length studio album and this LP has a nice blend of ideas coming from the worlds of jazz and electronic music and it's not like electronics and jazz haven't met before over the years there have been tons of musicians bringing these two worlds together among tobin as well as this is for tet in some of his solo stuff and in collaborations he's done and one of my favorite electronic music producers of all time Square pusher those guys are just single producers and and and producing music by yourself definitely has a different sound than when you're working with a full band but it's not like that combination of jazz and electronic music hasn't been explored either by groups like the Cinematic Orchestra Norway's jaga jazz and I'm not trying to say the p贸rtico quartet is late to the party when it comes to combining jazz and electronics I just feel like their music and this album is kind of like the next phase of this combo now while this record does not sound like the cool or the Bebop or the fusion that a lot of jazz nuts go crazy over it does embrace a lot of jazz elements like interplay between the musicians improvisation and exploration musically and sonically previous material from the span especially their own 9 album isla was much smoother and had kind of a an escalating post-rock quality to it with a lot of strong sax solo in a way it kind of reminded me of bands like fridge and producers like new japaese at the same time now this new LP sees the band's style evolving and maybe in a way that will turn off some of the more traditional jazz fans that have latched on to their sound there are some tracks on here that completely function without the aid of sax solos there are some spots on here where the sax does kind of steal the spotlight but for the most part it's either not here or it's playing performing in a way where it is just adding another texture another sound soaring above all of these layers of beats of drums of synthesizers of strings loops and samples to the electronics are kind of taking over with this album and they're now using them to improvise and to experiment much more there was even one track on here that I remember had kind of a drum solo going with an MPC take the track ruins for example which is kind of one of the more direct tracks on this LP it's got a nice straightforward groove a great upright bass line the bass is kind of being strummed and there are all these soft ambient sound scape textures just playing behind all of this and then this very emotive sax solo kind of just makes its way into the track very shyly it's it's kind of coming out of it's shell slowly but surely and when the reverb eventually hits this sax solo it just becomes gargantuan there is some evolution going on toward the end of the track that really kind of makes me feel like who this band is definitely in a different spot now these looped synthesizer arpeggios start coming in and as the sax solo becomes really noisy and kind of chaotic all of these glitchy harsh loud electronics just start barreling down on the track making it really kind of intense I like it because this track really feels like a full band I hear improvisation 'z I hear interplay between the musicians but the way the track is built with this really repetitive these electronic elements it kind of feels like it borrows its structure from an electronic dance song the third track on here kind of follows the same premise as that second one which which acts me a little bit but it's still a decent song the band really kind of starts stretching its legs out in this new direction on the fourth track rubidium which embarks on this eight-minute soundscape of of electronic textures tense strings really faint horns and some synth loops too then these drums just unexpectedly fly in and just start going all Art Blakey drum solo all over the place rolls and fills as far as the ear can hear it's pretty formless and vast and even though it is that it just has so many beautiful sounds in it and leaves me with so much to think about the sixth track lacquer vu is a bit more straightforward the beat is mostly electronic very repetitive very hypnotic I would call it almost a micro house song if it wasn't for the fact that it had these really kind of post-rock violins sort of wailing over it I just wish you had more of a climax to it the song ste plus right after though is fantastic one of my favourite tracks on here brings this album into more of a downtempo sound and has a guest vocalist cornelia a swedish singer and her voice is really light really fragile and emotive has kind of a joanna newsom quality to it this LP does take a bit of a risk introducing a vocal guest so late so close to the end but it really pays off peridot put the vocals are just this percussion played mostly by just the drumsticks hitting each other and these loops that are just kind of skipping along in this in the sort of tense way it feels like somebody hummed and then took the hum and then sampled it and chopped it up really quick so it just kind of had this glitchy quality to it I just wish a two-minute ambient interlude wasn't how this band chose to end this album it just felt extreme the anti-climactic especially since the the interlude didn't really seem to connect to anything but maybe this band isn't one for a big finish still I think it's pretty interesting that the p贸rtico quartet chose to make its third full-length album self-titled and I definitely feel that that's because these guys are really defining themselves on this album they really jump from one style to the other which normally would make an album feel really disjointed but I feel like Portico quartet gets away with it because every track here is executed with roughly the same instrumentation and sounds and the mood pretty much stays the same throughout this LP every track on this album feels so calculated refined but most importantly I think every single track on the saddle bum is very contemplative it's a very cerebral album it's not an LP that gets my blood pumping but my gears turning up here so some great sounds great production and recording wasn't huge on the ending lukewarm on a few tracks but still I think this is a fantastic album that should be checked out definitely feeling a strong eight to a light nine on this album portico quartet self-titled LP what do you think about it let me know because I am interested do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantino portico quartet forever

hey everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd with a question comment thing a lot of people comment on my videos send me messages and emails tweet at me have you given a ten would stack of albums that I think are worthy of ten sitting right next to me and I'm just refusing to review them and I'm not complaining because in a way I asked for it because I have not given a ten yet and I use a numerical rating system but because I'm yet to give a new album a 10 I'm not really sure what a new album me giving it a 10 would sound like you know sure I feel like I could say this or this or this is a 10 but I feel like those albums because I've heard them before I even started doing the needle drop hold a special place in my heart they're all so critically in fan acclaimed albums that you're supposed to like and suppose to think are awesome and albums like this one I feel like our tends not only because I really enjoy the music on them but because I've been listening to them for so long they've kind of become a part of my life not only have I listened to this music for so long that I just kind of get or understand its meaning but I've also sort of put my own meaning onto it as well my own personal meaning if I continue reviewing music I'm sure I will eventually run into an album that I think is worthy of the big double digit number but four things will that mean it's a perfect album will it mean this album will be game-changing alter the face of music go down in the history books as an amazing album will I always think it's a ten even when I'm in my 60s well I think this album that I've scored a 10 is as amazing as the day I reviewed it and will this album be life-changing or mind-blowing the answers are no no maybe not and not for everybody my personal reviewing philosophy and I know that sounds like crap but my scores that are attached to my album reviews are only only only only reflective of my personal enjoyment of the album whether or not I like love or hate something that's it I'm not trying to appeal to some kind of objective idea of perfection and I'm not thinking in my head well a perfect album must have ABC and XYZ in order to be perfect if you want a more technical explanation I pretty much take albums track by track oh I love this track ooh I don't like this track so much ooh I don't like that track at all and of course what I'm listening to an album not only do I take each track into account but how these tracks come together as a whole as an album so I guess to even really consider getting an album at 10 I would need to enjoy each track on it to the max and really just enjoy the whole thing as a combined piece what's going to make me enjoy every track to this maximum threshold of enjoyment um I'm not sure really depends on the album and what reasons I'm I'm enjoying the album so if a 10 is out there for me I just need some understanding that it's just gonna happen when it happens it's not something I really want a plan or force because to me the idea of scoring and the concept of a ten are not as important to me as just turning you guys onto artists that I think are interesting it is just as will it be a ten one day maybe that's all I can say cool cool count your chesta counting to 10 when 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 did

this EP is only made of a handful of tracks though and I was kind of lukewarm on the rest of what was going on here like the track yellow 90s and construction deconstruction yellow 90s for me was just Sharyn BNN tramp hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review Sharon Van Etten tramp Sharon Van Etten is a Brooklyn singer-songwriter who I've been listening to ever since she made her little first handmade demos although I haven't totally been head over heels with everything that she's done in the past from the sort of rough around the edges because I was in love which is an album kind of based on those initial demos to the criminally short album epic every time I listen to one of her releases I always think yeah this is good but there's just this kind of potential that's not being fully realized I guess but there are things that are already inherently great about Sharon that kind of keep me coming back to her releases again and again and then like Sharon's songwriting which always has some pretty great lyrics and her voice which is always just so raw and a motive she's got a really mature and and womanly voice in no sense is it light or girly or flimsy and that helps a lot when Sharon is trying to transmit the emotions behind these post breakup songs or at least they feel like post breakup songs to me this album kind of feels like the act of unpacking emotional baggage leftover after you've broken up with somebody and you're just kind of unpacking box after box after box sifting through things seeing what's worth salvaging what needs to be thrown away ASAP and what you just can't let go of no matter how much you want to you kind of get these really vague memories all throughout this album of turning points in relationships with this person or people like on the song give out where Sharon is saying to a particular person and saying that you're the reason I move to the city you're the reason I'll leave or on the song serpents where Charon is singing about kind of this inevitable change that's coming and it's a change that's gonna bring thinking thinking things closer to the end and I guess she's trying to come to terms with that and the track all I can seems to be singing about just just personal flaws and mistakes and and accepting that as well it's in a way that's sort of assuring for the listener too because I feel like she's just singing directly at me and she's just trying to do everything in her power to get me to understand this there's a lot of emotional strength on this LP but there are spots of weakness to on here like on the track I'm wrong it seems like Sharon's trying to grab validation from this broken relationship by singing to this person asking if if she was worth all the miles he put on his car I guess to keep the relationship going the relationship is over but it was still good right it wasn't just a waste of time right there's just a range of feelings and stories focusing on this dying love and even though that's not a novel concept in music and songwriting Sheeran is just so passionate and so good a singer that I just want to hear her side of the story and that passion again for me comes through the great singing and some really good vocal melodies too on the song Leonard she has this vocal melody that's constantly ascending and descending and in this really catchy way she's also got a load of very close vocal harmonies on this LP too they have kind of a first aid kit quality to them especially on the track serpents which is sung really loudly and intensely and there are moments on here where she's singing and her voice just seems very spotlighted very alone and kind of sweet and understated like on the track joke or Ally if it wasn't already a parent just Sharon's voice her melodies her lyrics and the chords that she uses to build her songs to me are the most interesting thing tramp has going for it so for me the songs feel the best on this album are the tracks that are either the simplest or just kind of have the the least bells and whistles and showcase those strengths like the track give out which is pretty much just acoustic guitar and voice but it's backed up by some really light electric guitar leads that feel pretty atmospheric and dramatic and these heavy but but sparse drums just really spacious leaving tons of room for the emotion of the track the instrumentation does get harder and louder on this LP too though like on the track serpents which has this very driving drumbeat the guitars get heavier too but it's not a busy song the musics volume is just rising to match the intensity of Sharon's songwriting on that track it's on the song Leonard that I think the instrumentation becomes a little too much I guess I do love that track it's one of my favorites on the album and the instrumentation does kind of feel lush and plentiful between what sounds kind of like an accordion or a pump organ a piano but the performance just kind of feels really predictable it feels like the instrumentation is supposed to be there a lot like you're supposed to do your homework and as a result they just kind of play what it sounds like they're supposed to play the song kind of skips along like like it was a Beirut tune or something and and speaking of Beirut Zac Condon of Beirut is actually on the eighth track here we are fine singing but honestly that song does kind of add up to my least-favorite on here I just feel like Zac's erratic vibrato works much better alone I just don't really dig it all that much mixed with with a Sharon Van Etten's song and her voice too but there are actually quite a few other notable indie musicians featured on this LP Julianne Barwick is on here Jen wasner from the van Y oak as well as Matt Barrack from The Walkmen and Aaron Dessner from the National is on here as well he actually owns the studio that this album was recorded in the personality and the songs and the stories are are there you know I just feel like some of these songs have quirks about them they're just kind of turned me off like the opening track which is kind of loud but just so short and does not leave the impact on me the gripping impact that I feel like a first track should and on the track in line the vocal melody kind of wanders in a way that doesn't really deliver a melody to me that that kind of sticks with me you know I prefer the tracks on here where the vocals just feel more precise I just think the last several tracks on this LP are pretty awesome though the track asked follows that simpler and more confessional style of songwriting that other tracks succeed with on this album plus I love how intense and loud that track gets as it kind of progresses starts off very soft but the instrumentation subtly introduces itself as it moves along just getting more and more in the last two tracks Joker Ally and I'm wrong feature Sheeran singing over this kind of jeroni instrumentation it's a trick she's done before but she's brought it up to another level on this LP the track I'm wrong feels really kind of huge kind of epic with some booming drums towards its end some guitar hums kind of rising in the background they have a little bit of bite to them that track for me is kind of like watching an explosion in slow motion this time around I feel like Sharon is doing way more instrumentally and production wise then she did with epic more instruments more musical guests sometimes I feel like they complement her songs sometimes I feel like they don't other times I could just kind of take it or leave it I just kind of end up with a group of tracks on here that kind of pale in comparison to others by a large degree maybe maybe but whatever because like this album acknowledges change it's inevitable it's gonna happen it's got to happen just roll with the punches I did end up liking this album a lot though feeling kind of a decent too strong 7 on this thing what do you guys think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana Sharon man Eden forever [Music]

well hi hello and how are you Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd review ep schwa moe vacation schwa Moe is a beat music producer whose last LP bad vibes actually made it onto my favorite albums of 2011 list and the album was full of these really chill understated instrumentals it was a kind of interesting approach to be producing because many of the sounds that that you could hear on on bad vibes were not only quiet but sort of seemed to be easily found and in the bedroom of just about any musician sounds that kind of resembled thumping your hand on a desk or or scratching a pencil or a paper cross something lots of acoustic guitar these kind of distorted and and manipulated melancholic vocals kind of calling out and going and it's not like Shlomo's beats were just these repetitive grooves that just kind of hammered on this one idea over and over and over there was a lot of progression on this LP now vacation is a little EP of some new material following up bad vibes and there is a noticeable sound change on this thing as well as some remixes from label mates at friends of friends records Nicholas jar and Teebs now for the most part on the CP Shlomo is still working with the same somewhat low fie quiet cool and relaxed set of sounds that he has been but he's changing his music style dial dial up a little bit with these three new tracks with the choppy beats and the sampled and pitch shifted vocals the tracks here resemble the sounds of future garage more than anything artists like Sepulchre burial subtract and even though Shalom oh is kind of jumping to a different sound especially on the first track where this kind of footwork where the rattles along with the groove the song this guy's production style still shines through along with the melancholy atmosphere that usually surrounds his songs the intro track here just feels so moody and the solo on this thing I think it's just a distorted and manipulated vocal sample it sounds great really dramatic really epic and the second track on this EP when you is a bit faster and a bit prettier - and the vocal sample on that thing is chopped and and just presented so delicately the darkness of the previous track kind of slips away in favor of something pretty sexy the final track on here feels a little bit more in line with what I would expect from Shlomo those future garage beats and and vocal samples are still there but the tambour of the electronics and the rhythms on this one feel a little more DIY between the guitar and the and the handclaps just the various percussion on this thing it just feels cluttered it feels like a dark cluttered messy bedroom filled with instruments that track to me feels like a nicer and more even mix of slow-mo sound on bad vibes in this and this new style he's incorporating with it I'm not gonna go into the remixes too much on this thing because the tracks themselves are solid enough three really good tracks and a reason to look forward to whatever this guy puts out in the future in a way I am let down because I wish there was more material on this thing and I do prefer when Shlomo plays with with hip-hop grooves as opposed to the ones he's toying with on here but I still thought it was really enjoyable kind of feeling a strong seven to a light eight on this thing but what did you think of it love it hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana slow-mo vacation forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd it's time for a review a place to bury strangers on words to the wall a place to bury strangers is a New York rock group that for years has been creating this this noise laced reverb post-punk music this EP features track after track of just harsh shots of guitar distortion and these kind of lazy listless disconnected vocals that sound kind of akin to what you would hear on Jesus and Mary Chain album I saw him live at South by Southwest this past year and they Slade I just wished the intensity of this band's live performances and the intensity of their last full length album exploding head translated to this new EP like usual with a release from this band the guitar sounds reign supreme there are loads of different distortions delays and reverbs kind of creating a sound that is that it's almost as voluminous as lightning bolts raining down from the sky or a bullet just piercing through a hundred glass windows the song I lost you has these really ear piercing guitar wails these very just driving drums and toward the end the song just presents this just brittle harsh wall of sound the second track so far away is a bit more danceable has a bassline that kind of reminds me of the Eurythmics track sweet dreams I think the tune is ok the only thing that really sticks out to me are these really bright high-pitched just shiny shiny guitar sounds that come out over the hook I prefer the next track the title track way more it's got these surf rock drums that's really kind of chilled relaxed bass line and these kind of swells of of guitar drums a various sound and texture in the background and over them are these deadpan duet male/female vocals singing about love it's the catchiest song on this EP honestly and speaking of catchy I mean I just don't feel like any of these tracks really measure up to the material on this band's previous album exploding head when it comes to to memorability none of the songs on here are as melodic none of the riffs on this thing are as heavy or as grooving I feel like the last track comes close to that but but only close I would say that maybe a place to bury strangers has subtracted the melody out in order to just be more dissonant being noisier but I don't think this EP is that noisy in comparison with other a place to bury strangers releases there's definitely a little more detail hanging in the background of the tracks on this EP maybe there's a little bit more body to the sound of these tracks and that's mostly because exploding head was was so heavily compressed and a place to bury strangers previous LP had kind of a rough recording when it comes to simulating the effect of hurricane-force winds flying straight at your face just nothing beats exploding ahead in the a place to bury strangers discography in comparison the production on this new EP kind of feels more like a a strong gust and I think it all comes down to the compression you know the lack of compression does give the songs on this EP sort of more subtleties but the overuse of compression exploding head is what makes that album so heavy so impactful so memorable even if it is so loud that it becomes a bit of a trial to sit all the way through it and to be honest I do think I am liking this album a lot more than I was when I originally reviewed it in 2009 so overall in this new EP I feel like there are some interesting guitar sounds but still I'm feeling less volume less intensity weaker hooks despite all my lukewarm comments I don't feel like I hit a terrible song on this EP for sure there were at least one or two tracks on here I thought were really good but I still came away from this thing feeling like it was just kind of a bit of filler in between album releases just to kind of kill some time hopefully when these guys do drop another album they bring that same bold big ambitious sound to shoegaze and noise rock that they usually do kind of feeling like a strong five to a light six on this EP but what do you think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next a place to bury strangers

No hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review Leonard Leonard Leonard Leonard Cohen all the ideas Leonard Cohen is a singer-songwriter who like Bob Dylan or Tom Waits is a top notch wordsmith know him check out his early albums they're loaded with really wordy stories finger picked guitar and some really faint accompaniment from strings background vocalists and the occasional organ electric guitar bass drum set the instrumentation is good but what makes Leonard Cohen's first four LPS so attractive is his singing and it's not like he's the greatest singer in the world or anything especially on his first LP where there are a lot of points where his voice kind of sounds off pitch what makes Leonard's singing so great is that it feels so believable it feels so real he really puts the idea of songwriting up there with acting he has the potential to come off really soothing and hypnotic sometimes and other times he can deliver his songs with this really riveting conviction that makes me hang on every one of his words now on Leonard's albums he's had his louder his Marc centric his bolder moments but a great deal of the tracks you're gonna run into in his discography are quiet understated kind of laced with this romantic melancholic theater called Rama it's a style he's kept up until his old age especially on this LP old ideas which is kind of a reflection of Leonard's aging style and you know his aging self - at this point in his life Leonard is almost 80 and his his age shows up most in his voice which is really kind of settled into this low-pitched gravelly smoky sound that sometimes reminds me of Tom Waits there's some tracks on here where he's not really singing as much as he is narrating in this really dust caked whisper that's pretty gripping a lot of his lyrics these days are still on point - like with the opener going home where I can't help but giggle a little every time Leonard Cohen refers to himself as a lazy bastard living in a soup it's just this really kind of funny self-aware and clever portrait of the character that he plays when he creates her performs his songs I like the breezy background vocals and the the light hand percussion the watery keyboards it's a song that's very quiet but really soulful to the song anyhow has a story about kind of being mistreated or just desiring someone who does not desire you back and never did - and this comes out in the lyrics like I know you never loved me but could you love me anyway or when Leonard kind of begs this person to just hate him less it's just one funny and desperate appeal after another and there's kind of a sour comedy to it and the vocals themselves feel kind of sinful in this song and the music behind them slowly paced this wandering blues tune but I think the song crazy to love you is where Leonard is at his best just vocals and guitar and lyrically is kind of struggling with the question of whether or not he should chase after this love that he desires I can definitely pick out high points of this album easily but I'm not into a lot of songs here I'm not into this album overall and it's mostly because of the sound the production of these songs it's an issue that I had with Leonard's last studio LP of new tracks dear Heather so many of the instruments and the effects on this LP just sound so plain and kind of corny I don't think they the drama or the sad emotions that these tracks present the song wallow by has this beat in this bassline that sounds like it was programmed in a keyboard that you could buy at Toys R Us and this long different sides has this similar cheap thin synthetic bass sound that I don't like at all I kind of wonder in the back of my head if that's a real bass guitar on that song and if it is how did they get it to sound so fake on the song banjo the background singers just kill me they do not fit in with the atmosphere of the twangy banjo led blues on that track at all and on the song come healing the background singers get pumped up even more for a kind of gospel effect but how much they sing makes it so so apparent that Leonard is not on key a lot of the time because they're trying to harmonize with him and it's just not working I think he just would have been better off singing that song solo or just have the background singers merely coloring the background lightly like they were on other tracks and on the song darkness that track just has this really farty electric guitar that sounds like it was plugged directly into the soundboard to record it for that track and it just sounds so bad and the slide guitar and the piano on that track too it's just so cheesy this album does spare me some of the headaches that I ran into on dear Heather the background singers for the most part stay in the background and there are no saxophone solos but I just cannot get down with the sound of this LP at all there's some moments here where it's bearable and I can really get into the song but for the most part I'm just too much of a stickler for the way things sound to enjoy this LP and yeah I know it's kind of silly and ridiculous to complain about the sound of the instruments on the Leonard Cohen album that's not really why people go to Leonard Cohen albums people come to these albums for the lyrics and the stories the personality and the voice I get that and I think that's the saving grace of this LP if that's why you come to Cohen's albums then there's probably no reason you wouldn't enjoy this on some level that is the good side of this album I just don't think that side is so good that it fixes the things that I don't enjoy because to me most of this album just sounds plain or just horribly horribly under-produced so I am just on the fence with this LP kind of feeling a strong four to a light five on it but what do you guys think do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana Leonard Cohen

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of Montreal paralytic stalks of Montreal is a jojoba and this is their 11th full-length LP and they're one of those sage indie acts that have been really interesting to follow over the years through all the highs and through all the lows they started in the 90s sort of as a part of the elephant six collective which churned out some really great acts like elf power apples and stereo olivia tremor control the Neutral Milk Hotel 's and their early stuff not to go on too long about it was pretty much an assembly of acoustic and psychedelic pop tunes that were just proud to wear its Beatles influences but of Montreal later progressed into a sound that incorporated more electronics more beats more synthesizers and also started bringing in sounds from glam rock and funk music to thankfully over the course of this change of Montreal did not just become you know a blend in the electronic act and part of the reason they stayed interesting is because of the singing and the songwriting from frontman Kevin Barnes along with the music his personality kind of changed too in his songs he used to be pretty kind of shy and introverted and throw out a lot of quirky lyrics but alva out on of Montreal's more recent stuff he feels much more frantic and overly emotional it's a persona that he continues on this LP especially on tracks like dour percentage where his vocals are just so wild just lashing out at anybody who will listen the lyrics themselves are pretty raw and personal sort of self-hating sometimes Kevin Barnes is definitely his own worst critic which is always made of Montreal's dynamic kind of interesting because you have these kind of tortured painful lyrics being spewed out over this music that is just too sugary for words now on paralytic stalks the music playing underneath barns vocals is changing again and it's going in a direction that I actually like more honestly it seems to be passing more on the electronics on the beats on the synths it doesn't completely get rid of them this album is not completely devoid of that stuff especially on the intro to year Anu the plaintiff or the end we will commit Wolff murder but the role the electronics play on this album is noticeably smaller and these sounds are being replaced with with arranged instrumentation with strings with horns with woodwinds and piano and to me it gives of Montreal's usual eccentric and kind of schizophrenic personality a sort of refinement you know it doesn't feel as gaudy it doesn't feel too over-the-top the band still able to keep up its energy though most of the time because if there has been one other noticeable change that came with the electronics with the beats of Montreal's music became really groove heavy and that momentum is still here it's just that with the arrangements with the guitar the drums the bass all this live instrumentation this instrumentation that just just feels alive the energy is just different more natural I think like toward the end of the first half of year anew the plaintiff we're of Montreal kind of goes in this psychedelic rock jam that gets pretty sweaty another thing of Montreal keeps up with this LP despite the sound change is the musical density and detail that usually goes into its albums there are so many sounds bouncing back and forth on these tracks if you put a pair of headphones on it will play pong with your brain a lot of tracks here just go through these really quick fun and and almost unpredictable evolutions a lot like the song winter debts with all the changes on tract it just feels like a song straight off of the white album or Abbey Road or something it starts off with this kind of acoustic introduction that is really kind of somber and then it goes into these rushes of pianos eventually there's this pit orchestra swelling really ominously there's a spot in here that sounds kind of country - with this pedal steel playing and a and a sort of honky-tonk piano in a way it kind of reminds me of old of Montreal albums and some stencil where there's a lot of sound play I would call it a rehash of old ideas but this album just feels too big instrumentally to just say of montreal has taken a step backwards there are other tracks on here that go through equally jarring changes that end up stringing these songs out to seven minutes eight minutes the final track is 13 minutes so a lot of these tracks rely on either progressive or just really unconventional song structures which makes listening to these tracks kind of like just driving really fast down a winding road between the instrumentation the longer tracks there's definitely some shade of evolution going on with this LP but of Montreal's changes have always come slowly a lot like the album satanic panic in the Attic is kind of a foreshadowing of what was to happen on hissing fauna are you the destroyer and maybe paralytic stalks will be the launchpad for the next new interesting sound that of montreal plays with for a handful of albums the band is experimenting with avant-garde music like on the eighth track here which is a number nine style sound collage that goes on for eight minutes and features a plethora of sounds including the instrumentation that I just mentioned and some spoken word I think a lot of the new fans especially the people who love this groups poppier albums might think that track is kind of boring but I dug it I thought it was intense but still even though if Montreal is clearly experimenting on a lot of these tracks their sweet side is still intact again that tracked our percentage which has a groove that reminds me a lot of just disco music the vocals and lyrics add that bittersweet touch to the song and the saxophone solo off the back end of that track is just sassy and the song Malevich dowry is this acoustic tune that I can't quite make heads or tails of yet it feels like as soon as that song rolls into town I'm just on an island and I have a little coconut drink or something it just feels really light and sunny and kind of cute now there are some issues I have with this LP and I'm hoping that if of montreal continues with this sound they hammer them out in future albums of montreal is making a lot of their songs longer now and in order to do that they're adding more parts to their songs and on some of these tracks these parts flow together really well on others they don't or the other parts just kind of feel like they're there the song winter debts feels like a complete journey and I really like how he renew the plaintive starts off with these electronic beats and through one transition after another just blows into this full-on rock song that really just is just awe-inspiring to me how that track changes the final track a lot like winter dets has a pop tune at its start a string break and then a piano ballad toward the end but I do think it relies on this string interlude in the middle a little too much and while I'm complaining I wasn't that huge on the first track it was kind of heavy psychedelic and hazy but just not all that memorable for me and overall I guess I wish this album was as conceptual as other of Montreal albums that I love and if there is a concept going on with this thing it has not really revealed itself to me yet as far as the lyrics and the stories on this LP go it's a lot of the same stuff Kevin Barnes has been singing about on his past several albums and he knows that he even brings it up in the second track of the LP where he says lately all I can produce his psychotic vitriol that really should fill me with and you know it's it's kind of interesting to see that extra layer of self-awareness get just placed on top of this album but I think the lyrics are are kind of due for a change just like the the music is and that change is happening here with this record I think you get a lot of solid pop tunes some nice experimentation some progressive song structures classier instrumentation some great Arrangements written for that classy instrumentation and the assurance that of Montreal is not going anywhere this is definitely the most fun I've had listening to a new of Montreal album in a while but what do I know I didn't even really dig hissing fauna as much as most people did I'm feeling a decent strong seven on this LP what did you guys think of it did you love it did you hate it why and what should I review next Anthony Fantana of Montreal forever [Music] you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album really related whatever album review Loma Prieta I V these guys are a California band fourth full-length album and the this group has undergone quite a bit of change to be playing with the sound that they currently are no matter which loma album you're talking about the band's heart has always been pretty sentimental towards screamo and hardcore punk and now more than ever this bands take on screamo music is extremely raw and uncompromising coming off as intense and passionate as some of the best albums in this genre created by bands like let's say page 99 who represent really the more extreme side of things now this bands early work was intense as well but definitely more accessible the group's first two lp's definitely had much more clarity to them clearer guitar chords maybe some clean singing - I was even catching some vocal harmonies on the second LP I guess overall with those albums there was a clearer balance between the abrasive sounds and the pleasant sounds but as the band progressed past those two LPs they've just been getting harsher and harsher and now on this album right here I think they're performing tracks with their harshest sound yet it is very very nasty and these guys accomplished this nasty goal by blending screamo and poor Punk with with other styles of music like noise there are some spots on here that kind of hit me as being sort of very powerful ensuite very punked-out riffs and blast beats and some of the riffs on here just feel really sludgy really thick and powering some tastefully performed breakdowns but even with all these extreme sounds all of this discord these guys still managed to find a way to put just some gorgeous musical ideas into these tracks the opening track here starts off with these pounding headache pounding drums and these screams the way that dude the frontman in this group screams by the end of this album er just maybe at the end of a show his voice his vocal cords have got to be feeling like he swallowed a bunch of ghost chilies or like some molten lava or something his vocals just are so heavy with these painful emotions and the vocals together with the bass the guitar and the drums they're all so loud together and packed so tightly into this small sonic space it's kind of claustrophobic the music is right on top of me and there's just no getting away this album can be just as harsh at times as some of the most lo-fi black metal albums out there or even like a converge album toward the middle of this opening track there is kind of this quiet break and then the song busts into these really kind of harmonious guitar chords they're really triumphant they're really beautiful they're still played at an ear-shattering volume but I love how pretty these guitar chords are and how they finish off this track with a kind of positive note and that's kind of where this LP finds its success just violently smashing together ugly and and beauty without even worrying about the consequences and then just kind of counting the casualties after that I think the next two tracks are some of the most unforgiving on this album a bit of a blur for me but they're still thrilling enough to carry me to the next three tracks which are kind of a trilogy some blast beats make their way onto these tracks just shots of feedback and these really kind of paranoia powered guitar leads but my favorite in this trilogy has got to be the final track it has to be the hardest and harshest track on this LP the riffs are as deadly as the Death Star and when this band flows into the breakdown toward the end of this song they really kind of groove it out they let it play out and as they're playing it the production the recording just starts getting louder just more saturated more distorted and it continues in this direction until it basically becomes a wall of almost complete noise it's almost like the music is so extreme it's just disintegrating before my ears it's just a real show of just spiteful bleak nihilistic feelings now funny enough after this track all the songs start showcasing a lot more harmony in the guitars in the guitars at least that's what I'm kind of picking up but the guitar chords just start feeling much more mournful much darker and it really kind of takes the hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review John Talbot Finn John is an electronic music producer from Spain and this is his debut LP but the first just gonna get one track after another of dance tunes that are just really sexy they are groovin but not too hard not too aggressive a lot of just experimental and micro house tunes lots of really straightforward repetitive beats atmospheric effects slow patient builds just always looking for different ways to evolve you know just elements that a good house album should should have in my opinion but what I like most is the variety of sounds and ideas that John is able to bring to this LP while kind of sticking to those themes lots of repetition lots of smooth atmospheric sounds this album starts with what I think is one of the best opening tracks of this year it really kind of sets up the dark sexy and silky sounds that kind of flow throughout this LP the build on this opening feature that just repetitive ever-evolving groove formula a lot like caribou or for Tet or Nicholas jar or mmm Panther do prints his grooves on this LP are so great when you get into them you just get have been dropped either at the tail end of the 80s or at the beginning of the 90s to be played in the club and the track horse has these really sporadic rhythms in it that really kind of makes it feel like kind of a footwork song but the rhythm isn't as loud as it usually would be in that style of electronic music it's very very quiet very understated and kind of dark and eerie because of it hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review lana del rey born to die Lana Del Rey is an American singer-songwriter formerly known as Lizzie grant or Lana Del Rey with an A in the Rey instead of an e and this is her sophomore LP born to die and this is an LP that came after an image reinvention for Lana her debut LP came out in 2010 and went under the radar big-time but now she's back with a new look and new singles new album new music video and this complete unknown has blown up to a surprisingly huge level of popularity and most of this happened on the back of the buzz of one single song the first single from the LP video games it came out last year premiered as a YouTube video a music video loaded with footage of Lana Del Rey sexily lip-synching into a webcam spliced together with footage of couples and skaters and skylines and you know just a bunch of stuff for dramatic emotional effect it seemed really DIY but when you think about it the production of the music really did overshadow that of the video you know with the harps and the strings and the piano and the really kind of nice glamorous reverb over everything and shortly after video games kind of blew up Lana was making all of these European television appearances and it all kind of seemed like magic until people found out that it was Universal Music Group that was actually going to be releasing her forthcoming LP through itself and its subsidiaries Polydor and Interscope so I guess with major label support some PR a viral video and a sexy image built on Nancy Sinatra inspired nostalgia you can get exposure just about everywhere and of course this put a really nasty taste in a lot of people's mouths saying ooh Lana's contrived Lana's fake Lana's manufactured and you know I think it's a little silly because there are a lot of artists on major labels that get praised in the indie blogosphere and they rely on image too so I don't totally see the issue from that angle honestly but still this is the kind of backlash that happens when a musical product I thought relies on its image more than it does the music you know image is part of promoting music it's not going anywhere and it doesn't have to as long as the images come together with the music in an artful way instead of a deceptive way people are naturally curious about the people who are making the music that they listen to they want to see them they want to get to know them but since day one the Lana Del Rey PR campaign has been 95% image music videos TV appearances photoshoots and magazine covers interviews and controversy most of what has come out of this PR campaign has been stuff like that not like songs and I think it turned around and bit everybody in the but when Lana Del Rey did her biggest TV appearance yet on Saturday Night Live and she pretty much bombed she was off pitch she had like no charisma and her vocals were just kind of goofy and you know I have to ask was bombing really out of character for her I think the SNL performance exposed Lana to a group of people who had no exposure to her or the blog buzz that she wrote in on and because of that they were less forgiving and they expressed that on every social media platform that's out there and the people that had been praising her up until this point couldn't ignore the fact that hey you know what this just was up to par but with these people who didn't like Lana's SNL performance would they have liked her other performances in my opinion she was kind of flat and mumbly and just boring on Jools Holland and her German TV appearance wasn't all that pretty either her singing on record to me is way more OnPoint more emotive and speaking of the record we do have to talk about that you know it's been a really fun buzz ride but we're at our last stop born to die so what does an album living up to this massive hype have to offer some stuff you know honestly I think it tries it tries really hard but it comes up a little short when it comes to substance Born To Die does have an interesting and kind of fresh approach to baroque pop though lots of lavishly produce strings in every direction really pretty and fine delicate sounds it's just like an ocean of instrumentation washing over my ears over and over and over and kind of lulling me into this really kind of sonic seduction and sometimes the string arrangements are really ambitious they really enhance a track like the introduction to born to die or the song Lolita those intros with those strings are pretty beautiful and the strings do a great job of helping out with the climaxes on these songs like how Born To Die explodes toward the end what kind of makes this baroque pop approach kind of kind of fresh is all the beats behind these tracks which are clearly hip-hop influenced especially with the NPC style base hits and chopped and loop vocals pretty much every track on here goes for this mashup of this baroque pop style with a sort of old aesthetic to a certain nostalgia 50s 60s aesthetic with these modern hip-hop rhythms and beats I think it's an angle not a lot of people are doing these days and I do admire this album for that at least still it's kind of a style I get sick of by the end of the LP because the strings while they are nice they do enhance some of these songs they get to be kind of just just too much for me I feel like too often strings in general are used to give us on depth and emotion and importance and just this feeling of epicness but the thing is no matter how much air freshener you spray eventually you're going to smell the crap after a while I just kind of feel like I'm listening to the soundtrack to a Disney movie or a perfume commercial they're just too many instances here where I feel like I'm hearing the strings more than I am Lana's vocals or the song itself I just feel like the arrangements get boring after a while and there's really no escaping them but then again I feel like taking the strings away would strip this album of what little appeal it has this album relied on the vocals to deliver the emotion and the depth and the epicness those feelings just would not be here for one I can't get into the lyrics or the story that this album throws out there I feel like Lana has this little black book of lyrical cliche is that she calls on whenever she needs to write a song and they just kind of assemble into this tapestry that are her verses and choruses heartbreaks born to die loving you till the end of time tears eyes walk on the wild side you're no good for me light of my life holding me tight kiss me hard in the pouring rain get out of this town these kinds of phrases have been said so many times that they've pretty much lost all meaning all real meaning and it's not like Lana is reinventing them to mean something different or mean something new either but the biggest cliche that this album is obsessed with is the bad girl cliche ooh bad girls Lana's portrayal of a bad girl is the most shallow thing on this album this album's definition of being a bad girl is smoking and drinking partying staying up all night and being objectified by and lovesick over the men that Lana is attractive to they're really what a bad girl is is that how this generation is rebelling because if that's the case then Ke$ha is a revolutionary viva la revolucion ah ah when it comes to being a bad girl I wish this album took a little more influence from Nancy Sinatra who obviously influences the image behind born to die but not really the message Nancy Sinatra musically was a serious badass she had her vulnerable moments like the song bang bang but the songs that she put out that were her biggest were the ones where she was the heartbreaker and she got revenge on the people who broke her heart songs like these boots were made for walking I'm not the loving kind sorry about that how does that grab you these are songs where Nancy Sinatra was owning her womanhood and being in control of herself and her feelings and what she was going to do with her life in a time when that was not really a mainstream idea in contrast Lana's biggest song is about trying to please and seduce her video-game-playing boyfriend which is kind of funny when you think about it I'm curious as to how this album makes women feel especially when a song like this is what makes us girls comes up where that idea of partying and staying up lay in skipping school and underage drinking is kind of reinforced as being bad so yeah I think the message here is kind of off it's misguided and if it is well intentioned that's not really communicated that well but if this album was a bunch of tracks that that were like born to die in blue jeans and video games I think this might have been a pretty decent LP because on record Lana Del Rey's voice for the most part is on pitch and those tracks are just pretty catchy but instead of sticking with the the precedent set by those tracks Lana starts venturing out of the comfort zones of the people who have been hearing those tracks and I think her own comfort zone the song off to the races is kind of loaded with the really goofy vocalizations that did not go over well on the Sandell performance and the song Diet Mountain Dew sounds like the soda tastes that track is just so straightforward and heavy with it's rhythms it doesn't really have the finesse or the delicate approach that make all the other tracks so appealing the song national anthem actually has lana del rey like rapping and it's kind of awkward and the song lolita is is almost the trashy radio pop that Lana Del Rey has been promoted as the antithesis to there are some songs on here that I actually admire for kind of almost becoming something I love like the song Carmen I think that track has a beautiful vocal melody and it's about the closest this album comes to really kind of capturing that Nancy Sinatra style in a tasteful way between the cheap lyrics and there's the overproduced music and the and the kind of confusing message this album is just kind of a bunch of songs that could have been really good but they just end up being kind of ruined they add up to something that just does not have a lot of lasting power I think this album is an interesting take on baroque pop it has some pretty melodies and production but it doesn't really go beyond that it's nothing that I'd want to return to kind of feeling a strong three to a light four on this thing but what do you think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantino Lana Del Rey forever I love you Vimeo games

hi here Anthony everyone Fantana for and album time review nehru teams jackets teams or Himanshu is a new york MC and a part of the rap outfit - racist and dance racist put out a couple solid mixtapes in 2010 that i enjoyed a lot and they spent 2011 releasing their official full-length debut relax if you see my reviews you already know that I love the tapes I mean even Cal loved the tapes I eat it pizza I ate it Taco Bell I ate it pizza a Taco Bell we loved the beats we loved the personalities that heenes and Victor Vasquez showed off in their mic skills their verses are always loaded with very witty rhymes hyper self-aware and hyper referential non sequiturs and they just have this magical ability to be joking but also not joking at the same time but the LP they dropped relax you know I reviewed it and it just didn't do a lot for me even though some of my favorite tracks of last year on that thing now it's 2012 and - racist members and emcees kind of related to the record label that they started greed head are dropping mixtapes Victor Vasquez dropped under the name cool ad which I I wasn't huge on but this second tape the second - racist related tape a man shoes neighbor jackets it's caught my attention and it caught my attention because it scratches all of the very much needing to be scratched pitches that the tapes did lots of jokes lots of material you know nobody is in a rush to get through the 70 minutes of music that is on Nehru jackets and it's not like he was just jerking off on this tape a lot of the jokes that he makes on this thing add up too clever and thought-provoking satire dealing with drugs race gender police technology food movies music war and politics the tape makes me laugh the tape makes me think and throws a lot of great beats out to in the process the beats on this thing come from producer Mike finito who actually raps on one of the tracks and his production on this thing brought this project a lot of consistency just huge fantastically huge and booming bass drums and samples that sound like they're they're lifting music from from Indian music - racist is always really good about throwing race in your face just to make you think about it and they've done it musically in the past - but on this tape it's it's just brought to another level the coca-cola freestyle bangles women parts 1 & 2 sweet all of these tracks and more on here sample at least one or two pieces of music that have a foreign flavor to them actually there are even some verses on this tape that aren't even wrapped in English and I don't understand them and I'm sure he knows that most of his listeners aren't going to understand them either but it's just another way that this tape throws race and foreign cultures into your consciousness as far as other features on this tape go some of the best and brightest of the underground MCS that blew up last year get featured on this thing mr. X Choir Action Bronson Danny Brown despot big baby Gandhi of course cool ad from - racist is on here and even childish gambino is featured on a verse that I actually liked but let's go back to the beats because some of the instrumentals on here are so good they really kind of made this album for me I love the cold and chilly soulful vocals sampled on bad bad bad they just add the perfect piece of atmosphere to that track just making it feel kind of sleek and sexy the track alien Gonzalez I can be wrong but it just kind of like its sampling like this Bollywood music these little symbols and these just falsetto female vocals it's really spicy it grooves like a hip-hop track but all these foreign sounds just make it feel exciting and fresh the tracks weight has easily one of the best grooves on this entire tape and I love the loud booming and aggressive direction the tape goes in with the baby track NYC cops I love the electronics rumbling in the background of you have to ride the wave it actually features Danny Brown and kind of feels like an instrumental one of the more electronic instrumentals from his tape xxx the beyond women has a really kind of cute light-hearted feel to it that matches the the lovestruck lyrics in the song and the track it's the drug has this really kind of sexy quality to it featuring these sensual female vocals and really kind of painting the kind of alluring picture that people usually equate with drugs the versatility is incredible and he kind of proves himself to be just as versatile as the production itself I actually think he knows himself off to be more versatile here than he did on the - racist album and mixtapes with a victor kind of playing this laid-back blunted role he's was usually much more kind of in-your-face and aggressive and lively on neighbor jackets though he pretty much tries to play every position on the field with at least one track going from really kind of hard aggressive and critical on NYC cops - feeling kind of so sleepy and blunted on suede sometimes he's rapping about his junk food addiction sometimes he's rapping about being in love sometimes he's just going all out and getting ridiculous and kind of rapping from the point of view of Jason Bourne from the Bourne Identity my only real issue on this tape is that there are a lot of tracks on here under two minutes that don't really have a topic or a subject matter and they just kind of end up feeling like a bit of filler even if they aren't nice to listen to as you're gliding through the entire tape but outside of that I love the songs on here the hooks are great productions on point the features are really great teams flow is always changing up and his bars are pretty complex sometimes this is you know don't let the really casual and thrown together sound of his voice throw you off I thought neighbor jackets was really fun just loaded with personality I just wish relax was as awesome to listen to but what are you gonna do I'm feeling a light eight on this thing loved it gonna be listening to it again in the near future but what do you think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana teams forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and album review time Lamb of God resolution these guys are a Virginia metal band that I actually mentioned in my most anticipated albums of 2012 list especially since I haven't gotten the chance to talk about any of this bands music and they do have a pretty large reputation in the metal world resolution is the sixth full-length studio album these guys have pulled together as Lamb of God and it pumps out the kind of grew grew grew grew grooves riffs and breakdowns that you would usually hear on the groove metal record a metalcore record and what exactly do those genres mean well both of them are heavily indebted to thrash metal of the 80s and 90s in thrash metal the riff is king as well but in metalcore and groove metal the rips usually aren't that speedy they're more mid paced and they become especially slow if there's a breakdown involved the riffs in this style of music usually have a lot of punch to them a lot of shudder just these continuous start/stop shots of guitar distortion there's even a spot on track 6 where there's like some post-production editing on the guitar riffs make them feel even more sharp make them feel even more robotic when it comes to modern metal hitting the mainstream it's been a lot of Records like this in this style that have been signed on to major labels or have gotten heavy rotation play on metal radio stations and that's fine I understand why it's popular I understand why it's marketable it's music that's created to just elicit an emotional reaction an aggressive emotional reaction as fast as possible not even leaving you time to think about what you're hearing aggression is lame of God's greatest asset on this record on to their records when it comes to that emotion these guys are about as instant as ramen noodles but I think the popularity of this kind of songwriting in metal music has kind of changed the public face of metal a little bit though there are exceptions like Between the Buried and Me and converge this style of music isn't usually big on detail or variation or songwriting you know not to be really brutal about it but I think it's kind of records like this that reinforce a lot of metal stereotypes that metal is nothing but just screaming and just senseless anger and breakdowns but you know it's it's whatever because if somebody really wants to believe that then they're the ones missing out this LP is an album that kind of fits that mold though if you guys watch my videos especially my metal reviews you already know that I love aggressive music but the thing is Lamb of God doesn't really bring much else into the equation there almost no unique song topics or lyrics on this record it's actually a lot of tunes on here about kind of being alone or being singled out and that's not necessarily a bad song topic if you put it in a unique perspective but these ideas are just painted with a lot of cliche lyrics about digging your own grave or bleeding or hands around someone's throat this album isn't really huge on on speed or technical ability not a lot of catchy melodies either and not a lot of thought-provoking sounds or production and the vocals don't really change all that much either track after track after true I guess I would have less of an issue with that if they didn't feel like you know just kind of generic metal growls when the vocals do kind of change its to do a cleanly some chorus or you know kind of a cheesy narration thing for the most part on resolution Lamb of God just focuses on riffs and aggression with a hint a hint of melody and harmony hanging somewhere in the air but the thing is the stuff they focus on with this LP I don't feel like they do it particularly well or approach it from a unique angle the riffs really aren't that intricate or hard-hitting I mean if I want an amazing riff there are a number of Meshuga records I could be listening to instead for just massive heaviness and just dizzying rhythms that sometimes fall into odd time signatures and as far as aggression goes I just don't think this album is all that aggressive it just has this kind of one level of aggression and it maintains it throughout the LP and after a while hearing it at this same level kinda makes it lose what little flavor adds and you know it's kind of a shame because I thought I might be in for something different with this LP especially with the introductory track which was just so slow just so heavy but after that I just kind of get one song after another that just feels like I'm listening to a thrash metal record that's a bit louder has kind of a modern shine a modern production to it but has less melody less songwriting power less variation between the songs I definitely give Lamb of God credit for putting together an LP where they're definitely using more guitar solos and more guitar leads than I've heard on previous efforts there are some spots where the guitar leads kind of build up into some nice harmonies even the final track has string sections playing against the Lamb of gods distorted guitar chords that feel that epic feel overall I just think resolution doesn't throw that many ideas out there it's just kind of 14 track headbang fest that doesn't leave you with much to think about after it's over and because it doesn't offer a lot of different ideas it just gets really old really fast for me maybe if the sound of the record was better I could see myself getting into it more you know but the guitars just don't have a lot of beef to them you know the kind of sound that I love to hear on an electric wizard record or a high on fire record and you know I do understand that that is not the style of music that these guys are playing but still I hate hearing heavy guitars that really aren't heavy at all it's just all distortion and no Rumble it just feels like Lamb of God wants to leave innovation and experimentation to all the other bands out there and just kind of play things by the book and if that works for them that works for them but it doesn't work for me because I just really didn't get much of anything out of this record I understand why people like it but it doesn't appeal to me not at all there are some spots where I kind of like the riffs and I kind of like the vocals a little bit but there was no one song on here that I liked all the way through kind of feeling a strong three on this LP but what do you think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantan Oh Lamb of God forever [Music] [Music]

going just Soofi muzzle hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd nice to meet you it's time for an album review ganja Sufi muzzle ganja Sufi is an MC singer and producer who's been turning heads ever since he landed as a guest vocalist on the Flying Lotus album Los Angeles which led him to get signed on Warp Records to release his debut album a Sufi and a killer which was one of my favorite albums of 2010 and to this day I have difficulty finding words to accurately describe what this album is it's kind of a weird mix of soul and hip-hop and low fine music and electronica and noise and funk and Middle Eastern music punk and psychedelic rock it's just a mess there are so many songs on here it just kind of uses being a mess as kind of a concept now after a remix album of that LP and a new EP we have muzzle which is 10 new tracks 24 minutes kind of a short mini album and a slightly new direction first off going to sufi is not working with the Gaslamp Killer on this one he's taken it upon himself to pull the recording and the beats together and you have a lot of lyrics on these tracks that kind of deal in social overtones and this stuff to me has kind of led to a release that is a little bit more in control of itself know if a Sufi and a killer was kind of like this auditory binge then this is definitely in comparison much more focused and sober I'm not saying this album isn't loaded with trippy and psychedelic sounds because it is like on the song feeding birds you have these vocals that sound like they're being sung through McDonald's drive-thru speaker boxes with lots of reverb on them watery and reverb guitars just shattering away in the background behind them there all these swirls of just ghostly vocals and electric piano on like the the intro track and the outro track which to me can only seem to exist to throw some weird sounds out there songs like black soot and skin and time out there little meteor but I kind of feel the same way about them too because the beats behind the tracks just the whole track in general just feels a little repetitive kind of runs in circles but those tracks a lot of tracks on this LP you don't really last all that long and while that keeps them from getting really annoying to me they don't exactly stick with me they're not really packing a punch and many songs on here don't really throw out ideas that haven't already been thrown out by a Sufi and the killer there are a few darker beats on here and I do like that do out and feed birds but if it weren't for the fact that ganja Sufi has such a unique voice that he's always changing up with different breathing styles and pitches and inflections and effects I think I'd be pretty bored with much of this album there are some songs on here though that kind of seemed to come to come together with a really strong song hook and sound like the blame which has this very dark beat and these strange little synthesizers just kind of droning away in the background and the lyrics kind of tell this story of violence and murder and maybe even kind of killing for your beliefs and also shame and the song nickels and dimes too which is kind of about leading a wasteful lifestyle and one should do his or her best to avoid that and I really like how that track kind of transitions into the song rubber band and you know if we are going to get less material I I at least wish that more of the tracks on here did that you know just so everything didn't feel so dis dis disconnected on this new LP I think going to Sufi is still pushing an original sound I'm happy he's been able to maintain it while kind of relying on himself more to pull this music together muzzle is definitely a little more cohesive but I think you know the way that a Sufi and the killer jumped around just so so boldly is part of what made that album so fun it kind of like short-circuited my brain in contrast muzzle kind of feels like the same drug that
