hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review Cloud Nothings attack on memory Cloud Nothings is a Cleveland indie rock band and it's been about a year since I was first introduced to this project when it dropped its sophomore LP which was self-titled on carpark records and even though I liked this album a little bit when it first came out my problem with it ultimately is that I felt like it was kind of forgettable which kind of plays out in the fact that I cannot remember not a single song from it the album was chasing after that really lo-fi washed-out reverb II rock sound that's that's been big ever since 2008 2009 and these days you know it's a sound it's a style that I'm really really just fed up with I'm just not interested in it you know I always try to keep my ears open to whatever is new and whatever's going on whatever style of music but it's difficult to stay interested it's difficult to feel excited when you've got so many bands lining up to beat the same exact drum Cloud Nothings did a huge 180 with this new LP attack on memory even though that is the title I think this album is really memorable this album just brings a set of songs that are just very clear and muscular tracks from genres like indie rock and punk rock and post-hardcore maybe with a little bit of emo thrown in there old-school cool ass emo not the emo everybody's like oh that's emo the I would just say the strong points of this LP are catchy hooks strong vocals and lots of variety in the in the 33 minutes that this LP lasts and to speak about the variety of this thing this album does turn out a few different kinds of songs and the first kind of song we'll run into on here especially on tracks 1 & 2 are these these slow burners these really hard emotional rock songs that feel just influenced by the repetition of bands like Slynt but had that fire in that drive like a Fugazi song the track like no future no pastures has this riff and it's being laid on over and over and each time is just getting it's getting louder it's getting rougher it's getting harder as well as the vocals - in the drums and the second track wasted days three minutes into the song it just breaks into the screw that gets jammed out until the song ends at around the 9 minute mark and this Jam is a real ride it's fantastic to hear the change that Cloud Nothings have made on this LP they are just sounding so much more together cohesive instrumentally you know what I mean it sounds like you're really hearing a band rock the hell out while I the guitars are getting noisy the vocals are just losing control but the album is not just one long drawn-out jam after another Cloud Nothings throws out some really fast and catchy songs on here - but doesn't cheapen the music or or make it just feel dumbed down in the process and I think the king of all the songs that fit that bill is definitely the tracks stay useless the introduction of the song sounds like it could have been written for a strokes tune but the song kind of morphs into what could have been like an indie rock song from the 90s but it doesn't really feel old and nostalgic the vocals just had this really kind of strong teenage personality in the hook just hit so hard I just want to go I need to stop now bad sometimes the lyrics are barely intelligible it's clay yeah you're hearing these growls sometimes the vocals do come off a little amateur but they are so emotive in authentic you know that that cannot be questioned at least the emotions behind the vocals they seem really just angry at some points depressed at other points anxious there's another track on this that goes really dark and heavy and it's the track no sentiment and it's on that song you get these just wailing guitars these huge heavy bass riffs and on here on here I can really tell these guys are using that Steve Albini production yes Cloud Nothings actually worked with Steve Albini to put this album together I'm sure it had a lot to do with why the music and the sound is different on this LP and if there is one track on here where that is heavily displayed it's that one and I like the idea of the song too in the lyrics it feels like the lyrics are about being kind of aggressive toward the past aggressive towards the things we remember we don't care what you do we don't care what we'll lose lose in the process of forgetting in the process of attacking the past what you're doing artistically and when you're doing it I think is a theme that gets played out on the next track and essential it'll never get old I think it kind of pokes fun of the way we listen to music consume music like perceive music and celebrate it how maybe you know and again this is my interpretation that a is a nice little instrumental as well at the end of the day I feel like this album just kind of feels like a batch of tracks just an assembly of random ass songs I didn't feel any kind of one strong hi everyone Anthony Sano here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review the act of estimating as worthless really long title amongst these splintered Minds leaden thoughts sing softly I don't even know why I said that in an accent the act of estimating is worthless is a New York band this is their debut full-length LP following up an EP and a little demo as well the active estimating presents a really interesting idea take the lazy and listless Fulk Punk attitude and sound that the Moldy Peaches had back in the day but this time we're gonna do it in a way where people can like take it serious but honestly the first thing that I did notice about this LP when I was listening to it was just the similarities it has to the music of the Moldy Peaches and Kimya Dawson and Adam green as well the acoustic instrumentation is right at the forefront of this thing the boy/girl vocals kind of lazily intertwining together are very off beat and off pitch the songs on these tracks are very simple they feature very simple melodies the melodies on this thing are almost like child song like in some respects almost have like a lullaby quality to them and overall the album just has this really young attitude these really straightforward and personal lyrics sometimes they come off really poetic and other times they're just not afraid to get guttural and spit a line out like I up it's a combination of flavors that makes this album equal parts cute endearing weird and also pretty relatable the lyrics are pretty interesting too dealing with a lot of sort of adult situations or just odd situations but kind of filtered through this sort of nostalgic and childlike mindset the more I listen to this album the more I learned that the act of estimating really did put together a solid LP and they have influences that vary outside of the peaches one thing that I think separates them definitely is the recording on this LP is pretty good and it features a mess of different instrumentation horns strings drums and upper a bass glockenspiel some tracks like no one on the road and nighttime just burst beautifully with all of this instrumentation while others just have you know it's just some really nice accompaniment that just continues throughout the song and to be honest sometimes when the horns swell on this album it reminds me of Neutral Milk Hotel a lot and there are other tracks like massive windows and things we remember where the instrumentation will be really loud and just saturated and distorted spots like that really really sound like the microphones to me you know you'll get a bunch of instrumentation surrounding these songs but it'll sound really hectic and sort of low Phi now another kind of striking thing about this band is just its its personality and how consistent it is throughout the album even the cutest and most adorable songs on this LP have a really kind of deadpan vocal and a stone-faced expression and this really strong sense of just earnestness just this raw earnestness it just reminds me of like a Bill Callahan song like a Smaug song or something so you've just got these simple songs these interesting lyrics and strange emotions adult situations with all of this sort of beautifully and meticulously crafted instrumentation surrounding all of it it's just a nice mixture for me overall this album is kind of like being a kid again and having like a secret spot that nobody else knows about like a really cool treehouse or something and you've got like a front deck on there and you can look at the stars at night or go inside read tons of comic books and play video games or whatever even though I felt like this album didn't really present anything brand-new to me sound or style wise it was a nice blend of things that I was already familiar with just kind of put together in a way I'd never heard them before and sometimes you know that's all you really need in order for an album to kind of feel fresh to you as far as negatives on this LP go I feel like some tracks on here just pale in comparison to others and a lot of songs on here just felt really kind of see me see me I felt like I was just getting this really strong notion of deja vu throughout this LP and it's mostly because of the vocals which are a bit of a double-edged sword because even though they lend this project a lot of personality you know it's like oh that's kind of their shtick that's their sound that's their style that vocal style it doesn't really change up and show the variation that the instrumentation does and the emotions do from song to song to song to song so in a way the vocals on this thing kind of end up making a lot of tracks on here feel too similar still I enjoyed the hell out of this LP and would like to know what you think of it if you take a listen to it feeling a decent too strong 7 on this thing what do you think about it do you love it you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana the act of estimating is worthless definitely not worthless forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review Charlie Haden and Hank Jones come Sunday Charlie Haden and Hank Jones are two very well traveled jazz musicians Charlie Haden is a bass player and has been a trailblazer in avant-garde experimental and free jazz for years over the course of Hayden's career he's released a lot of albums collaborated with greats like Alice Coltrane Pat Metheny and Ornette Coleman as well and his partner on this album Hank Jones is a jazz piano player and he's collaborated with many greats himself and has a pretty hefty discography too sadly he passed away in 2010 I don't know how much more recorded material there is out there of him that's yet to be a release that would still sound fresh and interest his fanbase so I don't know this this might be the last new recording with his piano playing on it too to come out this album comes Sunday it's Charlie Hayden on upright bass Hank Jones on piano just reinventing all of these spirituals gospel songs and hymns and traditional songs folk songs as well you know I never really bring it up but I've always kind of had a real sweet spot for this kind of music I actually even subscribe to a YouTube channel called strolling down memory lane that throws up that kind of music all the time there's just a really sweet gentle and warm aura around this kind of music this kind of music is the building block for a lot of American music it's the roots it's the blueprint to all the jazz that Charlie Hayden and Hank Jones played throughout their career and this kind of music was a huge inspiration to tons of singer songwriters especially one of my favorites Tom Waits now this is not the first time that Charlie Haden and Hank Jones have collaborated on a project like this actually released an album professor of mine turned me on to in college that was put out in 1995 called steal away where they're pretty much going in the same direction just reinventing reinterpreting tunes from that same style from that same traditional music era if you've ever wanted to listen to music that just felt like it had lots of dignity dignity then this is definitely a must listen even though come Sunday was recorded around 15 years after steal away was the intent of what Hayden and Jones want to do with these songs has remained roughly the same they just performed them together just very softly very quietly but also very intently they don't just let these songs Breeze by you know for the most part they kind of try to leave their fingerprints on these versions and the way that they play these songs out with this very solemn this very kind of clean performance it's really like kind of going to an old country church and just everything is very you know rootsy and rural but also very beautiful and charming know even though I really like steal away I am like income Sunday too but I do feel like I'm a little on the fence with it as well and it's mostly because of similarities it has and doesn't have with steal away on steal away you just got one reinterpretation after another of these old standbys that were quiet but very passionately played and the tone of the instruments was really nice to the bass was soft but very punchy very kind of mmm had some thickness to it and the piano though it was quiet it had these very light lush rushes of sound sometimes - and Hank Jones displayed a lot of very nimble playing when win win win but the one thing this album doesn't do as much as steal away is embellish these songs I don't know if it was because they were recording this project years and years later or if they really wanted to simplify their approach to these songs they really kind of want the songs to stand on their own and kind of not distract from that with the flashy playing or something but there are some tracks on here like down by the riverside or blessed assurance where Hank and Charlie just really are playing it straight sure there are some solos on that track but there are also moments like God rest ye merry gentlemen where it seems like they'll go through the entire track and play it so plainly and so rigidly that I really start getting kind of bored with it I'm not really looking for these tracks to be really jazzed up and upbeat or anything like that I mean I think there are some songs on here that benefit from the quiet volume of this album like the opening track take my hand precious Lord which is just played so slowly and so softly that it just reaches new levels of beauty for me and those are the spots that really hit me on this album the heaviest there are songs on here like give me that old-time religion where it does feel more upbeat it is performed pretty well it is embellished really nicely you've got those spots like I said that are so soft filled with dignity filled with beauty and then again you've got this other side to this album that feels so straightforward so unchanged that I could almost hear any two musicians playing it this way you know which is a bit of a shame because yeah I am here to listen to the tunes because the tunes are beautiful the tunes are gorgeous the tunes are well-traveled the tunes here have wit stood the test of time but I'm also here to listen to Hank and Charlie and I think I would have enjoyed this record a little bit more if I felt like they were more in balance with some of these songs like they weren't sort of letting the songs overshadow them at some points still I think this is a pretty good album they're unag Norah Belen fluence is coming from the world of shoegaze music as well most all cest songs bring a really vast and dreamy wall of sound that is kind of iced with very sweet cleanly sung vocals it's a sound that a lot of new bands have been chasing after for the past four years mostly because projects like all sets and wolves in the throne room have brought this style of metal so much of visibility but to be completely honest out of all the groups chasing after this atmosphere black metal style this black gaze style some people call it all sussed has never really been one of my favorites I get the frontman for this band needs a lot of credit because he's built a name for himself on this sound and he's also been involved in a lot of other forward-thinking metal projects that I have a lot of respect for like land lows or pests moire but most of the characteristics that I didn't like about previous all cest releases continue on to this album you know out of all the black metal and black metal influenced rock that I've ever heard I think all Seth's music is definitely definitely the most pleasant sounding but I don't think that's because it's uniquely pretty or beautiful or anything like that I think there are artists who are working in the same arena as this album but have pulled together songs that feel prettier to me like wolves in the throne room and even that last Agalloch album was really great I think all sets music comes off as pleasant because it doesn't really ever present anything all that gripping or exciting or challenging it doesn't really push any buttons for the most part on these tracks you get very very sleepy sleepy vocals lost in this wall of sound that doesn't really have all that much character to me a lot of the songs on this album sound very big and vast and airy but I'm not really catching an interesting sound or flavor that keeps me locked in the sound you know not to be brutal about it but I just feel like it's it's kinda kind of bland but the thing is I'm not too in love with the songs on this album either I feel like a lot of tracks on this LP come off as a little repetitive especially the song beings of light the chords and the the very light heavenly background vocals on the track go on for for almost ever the opener really underwhelmed me a lot of tracks on this album really underwhelming I don't feature all that much variety the only two tracks on here that I really really liked were the second track and the track havens toward the end of the album they're longer songs on the album but they really justify their length by featuring more detailed song structures lots of changes lots of builds and both tracks actually featured screaming vocals on them too which you know may turn off some people but it really broke up the man me the biggest surprise on this album though came on the last track it just has this chord progression these riffs that really remind me of like a Foo Fighters palette or something but they just have the the heaviness and in the vocal mix of like a Jesu song yes in case you yeah to us it was pretty entertaining to hear all sets make that change but it's it's nothing I was in love with you know I just feel like this project isn't for me I think it comes from an interesting angle if you're the kind of person who isn't really big into metal but you're kind of curious though it is heavy it is loud it does have an element of lightness to it lots of melody lots of harmony it just doesn't feel all that bold to me I guess I'm kind of feeling a light 5 on this but what do you think of this thing especially if you're a fan of this project did this album excite you did you love it hate it let me know Anthony Fantino all cest you

Hey hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time not for an album review for an EP review zoom Udo idiom wind zoom Udo is a project spearheaded by singer songwriter multi-instrumentalist Nicky Muto one half of the experimental music duo the books who actually came out with one of my favorite albums of 2010 the way out that's it right there and their Nixa Muto has released music under solo capacity before but most of it was before he actually started releasing full-length LPS with the books so this EP is a return back to that solo capacity but Nick is not really playing the same material that he was years ago when he was releasing music under this name there elements of funk and electronica and noise flowing throughout these tracks and the singer-songwriter element that sort of popped its head up a lot more on the way out shows up on this EP in full force the first track to come off of this EP is the title track and it starts with some really kind of wavy Airy chords rising and falling really quickly and then these strings sort of fly in to back it up and they sound very very tender very beautiful then all of a sudden this booming bass guitar comes in and Nixon Muto's really kind of friendly boyish vocal takes my ears on a tour through all these really pretty sounds and in the lyrics I kind of feel like he's giving me a little bit of life advice he's talking about a person's education and how it's not worth a damn how this person is also kind of headstrong surrounded in tragedy it's easily my favorite song off of this and you pee because I'm as enthralled with the song and the lyrics as I am the sounds that surround it this track and the other tracks on here to feature are really kind of odd mix and it gives the song an interesting character like the drums the hi-hat is just so loud and just so in my face whereas the the snare drum sort of seems to be coming in under that and the bass drum sometimes feels like it's just non-existent the music gets even odder on the second track fu c-3po great title on this song samples sort of come into play which makes it kind of feel like the most books esque song on this EP you've got a kind of funny sample starting things off talking about the human race and it may be saying well maybe it's not but I kind of feel like these these very watery swirling vibra phones that pop up in the background here and they're on this track maybe lifted from something else over that Nick the Muto's voice is just kind of manipulated with all these robotic vocoder vocals and those aren't even half the sounds that pop up in this track there are just like harsh shots of noise all sorts of inexplicable textures and Tambor's it's like half of the sounds in this track were created by like a mad sound scientist in his underground lair muhahahaha lightning bolt lightning bolt some of the moments on this track feels so overwhelming it's kind of like getting a bucket of bolts dumped on your head and I kind of sort of mean that as a compliment the last track on the EP has a really nimble beat and it grooves hard and it's got this really idiosyncratic quality to it as all these sounds are kind of pushing along it's really rhythmic manner the vocals are kind of singing in this in this very monotone cultish delivery the more I listen to the track the more I just saw reminded me a little bit of they might be giants and there are a lot of noises on this track too but they all kind of melt into each other in a really interesting way sometimes they swirl they bleed into one another sometimes I kind of feel like the goal of this EP was to throw as many sounds as many noises into some of these tracks as possible but still maintain some kind of semblance of musicality I think the one downside to the third track is that it ends a little abruptly for I kind of feel like it repeats itself a little bit too much towards its finish and then just kind of still it drums up some interesting sounds I do have some other complaints about this EP though I kind of feel like I'm just on the fence with the overall sound and and recording of this thing though I do think zoom Udo is going for something pretty bold pretty noisy something that is evolving past what the books have been doing recently it still ends up sounding kind of demo ish kind of thin because there are some spots on here where I'm just hearing a ton of sounds that I feel like would would come across so much better if there was just more space in between them this recording is just kind of claustrophobic and that doesn't really complement all the subtleties I hear on some of these tracks like I may hear an acoustic guitar or something or some odd vocal samples murmuring away in the background that I wish I could hear a bit more and I do kind of run into the problem with this EP that I do with most EPS and that's leaving this thing feeling kind of hungry for more so overall I did think this EP was really good though would listen again and I'm really looking forward to more music coming out of this project kind of feel like seven on this but what do you think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana zum udo Fuhrer you

the weakened echoes of silence hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd in it's time for an album review the weekend echoes of silence the weekend is a Canadian experimental R&B project fronted by vocalist and songwriter able to say hey this is not the first time I'm running into this project though I did a review the month this project dropped its debut release house of balloons and to be honest it was one of my most negative reviews of last year not only that but I think it was definitely in the top 5 for biggest negative backlash from viewers and yeah you know I said the weekend was a group possibly during a time when how many people were involved and who was involved wasn't common knowledge but that wasn't a big issue the big issue was just people angry and confused over how I could not like this release wha-ah-ah how could I possibly say there might be auto-tune used as an effect not a crutch somewhere on some of these songs moral of the story people hate differing opinions but I love them so so yeah I didn't like house of balloons I thought it was really nice that this project wanted to experiment with R&B sounds and emotions and subject matters but in a way I just felt like it kind of went horribly horribly wrong I mean the album shop for dark moody and depressing but I think it just ended up sounding kind of whiny a little douchey and it was mostly because of the lyrics a lot of misogyny and drug endorsements and partying and trivial relationship stuff not that those subject matters are bad but I felt like they weren't really handled with all that much poeta sysm I just felt like some of the lyrics were really trashy and shallow what do you want I still came away from this thing thinking you know this guy's experimenting he's got his own style and whether or not I like a weekend album I've got to respect that then the EP Thursday dropped about five months later and you know the production was noticeably better it got up to a little bit but I was still catching a lot of lyrics on these tracks that I didn't care for even Drake who was one of the guys who originally co-signed this project appeared on here spitting a verse and you know honestly I liked hearing the weekend on Drake stuff more than I like hearing the Drake on the weekend stuff I didn't review Thursday but I didn't come away hating it I just kind of felt like I was on the fence with it so just before Christmas the weekend drops this new tape brand new tape echoes of silence and I liked it a lot ah-oh and I think echoes of silence pushes past the previous two releases in every way the production on this thing is a lot better just the sounds are larger the atmosphere is more vast and some of the vocal effects that really annoyed me on previous weekend releases are just not here I feel like echoes is way more upfront with Abel's voice it feels more nude I guess sure there are some edits and some spots of reverb here and there on his voice that are very apparent but his voice just feels really bare and to prove how great the vocals are in the weekend the project faces its biggest challenge yet and that's a Michael Jackson cover of the song Dirty Diana and that's kind of fitting when you consider what the weekend usually sings about but still huge shoes to fill it's the King of Pop off-the-wall thriller and bad or killer albums and not just anybody can step up to bat on these songs in my opinion I think the weekend passes with flying colors on this track it has the explosion of drama and catchiness that the original does but it has this dark sad depression that the weekend is known for brought into the equation Abel's voice some range show some really eerie similarities to Michaels and it's so close sometimes it's almost like listening to a remix and with all these heavy beats and rising cents and really chilly background vocals it's an excellent take on the song it almost feels like industrial at some spots but still after the cover was over I figured you know I'm not going to like the rest of the songs the lyrics are going to be different the vocals are going to be different it's not going to be a song I'm already familiar with it's just going to go downhill but that wasn't the case though I feel like instead of falling back on its usual R&B flavor the weekend sticks with pop on the second track Montreal here the weekend crafts are really lean and memorable pop tune with relatable lyrics it's not just a really uneventful song where you get a repetitive B for five minutes with nothing but just vocalizing about a drug binge over it the song Montreal opens up with lyrics sung in French and then develops into this kind of tasteful story about loneliness love and a relationship on the rocks and even when this thing gets on the subject of sex on the next track it doesn't feel cheap like previous weekend tracks it's not like I'm hearing lyrics like fuck you right instead I'm hearing this story about how one person is sleeping with another despite the fact that there are memories of an ex in that person's head and kind of the sour addition to the stories that both people know the same goes for the party tracks on this album they don't really feel cheap or shallow I actually feel the depression this time the situation actually feels serious the party isn't fun anymore all the drugs alcohol and sex are leading to addiction drained bank accounts and lost time your father doesn't know where you are there's no rent money your mother is crying because she found your bag of weed and the laundry I feel like these moments are painted with the same powerful imagery that Danny Brown pulled out on tracks like party all the time and nosebleed off of the triple XL let me drop last year and of course the synthesizers and the beat behind this track are just huge and mournful it's like they're kind of acknowledging that the person being sung about in the song is already dead but the thing is it's not over the drugs and the sex and the twisted nosov the lyrics on this album gets even deeper on the next song I mean Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas requiem for a dream kind of twisted and it's interesting because as the drugs are getting heavier on the fifth track initiation the vocals are getting all manipulated and pitch shifted in really unpredictable directions almost like the listener is tripping out along with the person being son about it's kind of disturbing and when the song ends this release slips into slightly less unsettling territory with same old song which is kind of a personal story about passing up the chance to be with a girl who didn't want you when you were nothing but now that you're something she's calling and that's not really the most unique story in music but what's kind of funny is that I feel like that gets acknowledged in the hook talking about how this girl and the situation itself is like the same old song and I like the able is just really belting out these lyrics over the hook I mean I am really feeling this hook threw him off I love how he left all of his really huge breaths in while he was singing that hook it just really kind of made a feel even more emotive to just it just felt really just really crushing of course really moody instrumental helps the situation it has this really lumbering beat very kind of subtle icy guitar in the background the song the fall is okay I wish it was more eventful but the beat is decent produced by clams Casino and it does have an interesting story showing that there's always kind of a shade of doubt in the background somewhere no matter how confident the weekend gets the track talks about Fame being kind of like a drug high and it doesn't last forever in fact pretty much every song from track 6 to track 9 talks about how Fame has somehow changed ables love life or personal life and it's not like he comes off cocky or insecure or overcompensating like some artists sign it's more like listen you're only trying to get with me because I'm starting to get popular it's not going to last forever anyway you're crazy echoes of silence brings the personality the lyrics and the level of production I would have liked to have heard from this project in the first place but you know it's been pretty interesting following the weekends exploits up until this point and the fact that I thought this thing was great only kind of makes my mouth water even more when I think about the album the weekend has coming out later this year so as far as R&B goes the weekend is definitely more creative sound rich and more interesting than any other R&B artist out there I feel like that was true since house of balloons but at this point with echoes of silence I feel like that actually means something right now I feel like this is the bar and it's set here I'm feeling a decent two strong 8 on this thing thought it was great but um let me know what you think do you love it do you hate it why what do you think I should review next do you feel like there's actually been a noticeable improvement a change in this project or am I just crazy and liking it all of a sudden I don't know Anthony Fantana The Weeknd echoes of silence burn [Music] you [Music]

guided by voices they're back hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review this is the latest LP from guided by voices a legendary Ohio indie rock group I mentioned them in my recent Neutral Milk Hotel review where I said they were experimenting and innovating along with some of the greatest underground and Lofa rock acts of the 90s and part of what made guided by voices so unique is just the amount of influences that their music showcase just psychedelic rock British Invasion blues garage punk and post-punk prog rock art rock power pop noise just avant-garde tracks that didn't really seem to have any kind of form or direction guided by voices albums are notorious for just not sticking to one thing which is what part of what keeps listening through guided by voices album so interesting because you never know where the next song is gonna go the only thing that brought many of these bands releases any consistency was their low fiber cording style Robert Pollard's vocals and just this general oddness now this is the first album guided by voices has released since a hiatus they imposed on themselves in 2004 and now they're back with an older older lineup that used to be around when guided by voices was considered to be putting out some of their best material and this album is kind of being promoted as a return to form or return to some of the Bands best LPS like be thousand and alien lanes and even though the hiatus guided by voices took wasn't really all that long this band getting back together has stirred up a lot of talk again and it doesn't look like these guys are going to jump in and jump out either because we've got this record and another record coming down the pipe spring this year titled class clown spots a UFO but for now we have this record the first installment says these guys have gotten back together let's go eat the factory on this LP we have almost two dozen songs of various lengths styles and audio qualities guided by voices really is up to its old tricks again because they have really turned their back on the cleaner sounds and the more developed songwriting or the more traditional songwriting rather that was on their later releases this LP is pretty much everything you would expect from a classic guided by voices album it really has everything maybe it's not as low Phi as it used to be but I think the only thing it's truly truly missing is the nineties you know like a time period when this stuff would have sounded fresh and groundbreaking not to say this album is terrible not to say it's bad but sometimes going backwards to reclaim past glory can be a little like setting yourself up for failure hardcore fans will be pleased and that's not necessarily a bad thing as far as the meat and potatoes of this album goes I just think it's a load of hits and misses but it's mostly hits right from the opening track the the very distorted and low fyg ATAR chords are back drums are buried in the mix and Robert Pollard's very aged vocalists just kind of lost in the chaos and the track still has that guided by voices calling card of of sounding like something I've heard somewhere before but kind of like a bizarro version of it the next moment on this LP where a song really hits me is definitely don't afore a snow man it's one of the weirdest and prettiest tunes on this album these really lazy flat vocals are delivering this this very strange and surreal imagery that I have no idea how to interpret and you know even though the vocals do feel a little off pitch they're kind of also very calming to me too because they don't seem very eerie forceful just really chill though the guitar chords just had this really kind of friendly character to them and the overall feel the song is just really and inviting the tune is sure but it ties everything up really nicely toward the end the track hang mr. kite is a nice change of pace on the album there is nothing in the way of Pollard's voice and he just has this kind of godly atmospheric reverb on his vocal he is singing about this kite there are these very sobering cellos in the background it just has this heavy heavy feeling of seriousness to it but I don't know what is so serious about it as far as length goes it's another short track but guided by voices really knows how to pack a lot of punch when they want to in a short amount of time another track where I feel like Pollard's voice kind of steals the spotlight is my Europa and that song is nothing more than just his vocal and a guitar with a with a watery sort of affect on it it's kind of noisy but the vocal melody in the hook is just really striking to me the song old bones which actually in a way kind of sounds like a very chilled out sense scape diversion of auld lang syne was so pretty that I almost I wanted to cry a little bit to it those are like my favorites you know but there are a lot of tracks on here that I feel like have nice qualities but they don't stick to me all that much the song waves has this really kind of fun droney quality to it Imperial race horsing has a really nice touch of horns on it and the big hat and Toy Show is like a blues jam going horribly horribly wrong but in a kind of a luring way a lot of tracks on here just don't have hooks that stick with me or they end so abruptly they don't leave an impact I just know some of the tracks here would have been more likable to me if they were more fleshed out and I know that's that's a weird request or expectation for a guided by voices record but that sometimes I just feel like this album is just a scramble of different song sketches I think some people would call it filler I wouldn't call it filler though because some of the song ideas on here pretty good overall I thought this helped he was pretty good not exactly breaking new ground something for the fans but still standing proudly as a righteous pillar of we yes but what does Cal think sky with their voices it's not like I'm a psychic now lalla gist we have fun here feelin a strong six yeah but a strong six on this but what do you think do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony Fantino guided by voices forever

hey hey hey hey hey hey Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review the internet purple naked ladies the Internet is a neo-soul and experimental R&B project from two members of Odd Future Sid the Kid and Matt Martians aka the jet age of tomorrow these guys aren't really the flagship members of Odd Future but that's kind of the reason I was excited to hear this thing because well they're not Hodgy Beats or Tyler the Creator they're going to be different different there have been two jet age of tomorrow releases so far and they've mostly consisted of instrumentals blends of electronic and soul music ambient music hip hop and as far as Sid goes we're really yet to hear from her in a full-length album capacity so I did kind of go into this LP hoping I would hear something that would kind of just salvage my hope in odd future because pretty much everything they've put out this year has just not done anything for me but after numerous listens this debut LP from the Internet does not sound all that much different from a jet age of tomorrow album bubble just a combination of soul hip hop R&B electronics that all feels like it was thrown together quickly in fruity loops and the worst thing about this album is that it kind of sounds like things that I love but it it just stops short of being that when I hear this album I just hear this really Spacey synthetic world of R&B and jazz and electronics that reminds me of artists like Thundercat or the logos or even subtract I might throw in there and maybe that Erykah Badu album that came out last year but purple naked ladies does not impress me on the same levels that that those artists do I mean just kind of take the intro track for example violet nude women it's kind of Spacey an atmosphere but it's also a little and - once the song ends up falling into the groove later in the track I just hear this really tinny guitar that I don't like it all these cooing vocals that kind of get buried underneath this mess of sequence percussion and synthesizers it just like I said feels like a mess there are all these sounds here that feel like they're in the same key but they don't really manage to complement each other in any obvious way most of the beats and instrumentals on this thing just kind of passed me by didn't really stick with me or impress me or anything like that and some of them just felt really really really lazy kind of like fast lane and Lincoln there were only a handful of beats on here that I really thought were great the song visions for one had a fantastic beat that was really clear groove going on and I loved the chopped-up guitar freezes on there those were very nice touch the instrumental just has this really kind of watery quality to it and some great vocals from a guest vocalist on here Koko oh but the sad thing about that track is that it's so kind of short so short that it doesn't really kind of leave an impact on me I guess the song she don't give a fuck had a really nice jazzy feel to the instrumental and the song cont was pretty out there had a lot of nice transitions in it but it just didn't add up into a track that I thought was great the instrumental on lovesong felt really really tender felt really sweet I loved the cute little shy synth chords kind of stashed away in the background the beats are one thing I just kind of feel like I'm on the fence with them where this album doesn't really do it for me at all are with the vocals and with the lyrics since singing voice when you measure it up to other musicians in this style of music is not that strong I mean one of her guests koko out sings her by by a mile Syd's voice just does not carry much of a tune I would say on spots on here like the introduction to the song cocaine her voice almost borders on just tone-deafness and on a handful the tracks here it feels like SIDS voice is kind of fighting to be heard with some of these instrumentals - you know there are some spots here where the vocals do feel decent like on the first verse they say shangri-la but they're just not consistently decent you know and as far as the lyrics go I feel like they kind of show that this LP is kind of shallow like many other odd future releases take the song cocaine for example definitely one of the most mindless drug songs I've ever heard in my life to be completely honest it doesn't even look at the upsides or the downsides of cocaine or talk about cocaine poetically the lyrics just kind of paint this really short and vague story of Syd trying to seduce someone into into doing coke with lyrics like just follow me and do you want to do some kind of okay I just don't like the lyrics at all what's even worse is that left-brain who is really not one of odd futures best rappers comes in and spits this really short verse I'm high on coke she high on coke coast to coast baby flow of my boat a lot of the love and lust songs on here are just as empty you know don't assume that just because you're hearing a love song it's deep there's just a lot of filler lyrics on these tracks like hey baby hey girl I'll never web of me because I couldn't really make out a lot of the lyrics overall to me this album just feels thrown together the vocals are pretty off sometimes the lyrics really aren't that great a few of anthony Fantana the internet forever [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and this video is the last review of classics review week Neutral Milk Hotel in the aeroplane over the sea originally I was not planning to review this album I even kind of made a video about how I wasn't planning to review this album and why I was talking about the virally infectious and sometimes ridiculous cult status that this album has I asked you guys what you thought about it and you let me know and some of you made some really convincing arguments talking about how the people who are making a mockery of this LP are in the minority and if that's all I address I sort of let them win I'm sort of making a mountain out of the molehill of jokes that there are around the internet in regards to this album and not making a video where I kind of focus away from those things hurts this album more than it helps it plus the thing is reviewing this album really isn't that big of a deal an album is really only as important as you make it out to be so Neutral Milk Hotel was an experimental indie and full crock banned from Ruston Louisiana they only came out with a couple albums in their very short discography and the second that they dropped just so happens to be one of the most celebrated releases in underground music released back in 1998 people still go nuts for this album and it just has this staying power that not a lot of releases see but for me it's it's not hard to understand why I think this album has a lot of great qualities going for it this thing has a really bold sound built out of inspiration from noise rock from psychedelic rock and folk music hailing from Scotland Eastern Europe and America plus there is a heavy in luhan's coming from the 90s lo-fi rock scene contemporaries like guided by voices and said oh so this album definitely has a lot of influences going for it but on top of that it's extremely well arranged colorfully arranged with singing saws and horns and accordion keyboards bagpipes as well and plus the usual suspects are here acoustic guitar warm heavy distorted overblown bass and some really hard-hitting drums too with all these different sounds and textures in the aeroplane over the seat perfectly complements heaviness and noise and aggression with tenderness and beauty it's a style the project really built up to with a handful of demos and a debut album on Avery Island Avery is not the preferred album but it shares a lot of elements within the aeroplane a lot of the songs on here have similar chord progressions a very low fie and overblown sound influences from folk music psychedelic rock music and very surreal lyricism to all it was really missing was this just cohesive theme when I listened to in the aeroplane over the sea as opposed to Avery Island I feel like I'm really partaking in a story plus in the aeroplane just had this grand Jubilee of horns and just all this extra instrumentation to really kind of bring it to a next level plus in the airplane really has a a daunting a daunting sadness that just is hard to deny and it's hard to deny because it just does not let up almost every song on this LP looks for a different way to advance that feeling so funny is that sometimes I don't even know why this album gets me so emotional and and I guess I say I don't know why because it's not like I really get a clear clear and totally comprehensible story out of any one of these songs of course people have read interviews that talk about what has inspired these lyrics but what inspired these lyrics and what these lyrics actually are are two different things I just prefer to take the lyrics as they are the less you know the more disturbing they kind of become the imagery is so vivid and yet when I actually try to imagine what Jeff Mangum is singing about on these tracks it's like my brain has this malfunction it's like does not compute we really remember I mean how exactly does one picture a little boy in Spain playing pianos filled with flames it doesn't look like that no the lyrics are really where this album hits hardest for me I think everything else on this LP is great but it wouldn't add up to as much as it does if it wasn't for Jeff Mangum using his lyricism to build from scratch this really surreal world of two-headed boys ghosts tomatoes and radio wire the abstract imagery on this thing is so out there sometimes it rivals the fantasy world created in the book Alice in Wonderland the stories sometimes just feel so nonsensical but for me they have such a huge emotional impact anyway with all these themes of death and God and love and genocide and war and saving somebody's life and intimacy and family and all these stories are delivered in Jeff Mangum's kind of nasally voice it's it's weird it's like there's no stomach in his voice whatsoever it's like it's all up here and on a good chunk of this album he's like kind of straining his voice partially out of trying to reach the higher points of his register and partially because he's just forcing himself to sing so hard and so loud the dude must have a massive lung capacity because if you actually try to sing along with this album you'll see it's it's pretty difficult sometimes it's like the dude will go a whole verse without taking a breath I know there are some people out there who don't like Jeff's voice and are not going to like Jeff's voice but I enjoy it has a unique tone to it and he's on pitch for the most part and he just showcases a lot of personality and a lot of passion another critique this album often gets is it's simple simple chords simple songs simple melodies it's really simple but you know I think that's kind of an odd point an album being bad because it's simple I mean this thing is pretty funky it's not exactly looking to be technical overly progressive or anything like that but I do see the complaint you know if you've been playing guitar consistently for a year you can most likely play every single song on this album if you were handed the chords but I think the simplicity issue is a little overblown I mean take for example the way the king of carrot flowers part two builds up so noisily and so heavily into part three or the way the song ghost escalates towards its finish line not every album and band can do that stuff the greatness of these songs doesn't come out in their
