vielen classic hey everybody Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd classics Week continues with a review of the Marvin Gaye album what's going on Marvin Gaye is unquestionably one of the greatest and most influential soul singers to have ever lived the dude spent most of his life in the music business singing writing doing session drumming as well and a lot of his early career was spent singing soul pop duo op standards and he turned out some hits that are still widely celebrated today like how sweet it is to be loved by you and what's probably the most famous cover of heard through the grapevine he also put out a handful of very notable duet records with soul singer Tammi Terrell one of which featured the most popular version of ain't no mountain high enough now in the latter half of Marvin's career he kind of strengthened his image as a sex symbol by dealing in the funkier and smoother side of soul which dominated the 70s tracks like let's get it on I want you and one of his last hits sexual healing but these two sections of Marvin's career are separated by this album and this year just so happens to mark the 40th anniversary of this LP too for Marvin this record was a huge change in sound in subject matter and in the amount of control he had over the music he was making he deviated from his usual Motown sound to make what is his most widely known album and it's funny that this record is the one in his discography that is the biggest and considered to be the most untouchable I'm just saying the general public usually prefers its music to be a bit more blissful but you've got to consider that this record came out in the 70s which wasn't exactly the brightest spot in American history yeah the Vietnam War going on Nixon was in office there were all sorts of protests feminists and environmentalists were gaining ground in the mainstream it was a time when people most of which I'm sure were the young music buying public saw the world around them and they didn't like the way it looked and they wanted some kind of way to change it and what's going on just seems like an appropriate soundtrack for that the album opens up with the title track and the first single from this LP and it really kind of sets the lyrical stage for this LP promoting love together 'no sand a really strong anti-war message and it focuses on the way all this turmoil effects individual people brothers mothers sisters fathers Marvin Gaye really tries to make listeners connect with what's going on by kind of bringing this family aspect into the lyrics and in most cases something like this would just hit me as as corny I think maybe it's it's a decent critique to say this album is pretty corny sometimes that's how I felt about it at first but Marvin to me just comes across so positive and sincere in what he's saying and the production just makes the world that Marvin is sending this message from seem so heavenly and beautiful it kind of makes me want to be a part of it I can feel this way about the entire album but I think this song specifically cleanses the soul if somebody really listens to it I think it has the potential to just tear every shred of hate out of a person you can call me a dirty hippie with bad facial hair if you want but I think the world would be a lot better off more people took the message behind this song to heart now the side of this track the sound of this album to me is stellar usually I'm not so much into really arranged and string kissed pop in soul music but the strings just are worked into this album so well and the grooves move along really fluidly most of my issues with tracks that are really heavily arranged is that the groove kind of gets lost in the mess on here the grooves stay intact there's this vast atmospheric reverb on Marvin Gaye's vocals that are very soothing background vocals as well they're warm nimble bass lines all over this album as well as very light hand percussion too lots of finger snaps like I said these very honey-flavored string arrangements they're smooth saxophone flourishes interjecting on one song after another and then there's Marvin's vocal he is the cherry on top he's got such a strong voice just so much strength in every part of his range just so much control passion charisma and all of his vocal improv throughout these tracks really add to the album for me too but it moved the first track just kind of quickly segues into the second track a lot of the tracks on this album just kind of flow into one another without a barrier in between and I like that a lot it makes the second track on here kind of feel like part 2 of the first because it does deal in a lot of the same feelings and lyrical subject matters that the first track does but it's kind of song from the standpoint of a soldier who's just come home from war and it's pretty funny how four years later a lot of the messages on this LP are still pretty relevant Marvin drifts away from this portrait of a soldier to pull out a track on the third song that deals with drug addiction on flyin high and that song just takes an interesting turn of mood as it just kind of segues into Save the Children which is a pretty self-explanatory song title definitely the corniest moment on here but I think the track beautifully packages the argument the idea that we should live today thinking about how the world will look tomorrow because the next generation is going to have to live in it now what's interesting is that two tracks on the album god is love and holy Olli kind of reveal the feelings the sentiments behind this album as being kind of religiously inspired it reproduces standpoint and the song mercy mercy me kind of attacks things from an environmental angle now overall what's going on has a really solid sound and style going for it it doesn't really vary all that much from the idea of soul it doesn't change up its instrumentation a whole lot there is one notable change in sound on here though and it's the seven-minute track right on which has a very Latin flavor to its rhythm section in piano chords I can't really say much else about this record other than I give it a really high high recommendation it's just a really fantastic piece of soul a seminal record for the genre it's uplifting it's positive it's a righteous record it's very feel-good it's well performed well recorded well written I can't really think of anything that I personally take issue with on here I mean yeah I could totally agree with you or understand where you're coming from if this record is too sweet for you maybe it's a little too slick overproduced I personally am not much of a religious person so maybe I don't completely relate to when this album goes down that road but I think the messages behind this LP are something that even a secular person can get behind I'm going to leave it at that what do you guys think of this record do you love it do you hate it have you heard it is it one of your faves does this record speak to you or is it just kind of to Cal Church esta really quick quick Marvin Gaye what's going on forever [Music]

[Music] hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and I'm here to do a question statement comment thing as everybody knows I've been sort of reviewing some of my favorite albums ever this week some classics and of course over the course of doing these reviews I've been getting tons and tons and tons of requests and messages and comments asking me to review the seminal Neutral Milk Hotel album in the aeroplane over the sea of course this is the first time somebody's asked me to review this record I've been getting requests to review this record for years and I'm not complaining I'm always flattered that you guys are interested in what I think about a song record a band whatever but I am hesitant to review this album and it has nothing whatsoever to do with the music on it in fact I own this record I love it I think it's one of the best in the genre the reason I'm hesitant to review this album is because there's this really kind of unique cult fanaticism surrounding this LP that not a lot of artists and albums have this is in the case of in the aeroplane over the sea there is fanaticism and some of it sounds like the fanaticism that you would find with any other band but a lot of it is stuff like this it's a potato it's a tambourine semen-stained the mountain tops I love you Jesus cries yeah Frank and Frank and Frank can't gah gah gah gah gah gah gah boo boo boo boo boo boo boo boo boo boo it's like when people bring this album up there's this subtly intentional comedy to it in their heads like the more they mention this album post-its album cover and mentioned catchphrases from it the funnier it gets so it kind of makes me wonder am i reviewing music or am i reviewing a meme I think this thing is a fantastic record an amazingly abstract and beautiful record but the fact that it's kind of become a series of jokes to be typed and repeated in all caps all over the internet is really depressing to me and I think it destroys the feelings behind this record and the thing is if you think this album is amazing as I do then you probably don't need me to come in here and then say it's good and justify your tastes I just I just I just I just have a sneaking suspicion that a great deal of the people begging me to review this album just want me to fan the flames of this meme wildfire it's to a point where the joke is overshadowing the music itself now if you haven't heard this album screw the hype screw the repeated and recycled catchphrases just listen to it for yourself hear it out open heart open mind if ever seems to be a point in time when this album can be reviewed and then taken seriously then I'll consider it until then anything I put out about this album including this video will most likely continue this series of jokes that kind of makes a mockery of this LP so what do you think is this album still music or has the internet essentially turned it into a meme is the fanaticism behind this LP mostly people joking or is there some love in there to do Anthoni Fantana in the aeroplane over the sea forever [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for another album review classics week continues celebrating 50k 50k wu-tang clan enter the wu-tang 36 chambers wu-tang is a still active New York hip-hop outfit that was formed in the early 90s this is their debut LP dropped in 1993 and it's been followed up with numerous studio albums since but whoo tang is one of those groups whose debut LP kind of overshadows the rest of their albums people usually don't give the rest of their material the time of day even though albums like their sophomore LP wu-tang forever are pretty good but that's not a huge issue since every single one of the group's nine members has released solo material and a lot of that is as essential as 36 chambers like Ghostface Killah solo stuff which is my favorite out of all of the wu-tang clan's solo release material fish-scale ironman supreme clientele also Raekwon with only built 4 Cuban Linx parts 1 & 2 ol Dirty Bastard with the return of the 36 chambers the dirty version and of course we can't forget the jizzes Liquid Swords those are some of my favorites but no matter how much I like those albums this release is the Alpha this is where it all goes back to this is where it starts and you must start now whoo tang and this album were an essential part to the evolving face of hip-hop in the 90s this album is a move past the golden age hip-hop sounds that came out in the 80s the jazz rap and socially conscious rap sounds that were being dropped by groups like De La Soul and A Tribe Called Quest in the in the very early 90s and late 80s and the West Coast sounds of gangsta rap that were being dropped at the time too by guys like Ice Cube and waa and dr. dre keep in mind this is just a really quick abridged version of this evolution there are a lot more artist sounds and albums at work here because when people talk about this era of hip-hop especially the west coast side of things groups like freestyle fellowship for example are often forgotten so in the early in mid 90s the New York hip-hop scene was reinventing itself as something much grittier tougher more aggressive and ready to battle of course there are a lot of individual New York emcees that played a role in that like nas and notorious b.i.g but wu-tang definitely stuck out and was unique in their amount of members not to say that none of these guys would have made it if they've stayed solo their entire career but wu-tang power clearly comes from strength in numbers because with nine different people and seeing on these really hard-hitting stripped down beats this album sort of gives the atmosphere the feel of a never-ending cypher a rap battle there are a couple songs here where one MC will take the spotlight Method Man where Method Man is all over that song and of course claim in the front where GZA is pretty much featured on that track but on the majority of the tracks here is just one MC after another taking turns on these beats and because of that it sounds like they're way more hyped than they would be otherwise it's like a competition it makes this record come off with just a lot of energy and energy that is really infectious and with tracks that have gang courses like ain't nothing to fuck with and these really hard hard grooves and rize's beats this album has just a ton of momentum which makes it really hard for me to just not go nuts when listening to this thing and because most of this album sounds like a rap battle there's a very specific kind of lyricism going on amidst these tracks hilarious insults cartoony violence a barrage of brags and non sequiturs and cultural references there's about as much ferocity and testosterone on this as like a hardcore punk record so there's no question that enter the wu-tang is meant to be raw rugged dirty and stoned but it's music you know it's entertainment there's no reason to take a lot of the violence and bragging on this LP that seriously because it's so outlandish and ridiculous the real goal here is just to kind of be extreme and out there which i think is definitely highlighted on a sketch that comes before the song Method Man where they're kind of going back and forth talking about torture and another clear goal here is just to be clever funny witty if you can get into the lyricism on this thing you're going to hear a lot of great wordplay and a lot of fantastic quotables and to add another level of greatness to this record I love that every single emcee on this thing comes into these tracks with a different sound and a different style I hate it when I'm listening to a rap track and it's got two three four MCS on it and they all sound the same none of them have any flavor you can't really pull anybody out is being any kind of specific or bold thing not the case here everyone on this album has their own angle Ghostface Killah is the most hyped MC out of all of them he mostly works in the upper register of his voice throws out a lot of battle raps the GZA is extremely cunning and clever in the rhymes he chooses Raekwon has this nice rasp to his voice and he pulls out a lot of vivid street life imagery Method Man has this really kind of partytime attitude he's really chilled out laid-back looking for a good time at every possible direction and ol Dirty Bastard who I think isn't the most lyrical here but he's the most fun to listen to he combines rapping with this really weird kind of off kazoo like it's he's nuts or he was rather he's got this really low voice he slurs all of his words he's like a rabid dog now let's talk about the beats a little bit I guess the beats on this thing definitely helped bring wu-tang together into this aesthetic of course there was kind of a battle rap cypher thing going on amongst these tracks but there was also a certain sound to the music behind the rapping of course the name of the group is a tribute to old kung fu movies and that definitely gets brought home in a lot of the samples and clips of dialogue from these films too in the lyrics there's a lot of talk of swordplay and martial arts and it really kind of brings this album a huge sense of of camaraderie like you're coming up against a gang of lyrical ninjas in a hip-hop dojo but overall the beats here I think it's just kind of a case of of less is more because it's not like there's a whole lot to them and not to say that they're not intricate not to say that the sounds on these beats aren't interesting I'm just saying it's definitely not like a lot of modern hip-hop which is just saturated with a ton of different sounds poppin melodic catchy hooks R&B singers on this thing like a lot of hip-hop at the time there are ton of piano samples but RZA didn't just pick some kind of sweet or soulful piano break or something like that it seemed almost as if he was choosing the most sour weird most unused melodies notes and chords that he could get his hands on because claimed in the front 7th chamber and Method Man all have really weird piano phrases laid into the beat and there are even moments like cream where all the samples come together to create something that's really kind of chilled out atmospheric and eerie the drums on here have a really punchy analogue sound that's really kind of typical for hip-hop at that time really kind of classic style and there are some songs on here that clearly sample music from the very kung-fu movies that inspire the group's aesthetic - there's just one unique sound after another in every one of these beats and it just adds to the aggressive and unsettling atmosphere of this album they're very textured instrumentals that just leave a lot of room just make space for the lyrics for the emceeing and that's perfect to me like I said these beats are just saturated with a ton of sounds like today's hip-hop and not to dis where hip-hop has gone I mean I don't think today's hip-hop is terrible I just think it's interesting when you consider how much hip-hop has changed in the almost 20 years since this album has been released so yeah on this LP there are a lot of brags battle raps and tough personalities and beats but it's not like that's the entirety of this album there are some spots on here that are worth kind of thinking about the deeper meaning of like the song cream which stands for cash rules everything around me and even though it sounds like a really kind of greedy and stereotypical hip-hop statement that song isn't really a celebration of that it's just kind of a really gritty picture of what it's like to grow up poor and you're in a position where making very fast illegal money seems like the only way out of that and the song tears which comes around the end of this LP is about friends and family members dying after making some bad decisions like deciding to have unprotected sex with a lot of different people or refusing to hand money over to somebody who's trying to mug you at gunpoint 36 Chambers is definitely an aggressive album but it's not an aggression that should make you feel threatened it's an aggression that you get you pumped this thing is just a messy grimy and unbreakable 90s hip-hop album and there's not much more to it than that this thing is a classic it's an important part of hip hop's history but if you're not a hip hop fan I'm not going to promise to you that this thing is going to change your worldview if you haven't heard this album after all 36 chambers is the archetype for a lot of the lyricism we hear in hip hop today if you haven't heard this thing before and you're just not all that school than 90's hip hop in general try this thing out and at least get a sense for where a lot of modern hip hop's ideas come from just to kind of hear them at their best for that time wu-tang 36 chambers counter chesa no one's who you know is matching up the couch asta when i spit this floor it's more electrical than Tesla send your support please free Cal so I could do some shows and tour your locale you could quote me here my rhymes are brand and clever I'm saying it now but you'll be saying it forever you

frank zappa here hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review continuing reviews of some of my favorite albums ever classics if you want to use the c-word this is not going to be a regular segment I'm only doing it for this week my heart is just not into constantly reviewing older albums I'd much rather focus on new stuff because that's what I cares about the mostest I respect the past but I don't live in it however there's no reason we can't you know do this just right now to celebrate 50k right so to continue this week I would love to talk about the Frank Zappa album hot rats Frank Zappa guitarist composer singer rock icon and musical eccentric any conversation focusing on the weirder side of American music should at least mention Frank Zappa for sure not only has the guy written a plethora a plethora of experimental music over the course of his career but there are some serious musical chops to be found in his discography but I think the most memorable attribute Zappa had to offer in his music was definitely his personality when I think of Frank Zappa's personality and how it fits into his music it's almost as if a musician from the 2000s had got transported back to the 1960s and 70s because of the sheer level of self-awareness that Zappa put into his music he was a guy that just loved to make fun of everything including what he did for a living he laced his humor and his worldview in his music at just about every opportunity that he could zappa's music poked fun at hippies and the 60s on the seminal album were only in it for the money and less than ten years later on Zoop the lures he was making fun of the disco set and his other albums are also loaded with about teen angst and love and sex and rock and roll as well as Fame and societal norms however how rats is where a lot of the joking gets kind of cast aside in order to create a set of mostly instrumental and exceptional jazz rock and jazz fusion songs which maybe the most widely admired and known in the genre Zappa was not the only guy playing with these ideas at the time though he had plenty of contemporaries fusing jazz with rock funk an avant-garde composition like Miles Davis Santana Herbie Hancock let's not forget the soft machine as well as one of my all-time favorites the Mahavishnu Orchestra but Zappa's jazz rock tracks have a much different attitude than the songs of those artists were were putting together I know I said on this record earlier the joking kind of gets put aside but the sound the style the the feelings that get conveyed on this album are so much brighter and more fun and kookier in comparison to those artists which is not usually something Rock and especially jazz fans smile upon since jazz and rocker really deep and really sure your genres of music but Zappa's compositional chops and his is playing on this record are so great it's hard not to admire what's going on here on at least some level if you don't come away from hot rats loving the entire album I think at least the first track is is worth loving or maybe liking this song peaches in regalia starts with a rush of piano chords and what kind of sounds like speedily tremolo picked guitar leads I'm not completely sure how that sound is created to be quite honest I know in the past Zappa has experimented with recording guitar solos to tape and then altering the speed of the tape in order to get an interesting effect I'm not sure if that's what's going on here but whatever it is it's a really interesting sound and gives peaches of flavor that right after this introductory moment brass and woodwinds kind of fly in and it's not like there's any instrument in this spot that hasn't been on another record clarinet saxophone that sort of thing but the way they were kind of pancaked onto one another it creates an interesting sound an interesting tone it's almost as if one instrument is creating this sound and it just ends up being so memorable because of that because of how strange and odd the instruments feel on here and of course Zapp is unique approach to writing melodies only helps that after this some flute and keyboard and guitar kind of alternate for the soloing spotlight on this track and then just before the two-minute mark there's just this Jubilee of bright bright horns that are just so triumphant they come off as being equal parts beautiful and quirky with a really close listen it becomes kind of apparent that this song is really really composed very planned out but it's great because Zappa and the musicians he brought on to this record Jam it out so fluidly it's almost as if it's just stream of consciousness this song is definitely noticeable peak in the Zappa discography in this album it's really zappas compositional side at its sharpest after the opener things get dirtier looser more kind of jammed out if you're expecting you know one kind of meticulously composed jazz rock opus after another you're just not going to get that the rest of the tracks on here have spots that are clearly planned out - just like peaches especially the song son of mr. Greenjeans which is almost the cousin to peaches but most of the remaining songs on here are much longer because they're they're stretched out with solos and improv and that's great for jazz fans and people who love jazz fusion and guitar heroism but maybe not for people who love their songs short sweet simple to the point still I like all the songs following the opener on this thing and the grittiest of all of them comes right after the opener Willie the pimp which features the gravel-voiced Captain Beefheart a predecessor to Tom Waits and he is not shy on this track at all sort of lyrically painting this image of a pimp and shouting and shrieking all over this track like he's really causing a ruckus and just the the groove and the solos just the jam of this track just feels so loaded down and and dirty this track is about as filthy as a whorehouse mattress I would say and there's this really sleazy fiddle playing all over this song which really brings that attitude home things head back in the direction of refinement on the song the son of mr. Greenjeans which like I said is heavily layered and orchestrated just like peaches and regalia but on this song things really get stretched out with a lot of strong soloing and Zappa's playing is just so great on this track I can't help but eat up every note he was just such a great player the guitar was almost an extension of him you can really kind of dive into what he's playing and think about it and see that it's thoughtful but it's so fast and fluid it's almost as if it had no planning or forethought whatsoever following that song is little umbrellas which because of its lack of just blaring guitar solos is almost just a legit jazz song simply jazz not jazz rock almost a jazz song because this track is mostly made of composed moments my one real annoyance with this album is that I feel like little umbrellas could have been so much longer if it had been jammed out this song really isn't as stretched out as it could be and I think it's worth stretching out because the feeling of this track is so much different than the other songs it's more chilled out it kind of lurches forward and it's really kind of sad and mysterious way I'd say it's a lovable monstrous but the lack of strong soloing on that song is made up for on the next track here that song is gumbo variations where Ian Underwood whips out his most fiery performance yet on this album his sax screams for mercy on this song this thing is a 17 minute long combo of jazz funk and rock all the composing and all the planning sort of gets thrown to the curb as saxophone violin and guitar just placed so hard that even I get sweaty the closer it must be a camel kind of sends things off on a really weird note saxophones and drums kind of hit these syncopated angular jagged melodies it's twice the monstrosity of little umbrellas and has a lot more beef to it as well I would just like to say I love the hell out of this album and hot rats is just a standout moment in not just the Zappa discography but in jazz fusion and jazz rock in general I wouldn't say other albums in this style are inferior definitely not but this is one of the only albums that I know that combines jazz and rock with these really colorfully eccentric compositions so if you really value a strong personality unique melody writing jazz this may become a classic for you just as it is for me this thing is definitely one of my favorites and probably will be for the foreseeable future and now Cal Church esta hey everybody Cal Church St here Frank zapper cooking up at DAGs in just 30 seconds flat what delish however I am not much for hot rats or cold rats I don't really care what the temperature is only good rats dead rat all right but in summation whatever Anthony was saying you should listen to over there you should loads and lots of reverb and atmosphere for added dramatic effect but these are just kind of ideas that fit that post-rock blueprint that go into this album there is so much more going on with this LP than just that there's plenty of ambient music on here noise noise rock spoken-word fueled recordings and found sounds and samples and there's just this really strong Punk fury on this album - in just how urgent and aggressive and just socially and politically conscious this album can be as well as restless and there's a really strong element of classical music on here too but you should not go into this record expecting like a symphonic rock record that's definitely not where this is coming from I see classical because of of course the pianos and the strings and the horns that show up on this album but all all these extra sounds just come together in these highly highly detailed layers and these layers do add up to something that sounds a lot like a pit orchestra but at the end of the day this thing is still a rock album now lift your skinny fists it's a highly highly praised album there's no doubt about that but I would not call it an accessible album or an easy to listen to album by any means even if you are kind of going into it expecting good things unless you already know you love drone you love ambient music and sound scapes you know you love noises and you actually have the time to sit down and listen to this thing all the way through don't expect to be pleased as punch with this album the first go-around I could definitely understand this LP getting criticized as being maybe long-winded kind of pretentious maybe a little depressing too but honestly that doesn't change the fact that I love this thing and it's not like it's the most indulgent thing in the world it's not like listening to Trout mask replica alright so what's actually on here song wise if you take a listen to this thing it's going to kind of be like partaking in an auditory experiment where all the musicians involved try to use sound to paint an accurate picture of the beginning and the end of the world these songs feature really exciting highs and and tear-jerking interludes and really kind of dark angry sad sad sad lows thankfully it starts off on a positive note with the title track or sort of title movement which I have been able to kind of follow along with on this map of the album that comes with the album itself although it is not that accurate of a map being that some songs and movements end before or after they actually say they do over here that's whatever because this first six minutes or so of this LP is some of the most breathtaking beautiful and amazingly layered rock music to ever fall under the genre of post rock just tons of strings shimmering guitars swelling horns these really marching drums and all these instruments just escalate and escalate and escalate layering and building is really where these guys have a fine-tuned strength that is often imitated but not often recreated these guys really value and understand tension as if they're related to it or something the builds on this thing are pretty slow don't expect them to go anywhere fast I mean these songs do go past 20 minutes sometimes but in my opinion God speed really knows how to keep the quieter sides of their builds pretty listenable and engaging with interesting sounds lots of dynamic playing but when it comes to the louder sides of these builds god speed really knows how to prove how cohesive of a group they are and how just detail-oriented these songs are because they're always just getting louder and more intense just as you think these guys have reached the final apex of a build they managed to figure out a way to just get a shade darker or a shade brighter the size of the sounds that God's bee plays with over the course of a build evolve of course but also sometimes the phrases of the strings or just the horn arrangements or the guitar leads will change over the course of a build as well upwards or downwards which is also really nice because it adds to the evolution of the song you're not hearing this one single phrase performed in the one single way you did at the beginning of the song at the end of the song which is awesome because some groups will kinda slouch when it comes to adding extra instruments into their songs because it's an extra instrument it's just kind of there to add another color another texture the strings the pianos and the horns as well there's some glockenspiel on this LP to all those play really pivotal roles on this album from movement to movement to movement kind of a different instrument a different sound takes the spotlight which brings lift your skinny fists some awesome variety as soon as God speed reaches a lot of the tops the tip tip tops of these builds that I've been talking about some times and in its little formulaic they will kind of cut its throat and just let it die really quickly and kind of transition or segue into something different but you know to their credit they always transition into something interesting or just seems like really fluid on this LP like this first movement that I've been talking about as soon as it reaches it and just explodes wildly and these kind of wailing strings are left over in the background it kind of explodes like a firework and the strings left over screaming or kind of like the fading and flickering smithereens left in the air as it falls to the earth those strings kind of develop into a drone and then this guitar very delicately played introduces itself playing the melody to what seems like Amazing Grace it's almost a cover of Amazing Grace actually which eventually builds itself up to be one of the most heavy and riveting versions of the song I've ever heard all of a sudden Godspeed just kind of breaks away with these dissing strings kind of interrupting that song and they just take a turn for something much darker which makes this album feel even more like a movie for me it's like something in the storyline had just changed like a villain had just been introduced a villain something evil something bad because this part of the song sounds like fists clenching and teeth gnashing and bricks going through storefront windows after that track slows down the album goes into a pretty hefty series of ambient interval and soundscapes and and collage music and every moment just feels really kind of vast and eerie and haunting and just just like endless in terms of just its reach its largeness these guys make quiet music that just seems as huge as when they're being loud it's really something that the Tim Hecker fan in me totally gets off on in this series of ambient interludes the most striking moment for me is when this low voice pitch shifted woman's voice start speaking and it seems like she is giving a sermon the woman is talking about God and like I said her voice is kind of slowed down for this weird effect they're weeping strings in there and she's talking about dying and seeing God seeing God in some kind of vision and going insane the woman seems to be really passionate and really kind of sure about what she's saying toward the end of this clip that God speed plays she even goes as far as to say she knows things she can say things she has words that that aren't even in your Bibles yet but the thing is even though this woman seems kind of excited about the stuff she's saying the way God speed has altered her voice and the music they're playing against what she's saying makes it seem very kind of dark and twisted and disturbing to that one part of the album is something that I just cannot get out of my head the way those strings sound the way that woman's voice sounds it's all very unsettling for me following that movement the band pulls out another kind of slow building rock tune that to me is is one of the most twisted moments on the album the guitars on this one really wail the strings kind of circle around what the guitars are playing in a very repetitive way to kind of make this spiraling effect and this little tiny baby glockenspiel is just swallowed in the insanity there's a lot of material that comes after this track including one of the band's most popular songs which starts off with little monologue a little snippet from a conversation with a New Yorker talking about Coney Island how it was the playground of the world how people used to sleep on the beach there and now things have changed even though this is a great track I think pretty much all the material on this album is great it would be impossible for me to go over every single song moment segue transition interlude all of it plus I feel like in a way I'd be spoiling the album a little bit because like I said this is one of the most movie-like experiences I've ever had with an album there are different movements and climaxes on here each one of them brings a different set of ideas and emotions to me this album to me is equal parts uplifting and unsettling there are plenty of beautiful moments here but there are also spots on here that are as forlorn as a funeral march except this album has been created with with such a far-reaching ambition it's almost like Godspeed you black Emperor is trying to play off the entire planet like goodbye earth you had a good run now you're burnt to a crisp because of the military-industrial complex people are dead buildings are rubble streets are cracked the skies are black that's basically the attitude you'll be running into a little bit with this album not really an attitude I'm sure a lot of you subscribe to I don't subscribe to it I don't think the world is that terrible of a place and maybe God speed doesn't either if the world were that bad why make music for it but I personally don't have a problem with staring at the world's flaws and listening to music inspired by them to put it simply lift your skinny fists is an album loaded with qualities that I look for in music lots of ambition great recording and sound memorable textures melodies and songs some experimentation on here as well lots of variety in terms of ideas and in different genres of music great playing and proof Gorman's from these guys which really enhances the more ferocious moments on here and the more fragile ones to interesting use of samples and sounds and and voices to strong themes and concept and an interesting use of samples and and voices and as kind of an added bonus it's all kind of tied together into these really cohesive orchestral movements that that segue into each other really well using drones and ambient soundscapes and interludes there is definitely a formula going on here even if it isn't completely apparent because there is so much material to take in on this album but still there are enough variations on this style that godspeed has with this record that I'm never really bored I never really fed up I'm never really tired of what's going on here this album is just like a roller coaster for me it brings up so many emotions within me I know there are a lot of records out there where people will kind of attach them to certain points in their life like oh I listen to this record and then in the summer of Oh a I mean I know I do that personally but this record despite how long I've been listening to this thing for years and years and years I've never really done that all that happens when I listen to this record is I just kind of see imagery in my head of just Apocalypse and just like righteousness and skylines and war and people and nature and it seems as I listen to this album more over the years that imagery just gets stronger and stronger and stronger in my head not only do I find this album to be incredibly beautiful but a really unique experience to me and enlightening experience personally anyway and that's pretty much my take on this thing Cal Church esta everybody couch your chest to hear to say the great gets for you black in Peru great band you should listen hope you had a good allottee pray

songs don't don't stick enough with me maybe what I do know is that the songs from his most recent LPS have been kind of hit or miss for me I guess like on catacombs which came out a few years ago for example there are songs on that album like dreams come true girl that I love to death that are just so cute and and and catchy and just just really lovable and then you know the album will kind of turn around and make a weird production decision or just kind of throw out a song that's that's a little underwhelming a lot like lion killer gets married which just has this really kind of flat totally Undine amick repetitive beat behind it that really kind of makes the song feel longer than it actually is and I kind of felt the same way about wit's end to one song on that album County line one of the most emotionally captivating songs I've heard this year is just kind of followed by these tracks that I don't really care for like lonely dull which to me is just really underwhelming it's just really kind of too soft too sweet to really keep my interest there's just no bite to it but still eautiful Liyana cast mccombs album i find that there are a handful of tracks that are so good it keeps me interested in checking out the next album just in case one song after another is is kind of blowing me away so I did kind of go into humor risk looking for that and even though this isn't one of a harder rock edge to them tracks like the opener and mr. email and the same thing all have these really driving rock grooves that make me think that Cass McCombs has been listening to like the first modern loo lovers record a bunch of times just guitar bass drums just gliding along this single beat really nicely stopping occasionally for a pretty hook like on the same thing and what's cool about these more repetitive songs is that it really kind of gives cast the opportunity to stretch out lyrically like on the track mr. email which has a pretty dark tale behind it once you really start getting into the lyrics that involves just the law in jail and getting stabbed that track drags on a little bit but it's it's still pretty good and the opener love thine enemy has a lyrical punch as [Music] Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for another question comment thing one of the one of the one of the little questions that I get most often on my videos in my channel comments tweets Facebook comments and messages emails is how many times do you listen to an album before you review it before and the answer that I keep giving because this answer is the truth is it depends there is no set number there could never be a set number music doesn't work that way for example let's say the antlers Kanye West Animal Collective Godspeed you black Emperor and Neutral Milk Hotel we're going to come out with a collaborative album next year well whether or not you review this album well and understand everything it has to offer has a lot to do with how familiar you are with the musical styles of these artists how familiar you are with the musical ideas that they're presenting on this project and how many times you've been able to listen to this project and basically dive into it and understand what musically it has to offer somebody who is a black metal aficionado should be able to listen to a black metal album and decide whether or not he or she likes it and give better reasoning for that than somebody who is completely just unfamiliar with black metal and has no clue what it offers or what the point is or what kind of sounds they can expect even if you don't like black metal and you don't like the album that you're listening to at least making the effort to understand why you don't like it beyond just being closed-minded is what is going to come out with a review that's worth reading or watching so if you are really really familiar with black metal maybe it'll take three to five or maybe even six times to listen to an album and side whether or not you like it and figure out exactly why and if you're not familiar with black metal to get these same answers maybe you'll need to listen to the album ten times and not only that album but a bunch of other albums that led up to that album in the band's discography or in the style in general so when someone asks me how many times I listen to an album I don't really have a number answer number one because there is no set number and number two I don't really count III basically decide to review something when I've reached a I guess kind of emotional consensus with this is how I feel about this album and I have all of these reasons why once I have a clear grip on the feeling and I have that list of reasons as to why that feeling is there then I'm ready ready to do the review so so because this question keeps coming up I'm curious do you have a certain number of times you listen to an album before you decide whether or not you like it is there a set standard of times you should listen to an album before you decide whether or not you think it's listenable be people what you guys think I love you Anthony Fantana listening to things a certain amount of times forever [Music] you you

Wow hi everybody Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review this band is named cormorant and this album is titled dwellings these guys are a California metal band this is their sophomore LP it's self released and this LP is definitely a nice little surprise gem that landed at the end of this year because these guys have a lot that's worth admiring they're really heavy they're really melodic their songs are very detail-oriented not to mention these guys are really dynamic and how they build their songs - there's so much to say about this record I don't even know where to start because as I listen through this album every time I thought I had cormorant kind of figured out they pull another surprise out of their sleeve another influence another emotion another trick so I figure I'll just kind of start with the the sound of this album which is really great the production on this thing is is killer whether whether the band is just shooting for these mountainous highs or these really kind of dramatic and quiet moons all the sounds are just really pristine and the recording just has this really nice mix of of clarity but also like grit - the guitars come in really heavy the vocals come in really raspy and it all just sounds so live but not that a low five recording is is bad but I think being able to make out the bass lines being able to take in the detail of the guitar solos being able to hear intelligible vocals that have a really strong narrative all those things just make me appreciate this album even more the band covers a lot of different sounds and and textures on this album they're really booming heavy guitar chords that worry now in a really do me way on the second track harmonized guitars Lausanne unearthly dreamings there's an instrumental track as well with these really kind of oddly time progressive riffs and shots of black metal blast beats here and there too these guys really work to blend a lot of genres together and that to me is kind of what their style is black metal do metal progressive metal death metal as well on here and it's all fed through this great production and this really melodic sensibility there's spots on here that made me think of Mastodon and then these guys would push into a different direction and then I think of like angle lock and then they would push into a different direction and I think of like Oh paths this is the sounds that influence cormorant on this record are pretty obvious but how they pull them all together it's just really graceful and that's what kind of makes this record unique to me like the opening chords on a howling lust which are which are really kind of pretty and a little funky in a way build into these really pummeling riffs nicely the purest land has these interjecting black metal moments that that bring the insanity of that track even higher and I love how there are spots on these tracks that kind of transition into these very kind of post rocky and vocal samples where you'll you'll get this big long vocal snippet that will kind of push the narrative of the song forward and that's really kind of the last thing on this record that to me makes it a pretty bold release the narratives the tales that are being spun into these songs some of the lyrics on here you can follow from the beginning to the end of a song and really get a lot out of it if you're listening hard enough it's almost like these guys are composing stories as well as songs and sometimes it's almost like the lead singer is playing a character in this story that he's pulling together and a lot of these stories reflect real life and every song has a different tale behind it the song the purest land sort of seems to be about this this genocide o madman who's just like out of control and just like is is kind of a megalomaniac the vocals on that track just feel noticeably crazy than the other songs the second track on here is actually about highwire artist Philippe Petit and their lyrics on here about the wire and flying and some of the lyrics are actually in French too the song Hunta lyrically is one of the most specific up in and kills a Chinese man for defending himself against someone who was trying to hurt him all the stories on this album deal with with death facing death injustice and the darkness of humanity hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review this LP from the Polish composer hola Mitchell Mitchell Jackie sik great guy yes that's his name hey got your chest I'm going to in this review make the argument to you that this album is the perfect little instrumental tidbit for your winter on glimmer michael is effectively composing classical music with various sounds and styles musical elements flowing throughout it Noise music ambient music electronic music Baroque but it's not just sounds and styles that vary on the cell P it's an album of many moods - this is very emotionally heavy LP very emotionally heavy instrumentals one after another that range from being very kind of eerie and cold to dark and sinister but no matter what kind of feeling a track gives off there's always this real strong sense of beauty in the sounds and the melodies and I feel like glimmer brings about this beauty by going in essentially two different directions with these tracks there are moments on here like the opening track that feel like a slightly more traditional take on classical music the electronic elements the experimental edits and textures that hang in glimmers music aren't as strong bold apparent on the surface the first track on this LP sounds like a beautifully played Celeste being accompanied by strings that kind of get lost in this wall of harpsichord arpeggios it's very chilling and kind of reminds me of something that that could possibly be played to open up the the credits of a Tim Burton movie something like that I'm more into the moments where glimmers classical side meshes a bit more with its experimental side like on the second track dare Gale where the sounds just feel murkier they feel more obscured there they're darker they're weirder there are all these stuttering edits here and there and just the the gritty quality of the atmosphere reminds me of of guys like Tim Hecker or bands like Godspeed you black Emperor I get the same feeling from the fourth track too but there's there's some harsh swells of noise on that track to kind of swallow up the woodwinds they've evidence that our droning away behind it these dark noisy sound escapes with all this classical instrumentation that's what adds up to a real showstopper for me on this album the moments where the classical sounds and in compositions kind of take the forefront on this LP and not that they're bad they just don't feel as distinct to me I just felt like there were too many spots where some of the songs here felt a little uneventful because they merely coast on these harpsichord arpeggios and just kind of let the song progress on on that and it just doesn't feel as it's thrilling thankfully that sound and style makes up just a small part of this LP a majority of this thing is spent experimenting I love the creepy and light drone that hangs in the air behind the woodwinds on what wind walks up above that's a track title there are some very subtle edits and sounds and effects happening throughout the song too and that's what I like so much about this LP it is so soft and quiet and yet so detailed and just very very hidden details you can really just dive into the intricacies of this album and just just take in so much just eat them all up later on that same track there are all these bouncing echoes of acoustic guitar just just ricocheting off every wall in the room and man the whole track just ends in this very thick heavy crescendo involving these woodwinds and this harpsichord and and whatever various noises glimmr can string together it's a pretty powerful moment and the last track on here is a powerful moment as well but not because of its volume or arts or its massive instrumentation but because of just how finely tuned the melodies seem on that track there are some really beautiful lead melodies played by woodwind on that song and some faint trumpet swells toward the end of the song - it's it's really really great I know simple description but seriously that final track describing every detail in that song that's a whole nother video in itself but overall when I listen to this album I just I just see all this imagery of of just snow falling and like you know old decrepit twisted trees and I get kind of like a a weird kind of scary story kind of aesthetic coming for out of this - but not like a you know a modern weird freaky gory scary story kind of like you know a headless horseman kind of old-school scary story now glimmer is a good pretty solid album I didn't hate not one song on here but was I amazed throughout the entire LP totally in love with every track no to be honest I would have liked maybe a few more tricks up this album's sleeve a little more experimentation a little more variation - I felt like this album was a little too close in comparison with its influences here and there a few tracks kind of felt a little short to me like they could have been developed a bit more and a few moments on here kind of redo ideas that I think we're done better on tracks that had come before I know I'm being a little nitpicky but this is still a really hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd time for an album review the Black Keys El Camino these beasts these guys are a rock duo that I've been following ever since this blues rock and garage rock revival got kind of huge in the in the early to mid 2000s I reviewed their album brothers last year but I got to be completely honest and say I was not all that excited to hear El Camino in all the years I've been listening to the Black Keys especially releases like like thickfreakness and rubber factory and an amazing EP that they have released of nothing but but junior Kimbrough songs the duo has never really thrown me a left hook or a surprise and this is kind of a complaint I had with the band's last album I think it's an even bigger complaint for me with this album I think the Black Keys are long overdue for a direction change you know but there is a silver lining in that cloud and it is that the Black Keys are a picture of consistency every time they drop an album it's got pretty much the sound you would expect and it always gets the same semi glowing or glowing reviews there are some detractors here and there but not so many that they would be a big deal and as long as the Black Keys stick to the style and the ideas and and the sounds and the songwriting that has worked for them up until this point who's really gonna complain not to say there's been no change whatsoever in this band's career earlier releases were much simpler much more skeletal much more raw and that changed after the band worked with Danger Mouse on the album attack and release but to be honest it's it's maybe my least favorite Keys album and ever since then I feel like their songs have just kind of been getting simpler and more straightforward I just think the kind of romantic interplay that you would get between the guitar and drums on an album like magic potion has has kind of faded away a bit in exchange for writing songs that are popular hooky er more instant and because of that I feel like Black Keys new stuff contains less subtleties secrets on El Camino you basically kind of get this same flavor of of modernized but also nostalgic garage and blues rock the hooks in roughly the same way the guitars feature an array of different tones and effects the drums really forced some nice grooves the lyrical subjects revolve around girls and heartbreak and relationships as usual with a few kind of stragglers varying from that formula lots of warm bass lines fuzzy distorted pentatonic guitar solos a little extra piano and organ and background vocals here and there call me death but I feel like the Black Keys are working with roughly the same ideas as they were on brothers with a few spots here and there that kind of stick out like the first single lonely boy which to me feels like a newer take on the raw sound the Black Keys used to play with all the time the track little black submarine starts off as a really nice acoustic ballad and actually kind of sounds like a track maybe the White Stripes could have written on the album white blood cells sister has one of the hardest and catchiest grooves that these guys have have ever produced and Nova baby is is a is a notably sunnier song than a lot of the tracks on here but the rest of the tracks on here for me don't really feel new I get tired of ideas when they feel kind of overused I guess and when those ideas get overused is is really kind of a personal preference you know obviously in my opinion of this record is heavily impacted by just my musical preferences and how much music from these guys I have heard if you're relatively new to the Black Keys maybe brothers for example was was your first introduction to them you're probably going to enjoy this and if this is your first Black Keys album try it out it's really not that bad it's pretty solid there's not really any pop holes or anything but that's because the Black Keys don't really take that many risks outside of what has already worked for them in the past in my opinion it's consistent it's fast it's easy it's kind of catchy but I know personally I'm not gonna remember most of these songs come next month my only major complaint is that I feel like some of the hooks on here lyrically can get a little corny like hey nah nah she's a moneymaker hey nah nah she's gonna take you but outside of that the production on this thing is pretty good the guitars and the drums and the extra instrumentation the bass the warm bass all of it sounds really nice feeling a strong 5 to a lay six on this hmm but what do you think of it do you love it do you hate it do you love the Black Keys because of how consistent they are if you are a fan and you have been a fan from from the early days up until this point let me know Anthony Fantan out the Black Keys [Music]

tunes with pretty instrumentation and others are pretty low fly have a really distorted raunchy sound and are basically garage rock the band's recent releases are sort of showing a very tuneful side of comic gain but they're still sort of maintaining this this kind of messy edgy old-school indie rock sound as they do it all the tunes on here are packed with trebly guitars acoustic guitars really simple straightforward drumming fuzzy bass lines and boy girl vocals that sort of intertwine with one another nicely on some tracks and sort of switch off singing lead vocal with other tracks and what a tricks point never rappelled yeah hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album view OneNote Rick's point never replicas but I'm just going to refer to the project as OPN from now on because that's easier replica is the latest album to come out of this project spearheaded by producer Daniel low patent past records have contained a lot of ambient interludes and sound scapes and and the kind of synthesizer worship that could probably get any tangerine dream fan all excited and this new album definitely marks a change for Daniel he is still sticking to his roots in abstract music in ambient music and sound scapes but the tools that he's using now are different there's piano on here and synths on here a little noise and tons of effects various reverbs and such but the surprise guest on this album is samples sampling sampler San San San San temple dimple dimple dimple chicka chicka chicka chicka Tara replica is an album that is heavily indebted to the art of sampling and it really changes opions compositional style instead of dealing with individual notes or drones or cords or something like that OPN is now building tracks with blocks of sound slivers of looped sounds but still manages to maintain this soothing and mostly ambient and thought-provoking approach and I think because of this this creative an interesting mix of of synthesizer worship and ambient music and sampling this album kind of ends up pushing boundaries in the art of sampling music and maybe inadvertently because when OPN was putting this album together I don't think he was thinking of artists such as as Stein ski or the Dust Brothers or DJ shadow or avalanches or the books or Matt mousse or Girl Talk or any number of other plunder phonics or collage music artists but with all these sound clips that that from what I understand come from television ads replicas ends up being an album that that stands out pretty boldly whether you measure it up against ambient albums or plunder phonics collage music albums genres aside there are 10 tracks on this album that are very beautiful haunting and perplexing and it all starts with a very airy drone just kind of hanging suspended in the atmosphere it's very mind-altering for me and not too unlike what OPN usually does there all sorts of wandering and very gorgeous synthesized tones floating throughout the track and as the song progresses these very quiet quiet loops and just samples start popping up just adding more texture and Drive and tempo to it's like these ghosts noises start haunting the soundscape and it really kind of puts me in another place sonically now the second track is where the samples really kick in and originally it was my least favorite track on the album and now it's one of my favorites the way the the loops have been chopped on this particular track on a lot of tracks on this LP felt really obnoxious and maybe sort of lazy to me at first but once I was able to kind of hear past the fact that I'm listening to loops I was getting into the tempo and I was hearing the detail that is loaded into this song in particular behind the sampling because as the track progresses I'm hearing a lot of sounds that that to me are a little difficult to describe because I don't completely understand or know what they are I'm hearing some flutes I think and various effects bouncing off of one another lots of different synth textures it's a very intriguing track the track child soldier is really choppy as well but it throws even more detail into the mix with this manipulated chopped and looped singing all of these synthesizers some of them kind of airy and light some of them very noisy and just squawking it's like all this chaos set against this very sharp rhythm an eerie singing loops it's kind of like hearing this beautiful thing it built up and then smashed into a thousand pieces there are more tracks on here though like the first track where Opie ends more ambient side intertwines with these samples like tracks such as explain or remember but I think it all comes together best on the song power of persuasion all these really shuffling piano loops repeat over and over and over and it creates a really kind of tense and eerie and pretty atmosphere and it all kind of gives me this mix of different emotions that that feels weird but you know kind of keeps me on the edge of my seat and the sense swelling up underneath these piano loops to me kind of feel like like trumpets and tubas Calicut it just swells like a horn section really beautifully really delicately the song really grows into a sonic Odyssey as the as the since become more prominent and the reverb really gets turned up the title track is a lot like that too but the noisier samples really aren't as prevalent because piano is what's stealing the show here and these very somber chords are just kind of getting cocooned by synthesizers as the track progresses very slowly lots of fluttering synths and buzzing synths plus all these various noises that to me come off as is very imaginative overall this album to me feels like a little bit of a mixed bag you've got tracks that feel like they're they're nothing but samples and then you've got moments that that feel like there are no samples at all is just kind of like a synth drone and while stylistically you do get kind of a range of ideas on this album I feel like emotion all these ideas end up coming from roughly the same place which at the end of the day kind of makes this album feel pretty cohesive to me me me now there are a few negatives a couple a couple negatives for me for one close inspection reveals that working with samples can be really fun exciting and kind of invigorating as far as finding new sounds when you're trying to compose a song based on samples lots of questions can come up like how do I introduce this new sound how do I swap this sound out for another sound while you know not really losing the pace or the feel of the song how do I develop this how do I change this other thing samples sometimes are really not all that malleable because of that there are moments on this LP that kind of lazily rely on fade-ins and fade-outs because introducing a sample or getting rid of a sample it doesn't really seem like there's a better way to do it and there are some spots on here where some ideas and sometimes entire songs just kind of end and just bite the dust because it sort of seems like they've hit the dead end the track remember feels like that to me in the song up which has a really great introduction and a really great end just has kind of like these two different parts at the end it's starting its finish but these two sections just like crossfade really sloppily into one another at the midpoint of the song which really kind of kills the flavor of it tracks like these to me just don't showcase the same amount of detail and grace that a lot of tracks on here do but outside of that I am loving the experience that I had with this LP it did take a while for me to really kind of get into this thing though I had to listen to it I was kind of on the fence with it I revisited it I was on the fence with it I revisited it I was on the fence with it I revisited it and then I was thinking oh hey this is pretty awesome I'm kind of feeling a light too decent eight on this thing but what do you give it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next Anthony fan 10010 tricks point never Kessler percussionist but those two terms don't quite sum up what these guys do on this album what we essentially have on this debut record from Red Horse is a free improvisational noise album that just is one intense track after another now I've enjoyed music like this in the past for sure but I don't often review it usually because a lot of these records kind of come and go for me just sort of pass by but this one admittedly did stop me in my tracks on first listen at least we really do enjoy the harshness and the tension that noise music can bring but I think with this new age of technology a lot of the performance element of noise has sort of dwindled a bit because performing has essentially become you know flipping switches and twisting knobs and pressing buttons on laptops which isn't a terrible thing but I do love hearing strong musicianship and that's what you definitely get on this record though this record is noisy it is all over the place it's it's sort of boundary-less and a lot of respects how these two perform on this record really kind of had me an off for at least a third of the album the entire LP is about 45 minutes long it's five tracks none of which have you know real intense titles or anything it's just part one through five and the album starts off with just a really attention-grabbing metallic drone that just feels like I'm sitting in the middle of a thousand bull roles going on all around me in a really panoramic way and it's just one of the most ear piercing and shrill sounds I've ever heard on a record if you do listen to this watch your volume there definitely is kind of a masochistic pain element going through this first track and the way the drone shifts which is difficult to kind of take in it's really subtle and and really actually kind of intriguing but things really take off on the second track of this album so to say it doesn't take off in a you know kind of a pumped up you know let's let's just go kind of way it's more like it takes off in that Steve and Eli really start making some noise on here with various pieces of percussion and I think I think I'm hearing some electric piano some guitar some bass everything that creates a tone is just playing very sour notes just popping or swelling up all over the track as the percussion it kind of sounds like I'm listening to Zak he'll play from hella except he's not playing on a drum set he's playing on a snare and then basically anything in everything that he could bang a drum stick on that he found in a junkyard it also kind of sounds like a hundred cuckoo clocks are ticking and talking in the room where these guys are performing this track they're there they're there are these really Basie rumbles underneath everything and the percussion starts whipping out these sounds that that kind of sound like a helicopter is going by it's kind of insane and it's not like the drums and the percussion are abusive just really heavy just really relentless or anything like that it's kind of like just they're there they're busy they're really busy listening to the second track on here is kind of like listening to the inner workings of an old busted machine I feel like I'm in the middle of a machine and I'm seeing gears turning and and pipes are steaming and things are rusted and squeaking everything is shaking I just feel like I'm locked into I'm lost inside of this really metallic dark world and even though none of the sounds on this track really feel synthesized I still kind of sit here and wonder how they made half of the sounds on the song after the second track is where things on this LP kind of start to go downhill for me just a little bit the sounds on the third track don't really seem to bring anything that the second track didn't there's more guitar feedback on this and I feel like there's there's more space between one noise and another a little more breathing room but at the end of the day it just kind of sounds like two dudes making noise whereas the sound escapes on the previous two tracks were really imaginative and different part four on this LP gets busy once again just like the second track but it feels a bit darker almost in a lust more daeun kind of way lust more daeun but there are these huge metallic thuds just pounding as the percussion just wildly swirls it kind of sounds like a killer robot or an alien from another planet trying to break down an iron barrier to get past it and kill you and the second half of this track really kind of dies down and gets quiet and gets subtle with these with these really high-pitched metallic drones it kind of sounds like they're playing sound bowls or something however they're making these sounds they're they're really kind of tickling my brain a bit they're very interesting the last track unfortunately is where I really kind of got disappointed though this album does sort of seem to be a free improvisational noise piece done in five parts I was hoping they wouldn't go down the road that the fifth track did down this really stereotypical kind of noise chance peace road that reminds me of dozens and dozens of pieces that I've heard from from John Cage or John Zorn and you know both artists great fantastic pushed boundaries helped make experimental music what it is today I just feel like Red Horse is kind of toying around with this old hat idea of experimental music that we basically had this this quiet background this blank canvas and then we just start randomly creating unpredictable noises popping up in in every possible direction though when stuff like this is on it kind of you know keeps me sort of interested in that ooh what's the next noise going to be but ultimately it never ends up being that memorable or that shocking Red Horse has some really great musicianship on this album and I think they're onto some really interesting sounds and ideas my biggest issue with this record at the end of the day though I did find it pretty likeable is that it blows most of it's interesting and unique ideas right at the beginning of the album there inevitably will be the question of how do I enjoy music like this what are the standards what are the rules of thumb how exactly do I get something out of music like this you know music like this doesn't have limitations as to what it can be so there are really no limitations as to what you can like about it or what you could hate about it listening to an album like this is kind of like just sifting through a jungle and just looking for I don't know the missing link whatever
