hello boy hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the internet visual logic nerd and it's time for an album review the spits the spits but before we do this review first order of business this is our old font that we use I'm now going to use this font why because I want to how long will I keep using it until I feel like using another font ma the spits are a modern punk band whose spit in the face of the assumption that all modern punk rock is clean primped and created pretty much just for radio play they've been doing that for well well well over 10 years now and have several EPS and several LPS and and some splits and singles to show for it this self-titled LP is their latest and while I didn't think it was their strongest release it's definitely a fun listen and furthers the grimy style that they've been peddling on pretty much every one of their releases now I started off right with these guys years ago by listening to their self-titled LP first their self-titled debut LP first they have a lot of self-titled releases if I'm correct this is actually the fifth thing that they've released that is titled the Spitz but still for me this first LP is the catchiest thing and the most accessible thing that these guys have released so far with tracks like skate and die die die and black car this album is just a really distorted mid-paced punk rock album that is both mind-numbing ly simple but also kind of hilarious at the same time and this album is no different though if there is one noticeable change on here the spits on this release continue playing with the keyboards and and weird sounds and noises and vocal effects and drum machines that would pop up here and there on previous releases so as the spits kind of continued to play with their old sound but also kind of toy with these new electronics and this continuously fuzzy and distorted and grimy aesthetic this album has kind of ended up being a mixture of older and newer sounds for these guys there are some really straightforward guitar and vocal tracks on here that are kind of in the spins usual style like the opener all I want which is a very fun bouncy love song it's got really silly lyrics but it sticks in my head and I love love the low toned deep distortion on that track and the wailing guitar in the background it's killer it's just got this nice fuzzy grimy feel to it that I can really sink my teeth into the way these guys play the the guitar tones the drumming and just the recording quality just reminds me of like a combination of the Ramones and wire but like a little more low Phi and speaking of the Ramones I know they've always had an influence on the music these guys play but this is the first time I would say I heard a Spitz album where maybe I heard a little bit more Ramones worship than I usually do on tracks like brick by brick and my life sucks the guitar tone the vocal delivery the chords that the spits are using just all of it just bleeds Ramones the only thing that I think sets the spitz apart is that they're a little dirtier they're a little more atonal and their songs are definitely shorter and shorter keeping in line with other Spitz releases every song on here is short as hell in fact this whole release is short as hell it's 12 tracks and they clock in at just over 18 minutes so even if you hate this thing it will not be taking up too much room over your life so anyway the tracks on here the sound like the spits usual stuff some of them are good some of them are okay just nothing amazing nothing new but the songs that really kind of caught my ear on here were the ones like tomorrow's children that track is like an electronic piece of drum machine punk that would have caught a pretty penny on eBay if it had been released in 1979 and was pressed on like a hundred seven inches or something it's got these whaling keyboards in the background and just these these really throbbing driving drum machines and these really highly manipulated vocals that kind of make the the vocalist sound like a robot or an alien or something like that you know from a sci-fi movie it sounds like the spits but yeah it also kind of reminds me of bands like blank dogs you know just this bedroom rock project and the last track on this album at that single I mentioned did exist could have easily been the b-side but outside of those two tracks it's it's hard for me to pick moments on this album that I feel stick out in the spitz style it's hard for me to pick moments on here that really kind of stick out in this album because so much of it just kind of feels say me say me say me say me say me for me if the songs were longer I guess it would be a bigger problem but overall I just kind of admire the feel of this album it's filthy it's weird it's odd it's drooling all over itself in some kind of fierce rebellion against cleanliness and and sanity when it comes to punk music these guys are uniquely lethargic noisy mean nasty and ugly I really like the foundation that this album lies on but I'm not exactly in love with what the spits end up building on it I guess what I feel like the spits have built on this foundation with these songs is kind of like a disgusting roach-infested opium den it may be fun to watch from afar with binoculars but it's no place I'd want to visit without a gun or a drug habit and I get it that's probably intentional this album is more about the sound for me and that's cool the spits do make some interesting sonic choices on here like the blue P keyboards on the track electric brain and it sounds exactly like they're using a chain-link fence as percussion on song wanna be a DD the sounds are cool but I feel like the songs could have been written to be catchy er or more memorable really the spits don't really display themselves as good songwriters here and I felt like that that did come into play on their earlier releases because as I dug underneath the the grime of each song I found that some of the tunes oh boy hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you logos it's the name of this project logos there's not a lot of information to tell about this project all the websites I've found downloads on you know artists affiliated websites just kind of leave the cover art and a liner notes and just the download there and just not much else the production on this LP is handled by Ken Barrientos who has worked with other artists who I have respect for like blue and the law there are two kind of main vocalists on here Nico grey and Omar and Mari there's someone on here handling all the horns there's someone else handling all the strings and a good half a dozen or so guest musicians who range from guitar players to other vocalists this thing is just ten tracks and thirty minutes long and even though this thing is a short and free album I listen to this again and again and again I am like continually surprised at the amount of of just detail effort and quality that has gone into this mini album now what you ultimately get on this logo's album is an electronic futuristic and psychedelic brand of neo soul aided with lots of pianos and horns and strings and the style here is just so fresh sounding it just sounds so new it's the point where it's difficult for me to compare this to anything older really I mean there is kind of a chill vibe going on here with some heavy beats and very smooth relaxing beautiful vocals which which kind of reminds me of of downtempo artists like massive attack but I wouldn't be surprised if these guys spend more time listening to their contemporaries than older stuff there are tons of bee here loaded with odd distorted just bent every which way textures flying and whizzing by in every direction imaginable which reminds me a lot of Flying Lotus and there's also just this jazzy soulful smoothness to these songs to that remind me of of artists like Thundercat who put out that Spacey new-age jazz fusion album the Golden Age of Apocalypse earlier this year also that self-titled debut that subtract dropped to that Sol plus dubstep combination that that worked out really well logos does resemble some of those sounds those artists put out but more than them this project just takes me to higher planes of sonic ecstasy with all these layered vocals and space-age synthesizers it sounds so heavenly seductive sensual mmm I'm kind of pissed it's only 30 minutes long but in the 10 tracks that do make it onto this album there is a lot of variety and with some good highlights the second track which comes after a short intro what a great song to start this album off it just Oh hums it freakin pulsates it throbs with so much emotion it's noisy and it's odd but it's also really beautiful in the the harmonious sense that just kind of get layered into this thing the string arrangements that pop up later into the tune the female vocal that's so echoed is just bouncing off of every every other sound and the in the mix it just feels so relaxing and so classy and with the way the vocals stand out on the 3rd and the 7th track they definitely kind of feel like space soul to me just really poetic lyrics and and beautiful vocal melodies and all this instrumentation rising in the background in a really kind of overwhelming way it kind of felt like to me I was I was floating on my back on a really kind of still body of water under an eye sky like I said not a ton of material on here not a lot of background on this thing so not a whole ton to say other than that I think the music is great and it kind of speaks for itself the songs on this thing all progress it's loaded with creative melodies and textures that that were really mind for really mulled over and and fine-tuned these guys have a really definitive and and memorable style for me and this album really is heavily layered and and it's been growing on me with every listen more lessons reveal more details more sounds more everything more magic overall this LP is just really sending my years to another galaxy now as far as the negatives with this thing go I feel like this is kind of short it does have some tracks that I felt like could have been drawn out a bit more but still I didn't feel ripped off or anything like that and at this point I think logos is still just a little rough around the edges as a project as a collective obviously everyone involved in the group is an experienced musician but the end of this album doesn't exactly tie together all that fantastically and and there are a few tracks on here where I kind of questioned the mixing because I'm hearing the vocals get drowned in the cacophony of everything just a little bit especially on the ninth track where you've got these phaser synthesizers and this kind of like buzzing guitar phrase that gets chopped and looped if you're looking for an album that is free that is chill and when I say chill I mean ice relaxing and fantastically gorgeous and lush this is what you've got to listen to I'm feeling a decent eight on this but what do you think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana logos

Bekka hello my needle drops Anthony Fantino here the most tiredest music nerd but not too tired to review some fresh metal vector outer isolation this is the latest album from this Phoenix metal outfit the last time we heard from them is when they drop the album black future in 2009 it was exactly two years ago this month actually and that LP created quite a stir in the metal community just such an intense blend of thrash metal and black metal too with all these spacey themes working themselves into the little lyrics and all of that of course is backed up with loads of technical ability and innovation definitely not an easy album to follow up at a prime example that sometimes artists are more in competition with their own material than they are with other bands so I'm really happy to say that this album comes with some very noticeable changes but for the most part vector has written a series of tunes in their usual style without repeating themselves all that much surprisingly if anything this record just kind of continues to define vector style as a hyper melodic super dynamic intergalactic space thrash band now one of my few few issues of black futures that it could have used more variety and that definitely gets addressed on this album of course they're just intense riffs and and tempos on this record sometimes the the drum fills and the busy leads just kind of come together and hit speeds that would make me wonder if my record player were broken assuming I was playing this on vinyl but you know that's one of vectors calling cards to begin with what makes this LP sort of different to me that it is the increase of slower and more melodic passage on here the softer and slower spots on here definitely have more focus they have more purpose they're just not introducing things and allowing songs to have kind of a clean exit the softer spots are kind of starting to steal the show for me like the really droney atmospheric introduction to the title track that was a nice fresh sound for this band or the sudden loss and speed on the track Tetris structural Minds which man it's it's just so beautiful it's like everything just goes slow-motion after going the speed of light for for almost an eternity and it's like watching the Death Star blow up for the first time kind of beautiful destructive and poetic all at once that moment is just really stunningly beautiful to me along with others I love the the clean glistening arpeggios for me even the faster and more intense moments on this LP air coming off a little more melodic vectors always managed to work leads into their songs really well but I feel like they are layering a bit more this time around making things just really harmonious you know these little mean guitar phrases that pop up here and there the way that vector is now stacking them on top of each other it kind of reminds me of listening to video game musics just halfway into the title track on here I kind of feel like I'm listening to the theme song from Mega Man 2's air man level and some of the sinister and romantic court progressions on Venus Project have kind of a Castlevania vibe to them overall I just don't feel as pummeled or punished by this album I've got breathing room this time around and for some reason I'm not really catching the strong black metal influences and sounds that I heard on black future vectors always had much more going for them than a blend of of different styles they are unbelievably tight but also showcase a lot of finesse as they transition from one speed to another one volume and sonic texture to the next and on some of the tunes here they showcase some extremely impressive syncope which was one of the highlights for me from that new liturgy record Aesthetica now for anybody who is new to this band I will kind of warn you frontman David de Santo does have one of the most unique voices I've heard in metal bar none it's kind of like a black metal wretch but there's a much higher pitch to it in general and there's so much more rasp going on there in the throat the high-pitched banshee calls that we're all over black feature are in full throttle on this LP they really do pop up more and also efforts are made to change up vocal styles too with some narrations some lower growls some clean vocals here and there I was extremely impressed and satisfied with this record I wouldn't call this a disappointment not by a long shot I would say one of the major negatives to this LP though is that there are some moments on here that kind of sound a little too much like black future for their own good that's difficult to do when you're still mining for new songs from your old material our isolation actually uses tracks from the band's self-released CD that came out before black Future 3 to be exact which isn't anything completely new that since black Future did the same and the remakes are great those songs do finally get the production quality they need to really pack the punch they were intended to but I was hoping this band's inherent ambition would cause them to kind of make a greater leap forward with this record stylistically I guess still this record and the previous one are enough for me to to say to you that this band in my opinion is the most standout group in modern thrash metal sure obvious comparisons can be made to past greats like Voivod for example but what I love so much about vector is that they sound new they make thrash metal sound new to me all over again and with all the the science fiction themes the musicianship and clear differences between consistently good songs all of those things add up to for me one of the best metal releases of this year feeling a strong 8 to a light 9 on this album but what do you think of this record do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana vector our isolator you

Kate Bush 50 words for snow Oh buddy hi my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review Kate Bush 50 words for snow Kate Bush is a UK singer-songwriter who I needed to get acclimated with more than I already was for the purposes of this review full disclosure here I am not exactly a scholar when it comes to Kate Bush's body of work and even though this album was not clicking with me on my first and second listens I was up for the challenge of reviewing the Kate Bush album especially since her name gets thrown around with the art pop greats like Bjork Peter Gabriel Brian Eno and even though my first impressions were kind of lukewarm with this LP it didn't sound generic to me so I figured it was worth kind of sticking around and figuring out why I wasn't totally in love with it but now with hindsight now that I've heard it many more times I can understand why it wasn't clicking with me at first I can understand why it's it's not clicking with a lot of people and why it may not be for every Kate Bush fan and I think a lot of it has to do with just just with pacing this album is very slow Kate's knack for storytelling and her personality are still here but like I said they come on slowly the material on this LP I feel comes on even slower than what was on 2005 s Ariel really getting into this LP can be as time-consuming as just taking an ice cube pulling it out of the freezer throwing it on the counter and then just waiting for it to melt at room temperature ultra still it's it's no surprise that in the world of music there are records that jump out at you and others that you kind of need to dive into actively and this is definitely one of those instances now the instrumentation on this LP has been toned down a little bit I think to a really icy combination of vocals piano and strings of course there's upright bass on here and synthesizers and guitar drums as well and some guest vocalists but sometimes their appearances the roles that they play just are so subtle it's just not going to hit you on first listen no way but still even the first time around there's some very obvious musical posts that that make one track different from the other the opener features Kate Bush's son actually singing and and shockingly his voice is a lot like hers especially when he's reaching into those highs he just sings with this choirboy falsetto and delivers these these lyrics that are kind of penned from the narrative of a snowflake falling to earth and he just gives it so much innocence and like sincerity which proves he's as much a singer as he is an actor kind of like his mother the track misty has some really nice eruptions of strings in its center and it's in its finish line the track Wildman is easily the most accessible on here has a really obvious grooves and quirky synthesizers in there and the chorus just explodes with the youthfulness of Kate's early early work snowed in and wheeler Street is a duet about kind of two lovers who across time name-dropping very specific historical events are always kind of broken up their paths never quite meet up just run parallel to one another for all that long both vocalists on the tracker just so passionate and they're so sincere I really love that track it was one of the tracks that I loved the very first listen but you made it even more surprising that the vocalist guest vocalists on this track is actually Elton John the title track is a bit of spoken word with just this groove this sound an aesthetic that reminds me of a track or two from the new PJ Harvey album and on that song you pretty much get what the title says 50 words and phrases for snow doled out in a very dramatic manner by actor and author Stephen Fry so yeah this is a quiet album but certainly not uneventful overall I found the musical elements of this LP to be pretty nice pretty solid yeah this thing wanders it meanders it repeats phrases and ideas to draw them out in a in a really indulgent display but it's not like these songs are without their progression it's just not obvious progression you've really got to chew this album over to kind of pick up all the subtle flavors that are occurring behind the vocals and the piano now the other side of the coin here and this should be no surprise for Kate pence is the storytelling element of this album just how prevalent that is the track Lake Tahoe is about this ghost woman who's who's calling out to her dogs she left behind when when she died I'm gathering and the song misty oddly enough is about a kind of steamy and romantic one-night stand with a snowman literally a snowman and it's only one night because in the morning he's nowhere to be found the sheets are all soaked and they're twigs and leaves left behind the song wild man is kind of a in ode to the Yeti lyrically the only points on this LP that I kind of found underwhelming where I was really wanting more were on the title track definitely where it's pretty much just kate counting against these different words and phrases for snow and yeah I really like the sound of that track I love the instrumentation I love the feel of that song but the more cynical side of me says you know what this is kind of like a glorified version of 99 bottles of beer on the wall and the final tracks narrative isn't really all that strong either and just does not feel like it ties all the ideas of this album together in a way that I guess I'm happy with but that's just the lyrics musically the only song I wasn't really into on this thing was actually Lake Tahoe the track storyline gets kind of mangled and obscured with all these elongated vocal notes which isn't really an issue with a lot of the other songs on this LP plus the melodies on Lake Tahoe for me just don't feel as as purposeful don't hit as hard I guess nearly every other song here I kind of felt some kind of strong melodic theme going on but yet Lake Tahoe just kind of continues to elude me I'm really enjoying the concept I'm really enjoying the themes on this thing overall it's kind of like being trapped in this winter themed fantasy world created by Kate for about an hour or maybe rather lost because this thing in a way is is kind of like walking into a forest in the midst of a very heavy snow walking in too far and kind of losing your place because the snow is covering your tracks and now that I have more of a lay of the land I figured out where things are it's been a nice experience at every turn there's another metaphor for death or love or loss or age and not that I can't completely relate but I feel like I would appreciate this album so much more with a decade or two under my belt especially since there's a very kind of strong adult contemporary vibe radiating off of this thing I just enjoy personally the quirkier sounds of an album like The Dreaming more if that ever changes I know the album to go to is this thing long-winded is it indulgent yes it is so long-winded and indulgent but that's what kind of makes this thing stand out and even though yeah it's not as bold as a lot of Kate's albums it still ultimately ends up being kind of idiosyncratic just like her previous efforts are if you think this thing is boring I'm not going to tell you you're missing out on anything because this album just does not hold what you look for in music and that's all but if you're in the search for a very chilly atmosphere and songs that that kind of seep into your head very slowly then this is definitely one of the high points of this year kind of feeling a decent too strong seven on this thing but what do you think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana okay Bush fifty words for snow [Music] to you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busy music oh my needle drops I hope you're well it's time for an EP review the new cynic EP carbon-based Anatomy these guys are a Florida band they've been around for years or at least the musicians have because there was a period where they were kind of broken up and now they're back together the band released a second full-length LP in 2008 and ever since they've been kind of making this very slow trajectory away from their older sound but you know can you blame them I would rather they try something new and different than try to reclaim past glory from the 90s now we've got this new EP I've been listening to it at great length and I have to say I'm pretty pleased and impressed because there are elements on here that I think will pleased cynic fans will feel familiar to cynic fans and yet they are moving in a direction that's obviously different now for those of you who don't know cynic yeah they're a progressive rock band there are elements of death metal in their music older music jazz music as well drones soundscapes and with this EP we're seeing the introduction of world music as well and I gotta say the overall sound and aesthetic of this thing is is heavier it's heavier than the previous releases the sound is louder and thicker and just more arena sized especially in the case of the cleaner guitars on this album everybody knows that cynics previous stuff is always kind of featured you know some some pretty clean sparkling guitars but this EP makes them pretty just gargantuan just echoing in every direction just kind of feels like I'm listening to a rock band to play in a great hall with high vaulted ceilings I do really think the production is is is on this album and even though I do say this record is heavier its kind of heavier sound wise production wise these guys are taking another step away from their more metal side I think and they're not really a death metal band at this point not really even a progressive metal band for me at this point more just kind of a modern progressive rock band because this EP for me embraces sounds that reminds me of the Mars Volta with just these really ambitious guitar leads layering over each other in a pretty jazzy and harmonious way and the production style and especially the vocals on here though cynic has always had clean some vocals I'm feeling like a porcupine tree kind of tone on this record too and yeah even though this is not the most unique thing in the world there are albums and artists out there that I can compare to this it's not often that music of this style kind of hooks me in and interests me emotionally the opener to this EP starts things off with a really beautiful female vocal and in these really ethereal textures hanging in the background it just kind of sounds like listening to a waterfall on a starry night and crickets are in the background it's like it's that delicate and the second track the title track on here is really kind of the centerpiece of this thing for me it's got such a busy bassline really intricate drumming a nice groove and these really clean harmonized vocals that to me don't feel hokey like like I feel and a lot of progressive rock and metal music put out today they have kind of a cold soothing calming eerie feel for me they're kind of cultish your chilly it's just kind of strange or odd to hear these very smooth unwavering vocals singing over this really kind of busy chaotic instrumentation and I love the way the song really twists the the bridge is great the guitars just sound really really melodic and the musicianship is extremely strong but then things start to fall apart a little for me after that because tracks don't fade into each other all that well things just don't connect all that well thematically in in my opinion the third track is I think a little bit of filler it's like a two-minute instrumental with a sitar and some hand percussion there's a drone in the background too and while it sounds pretty nice that hasn't really been altered to fit into Synnex style and the fourth track just starts off really sloppy with a messy messy fade in of this guitar phrase kind of popping in and then fading down as other instrumentation fades up and it just feels so awkward and weird and and not really the best way to introduce the next song which is a shame because the hook on that thing is nasty it's just so catchy in the and it bursts so beautifully with though with the drums rolling and the guitars just just climbing and climbing everything is just like so nicely layered and while the the tone and the textures in a way kind of remind me of like of alternative radio rock from the early 2000s I can't deny that what I'm hearing is just really great interplay and great songwriting and the next track elvis beam-out may not be my favorite on here but it's really got some nice noodley guitar leads just interjecting between very quiet understated verses that just feel really calming it's got the same progressive rock style as the previous tracks but with some effects on on the drums I think this really kind of springy echo and just the way the track is produced it just sounds Spacey just feels atmospheric it feels like meteors and rings around Saturn and spaceship launches and satellites and maybe maybe some aliens no way buddy I'm in this country legal I hate Gaucho just that track sort of fades out to a very AM aspheric final track with some spoken word over it it's a bit of an anti climactic ending I guess but still sounds pretty beautiful cynic whether I like the way this EP is structured or not they're always pulling up some really nice textures now overall I really like the direction cynic is moving in with this EP yeah I think their previous material is impressive but I think they've moved away from that they've changed and still managed to stay impressive this thing is not that aggressive it doesn't come on really hard but I think it's got a lot of really great qualities all of which I just brought up in all the songs I just talked about so I suppose my negatives for this EP are that I feel like there's a bit of filler on here and the reason I feel that way possibly is because you know there are some great ideas on this EP but they don't fade into each other all that well they're not organized in such a way that I feel like I get a big punch from this thing things just feel a little scattered I guess and disconnected though I do like some of the shorter tracks more than others I can't help but feel like this EP is essentially three rock songs that I can really kind of sink my teeth into with three transitionary tracks kind of popping up here and there and I have to admit I was kind of left wanting more material wise maybe even though I'm not in love with this EP it's better that way because I'm really kind of left hungry I'm really looking forward to whatever cynic puts out full-length wise in the hopefully near future so I'm feeling like a strong seven to a light eight on this really impressive musicianship recording songs for me but what do you think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next anthony Fantana cynic forever

Mac Miller blue slide park ha ha ha hi everyone my needle drops Anthony fanta know the Internet's busiest music nerd here and it's time for a review the new Mac Miller LP blue slide park this this this kids a Pittsburgh rapper this is his full-length debut album after a series of some pretty decent mixtapes and I'm not really sure why but this kid seems to have a ton of fans but a lot a lot of haters people hate this kid and while I don't really quite get the fanatic love I don't get the insane hatred either I mean I kind of consider myself middle-of-the-road maybe a casual Mac Miller fan a lot of Mac Miller's older material to me is just kind of from the heart hip hop kind of painting a fun and and silly picture of this suburban dope smoking kid who's very nice and approachable likes to party and has a dream that's kind of a subject in a style that hasn't faired all that well in hip hop the most recent character besides Mac Miller to kind of do a similar thing is is Asher Roth when he put out that album asleep in the bread aisle in 2009 and yeah the rapping and the lyricism on that album is pretty average it's pretty bad sometimes too but there was a bigger issue with what people had beef with in regards to that album and I think it was kind of a problem of trust I kind of felt like that album was a label manufactured trick to kind of get pot smoking Xbox playin keg standing college kids to buy a rap CD Mac Miller on the other hand that question of authenticity is not there Mac Miller is actually that guy and to be blunt about it I'm not big on this album either for me the biggest issue on this thing is that you know this is a full-length debut official album I kind of expected to be wowed a little bit but his lyricism and his flow haven't really progressed matured anything this album is just kind of loaded with fun shallow slightly egotistical party pop rap that is peppered with you know cultural references it's not terrible but I'm not really a fan and it's not so much what Mac Miller says but kind of how he says it because in a way Mac Miller kind of reminds me of the Beastie Boys when they first came out they both definitely cater to a similar demographic and they shared lyrics about parties and getting wasted but at the end of the day I think when you kind of dug below the surface of the Beastie Boys there was kind of this tongue-in-cheek thing about them where they were very well aware that what they were doing was ridiculous I don't really get that vibe with Mac Miller especially on this album because on this LP he seriously tries to create a song where he puts together the soundtrack for the park where he used to hang out at at night and get high and there's even like you know police what kind of going on and off oh no the police are here we're hanging out at a playground getting high it's kind of embarrassing the only thing that I think has really changed about this album lyrically is just the story the narrative just the things that Mac Miller is is rapping about and you know at first this kid kind of came off as as being very hungry and and and and looking for fame but that's gone now and the discussion has turned to dealing with that Fame dealing with haters dealing with fans dealing with the money dealing with the popularity just dealing with it and constantly assuring me and his fans that he hasn't changed he ain't changing nothing's changed he's still the same and that may very well be true but I don't care I would rather Mac Miller change and then make an interesting album then not change and just keep making the same albums over and over and over again the beats on this thing I think are really where things kind of go downhill and I'm really surprised at that because most of the beat choices on his last mixtape we're pretty good I kind of welcomed that mixtape because it moved away from the silly and sugary beats I was hearing on kids that I was hearing on best day ever you know tracks like the spins and then senior skip day that kind of made me cringe blue slide park by comparison is like 50% sugary candy cane nonsense it gets worst on the track up all night where you've got this like pop punk rock drumbeat mixed together with these walking on sunshine piano chords it sounds like a party song for kids who still have a curfew the heavy bass hits on smile' back and and my team kind of feel like like Young Money beats or something and the hooks on tracks like gold and diamonds and and under the weather are so sweet they kind of feel like trying to swallow an entire sleeve of Sour Patch Kids without chewing it just doesn't even feel like hip-hop at this point it just kind of feels like pop instrumentals but with rapping over them the only thing that's really appealing about Mac Miller is his story his fun personality and his kind of underdog image well that's appealing depending on who you are there are some decent clams casino beats on here and the track party on Fifth Ave kind of cuts out the horn phrase from let me clear my throat and then puts it over this more like Club beat it's kind of an interesting reimagined version but a little bit overall I just could not really sit through this thing it was kind of redundant it just felt a little pointless in that Mac Miller wasn't really saying any thing a lot of the time he was just kind of dropping mediocre punchlines left and right and when he wasn't doing that he was kind of telling his personal story about dealing with Fame and that really didn't interest me I see it being interesting to fans to people who have watched him carry on this form so I'm kind of feeling like a strong for to a light five on this but what do you think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what should I review next you have any Fantana Mac Miller Bret [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd my needle drops hope you're doing well and it's time for an album review the new Drake LP this is his second full-length album the second full-length album from this canadian rapper who cal church esta will be giving you some background information on cal at hurry um dr. drake was graduated from the University of Degrassi rap school where Drake minored in the arse and the B's he studied under professor little Wayne and he graduated tap of his class and the best is mystery thank you thank you thank you thank you that was beautiful all right review time Drake take care but I'm not going to go too far into Drake's past since it's been so efficiently covered already by Cal Church esta this dude's last album take me later oh man I hated that thing to me it just felt so whiny and depressing and I really didn't understand why and it awkwardly straddled hip-hop and an R&B with this kind of underdeveloped persona and I wasn't really surprised that it felt that way Drake was kind of thrust into the limelight after only producing mixtapes and I think that led to this debut album being filled with with with terrible melodramatic and cheap lyricism and even though I was getting all these vibes from this album I didn't really necessarily assume that that Drake's future stuff would sound exactly like that take care doesn't come off like that to me thankfully there are some potholes on this album and we will get into that but overall I feel like on this album Drake feels more confident in his style in his sound not only that but he sort of embraces even tighter all of the aspects of his persona that made him really really kind of criticized when he first came out his his softer more introspective side all these R&B sounds the idea of this this very successful butBut sad and depressed character Drake is is not a hard or a tough rapper and he doesn't try to be even during his most boastful moments on this album he comes across about just as fluffy as a as a 3 Musketeers bar you know he's not a badass but do we really need another badass in hip-hop do we in my opinion Drake's skill level is up on this album and the lyricism though it's not exactly free of melodrama it's a little more adult it's a little more you know thought-provoking I guess I don't feel like I'm just listening to words read straight off of some kids tear-soaked diary page the opener to this LP is one of those personal moments where Drake kind of pens the story of his rise to fame he does it with some really consistent lyrics even though some of those lyrics can kind of be unrealistically boastful like how he killed everybody in the game last year not true I was there moments like that I don't feel like are meant to be - seriously but they do kind of raise a problem when Drake is rapping about how accomplished or how great he is to me it just kind of feels like he's fill in space because if he's not rapping about that he's rapping about how crazy some girl is making him their rhymes on here about other rappers biting Drake's style but clearly that's what he is doing in the case of the experimental R&B act the weekend and I know the weekends Fame and successes is partially owed to Drake because he's openly endorsed them he appeared on the projects previous EP but the favor has clearly been repaid in terms of musical inspiration for this album the R&B sounds the beats in general on take care in comparison with thank me later feel way darker more atmospheric more depressing even though Drake's lyrics may not be amazing he may not be giving me the best reasons in the world for being should the music makes it easier for me to relate and I guess get into the mood that he's trying to put together I feel like that aesthetic comes together really well on the second track shot for me with the vocals and the piano and the keyboards and then the finger snaps on that track the song to me just sounds beautiful the lyrics just don't feel all that childish kind of a story of of two lovers growing apart it's an adult kind of story Drake singing voice on this LP feels much much much less flat and robotic than it did on thank me later so yeah I do feel like Drake has improved his R&B game got more experimental got more creative and I think he's improved his rap game a little bit too and that shows up on the next track headlines now Drake doesn't exactly come out and kill it on this track but he has never really been about that he's always been more about what's kind of pleasing to the ear what's catchy between him and his longtime producer 40 there's just this huge appreciation for what makes music memorable real isset able and and fun and on the next track from this LP the artsy and glossy R&B style gets taken to a new level for drake with a feature from the weekend which surprisingly for me goes off without hitch I like the track a lot subject matters okay but the the beat is fantastic the really ethereal keys in the background and the big fat saturated distorted bass it's a nice and interesting contrast to me the title track from this LP is the first misstep that it makes and it's kind of an issue that a lot of albums that have such a high profile kind of have they're loaded with useless features and tracks that don't add to the idea or the concept of the feel of the album at all they're just put into the album to either get a radio single on it or just sort of get a feature on there that will attract fans of that featured artist and then get them to listen to the album to Rihanna's vocals and kind of the the the world beat electronic crap that's going on with the title track on here just does not fit into the the feel of take care it just feels out of place and as long as I'm talking about things that are out of place I feel like little Wayne is another one of those features he really doesn't rap about the same stuff that Drake does and when he does it just kind of sounds a little funny to me and as weird as it sounds to say this I think he raps with less finesse than Drake I think the only good thing about little Wayne being on this album is that he kind of shows how far along Drake has come since thank me later because little Wayne is making me roll my eyes more than Drake is especially with lines like I Stevie Wonder about her throw up everywhere Birdman is on here but he just kind of rambles and takes up space Rick Ross drops a pretty tolerable verse Stevie Wonder comes on for a harmonica solo that sounds like it would come off some Kenny G smooth jazz record and Nicki Minaj is Nicki Minaj some decent lyrics and this really fruity pebble personality there's there's there some rappers on here that I like like Kendrick Lamar and Andre 3000 but it's not like they're moments on this LP really grab me or leave me thinking oh wow that was those real highlight of this out overall I feel like these extra features and and tracks just add up to a lot of filler a lot of recycled ideas and a lot of do-nothing moments that draw this album out to 80 friggin minutes 80 minutes of Drake this album would have been so much better were it leaner and just sort of more straight in and in to the point but instead we get tracks like make me proud which in its hook and its concept is pretty much like best I ever had version 2.0 you've got hy fr which is pretty much like a boring radio track about Fame and groupies you've got a really lazy hook and a in a boring beat and a throaty little Wayne impersonation on the song cameras and the last track is extremely anticlimactic I mean any number of the slower songs on the album practice for example would have would have made a better closer but still I love the feel and I love the aesthetic of this album it feels like a roaring fireplace in a in a really huge room with wood floors and expensive furniture and a smoking jacket and and cuddling with a fine lady but the harder hitting tracks on here like underground Kingz and and will be fine to me kind of improve upon older ideas of drake's while the song lord knows feels a little new Just Blaze actually produced that track and he came out with what I think is the best beat on this album the huge chorus vocal the sampled soul voices on that too that are all kind of manipulated and watery and this huge thick bass beat it's uh epic I think the slower moments on this album come out really well - I think the only real misstep is the song Marvin's Room which has a really great weekend esque beat hanging in the background but it's loaded with all these cheesy foam recordings and horrendously bad lyrics I know you still think about the times we had that's trashy romance novel stuff come on Drake indulges in that stuff on other tracks like on practice but it just doesn't make me cringes as much and part of me likes that stuff and then another part of me feels like that this music wasn't really written with me in mind it's kind of like Drake's albums are released to attract the ears of of women who wish they had a man in their lives who would say all the corny crap that Drake raps it feels a little inauthentic like Drake as this dude who goes to the club with his collar popped just soaked in Axe body spray who goes around saying all this emotional crap to two girls hoping that they'll they'll go home with him a lot of tracks on your deal with Drake's personal story and he's really good at painting it but pretty much everything about Drake's personality draws from and is inspired by his fame and we all know famous temporary in ten years will Drake be famous will people care that he was famous still the sound the style of this album is is really great and that's why I think what awesomeness this album does have behind it is more ode to Drake's producers I have to take into account that man this just feels so in to me if 30 or at least 20 minutes of crap were cut from this LP I think I would be dealing with an album that was great for me take care as it currently is is just a steak with way too much fat in it that you've got to cut around to get to the good stuff overall I do consider this album to be growth for Drake though especially considering that I liked this much more than his last album I'm feeling a strong 6 to a light 7 on this but what do you think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantan Oh Drake [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review this is a review of a piece of music from the band pianos become the teeth they are a Baltimore band this is their second album and I'm sure kal chesta has lined up something witty deep and thought-provoking in response to this band's name yes a word of advice don't play pianos with your teeth play it safe and just do with your fingers I hate couch esta so yeah screamo it's pretty polarizing term and I don't know why because it's kind of difficult to really even say what an emo or screamo band sounds like people seem to be sure that this style of music originated from punk and hardcore music specifically in the Washington DC area scene where musicians who have loved and played that kind of music we're looking for ways to express themselves differently - two of the earliest examples are rites of spring and embrace the last of which featured Ian makai on vocals and the front man from rites of spring actually joined with Ian MacKaye later to form Fugazi and in comparison with a lot of the DC hardcore that came out before his albums were way more melodic they're sadder they're darker they just sound like they were produced by young people who were kind of frustrated and figuring out a way to navigate life in this emo emo core emotional hardcore term has been getting used for decades and as a result early bands like rights of spring don't sound anything like the the emo bands of the 90s like jawbreaker and Sunny Day Real Estate and cap and jazz and those bands don't really sound like the bands that kept the emo style popular into the 2000s like Jimmy old Dashboard Confessional and brand new stylistically some of these bands aren't too far away from hardcore punk and others would easily hook in a Weezer fan which only goes to show labels and genres only goes so far to actually describe a piece of music to make things even more confusing you have another sub-genre called scream OH which seems to take all of the elements of emo music but bring them to an extreme a harsh and abrasive extreme especially the vocals if you're interested in the style and you've never heard any of it I would look up bands like page 99 great band Envy great band 2 and gospel as well now like a lot of people I had kind of given up on this genre and post hardcore 2 which I've talked about before in previous reviews but this year has been kind of impressive for this style of music I found the new Touche more album to be really enjoyable and that La Dispute LP that I threw on the love list earlier this year I think I love that album more now than I did when I first reviewed it so I figured I would just try this band out try this album out give it a shot since there have been quite a few groups this year in the style that have shown promise now this LP is titled the lack long after it's 8 tracks 37 minutes definitely not drawn out by any means and these guys make some pretty dramatic rock music like any good band in this genre should and a lot like the band Envy they make sure to incorporate some post-rock elements into their music too there are some spots on this record that I could actually see the band explosions in the sky Rocking especially at the end of a track like liquid courage it's not like you're going to find a lot of long quiet slow and shimmering guitar interludes just just sparkling in the sky it's it's not quite that post-rock but these guys definitely display a love for this music especially in their climaxes where they're hitting these heavy power chord with the drums pounding in forjust maximum emotional effect and these guys stick to their guns they hammer up eight songs in this style they're pretty consistent but I just found a lot of negatives as I listened more and more and more a lot like that Touche more record I reviewed earlier this year I thought there wasn't really enough vocal variation on this album the vocals are just screaming and screaming and screaming and screaming and it is a little exhilarating at first yeah but they never really quite let up on much of this album the only real moment of major variation is the last track of the LP for me anyway and you know what it's partially the screaming it's also the fact that he screams so unintelligibly I can't really make out what he's getting so emotional over I do pick up some small hints I'll pick up words like hospital or or summer on this LP but for the most part I just am NOT getting a message that I thought I think I should be and to go back to the vocal variation thing I mean the vocals when they're screaming over these over these really soft and quieter moments with the guitars it just feels so out of place for me I had a similar problem with with the new fucked up album - I actually watched a review of this album my friend jumble junky music had done that bro is my bro and he kind of came out with the with the same complaint that there just isn't enough variation on these tracks - to make this album all that memorable even after I've listened to it multiple times a lot of the moments on this thing kind of bleed together for me but another thing about this album which makes it kind of difficult to remember is that I feel like there may be too few tools in the toolbox you know what I'm saying even though these guys do have some great drumming they're tight band some of these tunes segue into each other pretty nicely I find myself wondering what do these guys do differently than any other band in this style who would come before them I'm having a really hard time answering that question these guys have tons of elements that that I enjoy and I look for in this style of music but I have a difficult time describing them without making these guys sound like every screamo band to to ever live I feel like the most admirable trait of this album is that it's a modern screamo record that totally does not suck but then again is is that that admirable of a trait since I already said I have found records in this style this year that were pretty good so overall yeah I just kind of found this album to to not be terrible or unbearable but just kind of alright a little likeable I'm feeling strong too decent 6 on this record but what do you think of it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana pianos become the teeth you

Atlas sound hello my needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review atlas sound parallax atlas sound a singer/songwriter Bradford Cox really doesn't need an introduction better known as a member of the band dear hunter the indie rock neo psychedelic band dear hunter and as deer hunter grew with more and more fame Atlas sound has kind of become Bradford Cox's safe haven for some indulgent musical experiments the previous album he dropped logos is actually one of the first albums I reviewed on this channel and it's a very terrible inaccurate and horrible review and I think since then this this album has definitely grown on me and I've grown to appreciate the music of Deer Hunter even more as well I even saw them live when I was in South by Southwest earlier this year and man they were quite possibly the best band that I saw there maybe even topping Bad Brains so I was looking forward to parallax once I heard it was going to be released and I gotta say if this is your first introduction to Atlas sound maybe one of deer hunters previous three albums would would be a better fit or maybe one of the previous Atlas sound records I'm not saying parallax is bad because to me this album just kind of comes at a strange time dear hunter over the course of their career has grown a lot more accessible especially with their last album halcyon Digest a lot of the songs on that LP were really poppy while still maintaining deer hunters very psychedelic edge and whenever I would hear something new from Atlas sound is coming out and that happened a lot recently since Bradford Cox was putting out kind of a bedroom seer of home recorded compilations of songs it wasn't so much an amazing musical experience as it was kind of an interesting look into the mind of Bradford Cox some knob twiddling weird beats sound escapes as well as catch here in popular moments - Atlas sound has kind of been a project that I've been able to listen to and find a lot of exotic musical thoughts parallax I don't feel has that and it's mostly because Bradford Cox is making a conscious effort to come up with a uniform sound stick to it and the sound Bradford works with on this LP is one that is is very unintrusive its straightforward its oriented around verses and choruses it's actually reminding me a lot of the direction Deerhunter has been going in and though I think a lot of fans will be excited about this to me I kind of feel like Cox in a way has put himself in competition with what Deer Hunter was doing on Halcyon digest because a lot of the songs on this LP to me personally just kind of feel like duller more meandering and just kind of unfinished versions of tunes that I know if they were done in Deer Hunter would be clearer brighter bolder maybe fleshed out with some build ups or segues and extra instrumentation and a wider variety of effects not to say it was terrible and not to say it doesn't have its moments I feel like there are quite a few standout tracks on here parallax is a great song and catchy so is the shakes the opener to this album and I think my favorite track on this whole LP is Monalisa but overall I just kind of find this album really easy to listen to but difficult to remember no matter how many times I listened to it and revisit it because so many of the songs here though they do have a more uniform style they just kind of blur together for me I guess this style isn't without its merits I mean you know this record is pretty popular right now in that real estate record that came out earlier this year was pretty hot too if that's the sound that catches your ears and makes you come back for more than by all means get into parallax but as far as I'm concerned I'm more into logos I'm more into the deer hunter discography I'm feeling a decent two strong six on this thing liked it a little bit it's alright it's alright with me but what do you think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next you have any Fantan out atlas sound you

well hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's most childish music nerd and it's time for an album review the new childish gambino album camp childish gambino is actor writer rapper and producer donald glover and through shows both online and on television like 30 rock and The Daily Show Derrick comedy and community Donald Glover has been famous way before his music career has been taking off which was really happening last year with this EP he dropped and the mixtape cul-de-sac and every step of the way I have not been a fan and yet people keep asking me to review his stuff so I figure just make a review be straightforward be honest just say how I feel he can rap candy he has a flow doesn't he he has some witty word play doesn't he and yeah he does have all those things he has those things I don't deny Childish Gambino's technical ability his voice is a little whiny but at this point after listening to that EP listening to cul de sac listening to this I'm pretty much past the inflection and sound of his voice what bugs me about his music is is much greater than this to me in hip-hop genre where the lyrics are so pivotal to to driving the music what you say and how you say it are just as important to me as your technical ability and what childish gambino says on this album is is sad it's it's a very personal depressing I kind of like feel bad for him sad because if the lyrics on this album are any reflection of Donald as a person then to me he's revealing himself to be very emotionally damaged and and traumatized individual I don't want to act like I know the guy I don't know the guy but I'm just not into the themes that are being brought up on this album and the first major theme on this album is is blackness and Donald isn't obsessed with how black he is but rather how black he isn't he throws out lyrics left and right and left and right reminding me of how black he is not and of course the black people he doesn't consider himself to be our of course black people from the hood who he paints as as being really ignorant toward his ideas and his personality and his clothing choices but the thing is there's really no reason to believe him unless you're a white person who lives in and grew up in the suburbs with very very limited access to african-americans there are some spare moments of solidarity on here where Donald will rap about how african-americans uniformly will suffer from racial profiling and things like that no matter whether they're nerds or from the hood or whatever but for the most part Donald is just too obsessed with how unhooded he is and it's kind of disturbing in his lyrics he simultaneously says that the hood wants to hear him and and he's just not being given the chance to talk to these kids who grow up in these urban areas and yet the hood has also kind of rejected him and just doesn't understand and what kind of bugs me is that Gambino kind of boldly flaunts his his personality in the aesthetic he's trying to put together and acts like it's something unique I mean this is 2011 there are plenty of rappers out there who are african-american and not from the hood and are way less insecure about it and there are rappers from the hood who are ten times more emotionally complex and sound than childish gambino just because a bunch of people are of the same color and live in the same area does not mean they all think the same thing I've heard a lot of albums recently that have challenged hip hop stereotypes from Fat Sean kid cudi strong arm steady shad bus driver Tyler the Creator cool it's Rex Danny Brown LSI Big KRIT Shabazz Palaces Milo little B and Kendrick Lamar I don't love all these rappers but they take what makes them different and they create something that is really bold and proud a lot of them aren't rapping directly to the hood and they don't need to remind me of that unlike the artists that I just listed what makes childish gambino different or slightly different rather doesn't really add up into something bold and proud it's more like a laundry list of insecurities the thing is musically I don't even think Gambino is all that different from the rappers who he criticizes with some of his lyrics his flow and delivery and inflection are highly influenced by guys like Kanye and little Wayne especially when he's doing his punch line thing his lyrics are insanely misogynistic which is one of the biggest stereotypes in hip-hop he's constantly on about doing as many women of his many different races as possible like their Pokemon or something and he's got to collect them all he's really obsessed with his fame it seems everywhere he goes their struggle struggle struggle sometimes he actually tries to derive struggle from his fame which only comes out kind of pitiful and a bunch of beats that I could totally see making their way on to like a Young Money record if you're listening to him rap and you hear him reference stuff like Ariel pink or rug rats or invader zim and you react like ah well he is just so different isn't he I don't think you're listening to his music very hard I'm sorry but Gambino is not the only rapper wearing short shorts on the surface Gambino is a nerd a hardcore nerd with a pretty conscious and intelligent eye on what separates us culturally and racially that's what he portrays on the surface to me but you'd think if that's what he actually was he would comment on that in a funny or witty way that was thought-provoking a lot like how - racist does instead Gambino kind of takes what little things separate all of us and then he just gets upset about it I feel like I am Gambino's therapist and the pay is just not good enough being the odd man out is the only card Gambino knows how to play and the thing is is that he's not that odd and he's not that out like I said I don't know childish gambino and if this album is truly not him then the character he's playing on this thing comes off to me as being about a young crush on a summer camp bus driving away from the campgrounds and it was pretty beautiful and I liked it a lot and there are some moments on this LP that get pretty personal when it comes to Gambino's past like getting out of the hood because his parents wanted better for him or he's rapping about problems that other family members of his have either getting sucked into street life or culture that for some reason he feels like he's been rejected by and yeah we could talk about these very racial and personal and emotional problems all day but it doesn't make for very interesting ladies and gentlemen mr. David Lynch Crazy Clown time.the hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review mr. David Lynch Crazy Clown time the students of course critically acclaimed filmmaker and director and with this LP he is making a foray into music but this is not as first did it even Lynch is responsible for taking part in the soundtracks to his own films of course he's experimented with spoken word and ambien music and drone music before too he's even sung on other artists albums and written lyrics for other artists as well and even though I thought the singles that dropped before this album last year were just okay I was pretty interested in listening to this thing because David Lynch is the kind of director who if you know his movies especially movies like Eraserhead ah he just knows how to use sound to create a tense and weird situation so I came into this thing expecting an interesting sound and an interesting sound is what I actually got a lot of the tracks on this one our album feel pretty empty pretty thin hollow and creepy there's not a lot of punch to these songs and that's how they're meant to be David Lynch uses a ton of reverb a very low fight dirty recording quality low volumes and very subtle whisper vocals a lot of the time to kind of put distance between the listener and the music the atmosphere surrounding the music sort of holds more importance than the music itself some of the tunes on here feel broken and dirty dusty kind of mutated like a Tom Waits song and like I said there is that kind of low Phi weird vocal style combo going on this LP that I think even fans of woods or aerial pink could appreciate the track so glad has this really patient drum be in this cavernous surf guitar and kind of crooning over it is this really weird falsetto vocal that sounds like it's coming from some child's doll that somehow come to life and will kill me once I turn my back on it or fall asleep and the title track to this album crazy clown time which is maybe my favorite on this thing David Lynch brings that weird falsetto vocal character he plays to an even higher level and makes me pretty disturbed and perturbed in process there are tons of reversed guitars and rickety drums all over that track and the story that is being told through the lyrics is a little sick but Lynch doesn't always kind of stick to the styles on those tracks among the 14 songs on this album he jumps around a little the opening has the kind of same reverb II rock quality that a lot of songs on here do but the song is fronted vocally by Karen OVA yeah yes the song good day today is this kind of repetitive electro pop tune with a very dirty quality to it but these weird eerie auto-tune vocals just saying they want to have a good day today but all the interesting sounds and ideas that David serves up on this album do not cover the fact that this dude does not really showcase much song structure or know how about song structure on this album a lot of the songs on here don't have much of a build they just kind of harp on one single idea for four or five minutes until it becomes kind of directionless or boring the four to five minute tracks where the vocals feel kind of repetitive or buried it's those songs that end up feeling the longest for me on this album at first I was pretty excited about this album because I thought David Lynch is going to shake things up because he never comes out with music but in the end all it ended up sounding like to me is an album from a guy who never comes out with music with all the uneventful songs on here in the filler tracks and a low fire recording style I kind of feel like David Lynch has put himself in league with all the other bedroom producers out there all the other self producers out there who are putting their countless tracks and EPS and albums onto the internet every day if you're going to be kind of competing in that league I've heard better lo-fi stuff I've heard better self productions so yeah in the end I kind of ended up just feeling pretty pretty neutral pretty on the fence with this album feeling a life 5 to a decent 5 on this thing but what do you think do you love it do you hate it why what did you think David Lynch was going to bring on this album what did you get and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantan Oh David Lynch

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's most ghoulish music nerd and it's time for an album review ghoul transmission 0 in ghouls sort of fictional little world they are from a land called creep Sylvania but from what I understand they are actually from from Oakland Oh where's that well it's in California but if you ever go there make sure to protect your neck because if you don't you might get junked why do you think they call it troubling freaky yep that's where they're from these guys are a thrash metal band but they're one of the most personality driven thrash metal acts I've heard in a while Bell Bell Bell the vocals that they have going are done in a really a death metal style they have a very misfits esque horror movie fetish going on and ghoul also has this very theatrical over-the-top dramatic GWAR kind of shtick going for them to musically like I said these guys do play thrash but they've got this really lean straightforward crossover thrash thing gang vocals and fast paces and just and in-your-face aesthetic that I think fans of DRI or suicidal tendencies will be able to get into as well what also influences this bands music a little bit is is surf rock in a couple of tracks these guys actually managed to work in the drum beats bass lines and guitar leads that you would normally hear in a surf song but the thrash elements and the death metal vocals are still there it just doesn't clash in the way that I thought it would initially it becomes a part of Gul's sound and that sound ends up being kind of exciting and conflicting to me at the same time because I don't know whether to just get up and start mashing and elbowing thing or go on YouTube and start looking up old episodes of Tales from the Crypt now to bring the shtick that these guys have going for them even further the lyrics the songs on this album actually tell a story a very comic book-like story filled with cartoony gore that makes it about as fun to follow as like a toxic avenger film the story this record tells features the four members of the band going on this bloody and and horrifying adventure involving killer robots and and cannibalism and mind control and voodoo curses drugs and and cultists as well even though there are elements of punk on here thrash metal and death metal all very aggressive hard-hitting genres ghoul takes everything that is so grim about these styles of music so dark and and so serious and they make it pretty fun to me it's it's kind of light-hearted because you don't need to take it really seriously but ghouls respective members have toured with or played in plenty of metal bands who are taken really seriously like wolves in the throne room dystopia ludicrous under and the band impaled who actually think they share the most characteristics with now sound wise I really love this record I think it's got a lot to offer the drums just have this really nice punch to them the cymbals get a little lost in the background for me a bit but the guitars are really where a lot of this records guts come from they've got this nice heavy crunch to them that sounds fantastic it's sound kind of reminds me a little bit of that new toxic Holocaust record conjure and command so yeah I do think these guys improve their sound beyond their last record splatter thrash but they also refine themselves musically a bit too I think the music on this thing to me just feels less chaotic less messy the riffs have a lot of muscle to them and they're really catchy because these guys are hitting great grooves and even though these riffs are pretty hard-hitting I think a lot of them are evened out because these guys manage to cover them color them in some really nice solos and Lee as far as negatives on this album go there aren't a lot but some of the riffs some of the solos do sound a little generic kind of cliche if you're a thrash metal fan you've heard buildups leads and solos like this before so that makes some of the moments on here kind of a forgettable blur to me if it wasn't for the story the good production just the personality of this band I I wouldn't be riding with these songs as hard as I am right now and I'm sure for some people metalheads and non metal heads this record is gonna I don't know have a little too much Kitsch for you might be too silly for you I don't know and though it is an important part of the storyline I feel like the song morning of the mesma Tron is a little too long a little too drawn-out this eight minute monster among all these like two to three-minute thrash punk tunes with death metal vocals but overall if you're a metalhead I think this is going to be the most fun you're gonna have with a metal record this year and even if you're not huge on metal I still think this is worth trying even though these guys are really excessive they kind of do it in a pretty self-aware way which you know really hits home for me on the last track where one of the lyrics say spill your blood for rock and roll I'm loving the hell out of this thing feeling like a decent eight on this really fun enjoyable solid record with a good variety of different sounds on here that let me separate one tune from another pretty easily but what do you think about it do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantana cool
