oh gosh yeah hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review oblivion eyes abhorrent revolution evolution evolution these guys are a band from the UK 5 piece new debut EP self-produced 17 minutes and from the looks of the cover here I'm sure you can guess you're in for something pretty grim and extreme this thing initially was released in the UK but just recently from what I understand it is now out in North America mm-hmm so I figured that would make it worth a review and also for some reason there's just been you know the slowly growing demonic voice inside of me screaming more meta sometimes that voice gives me indigestion so these guys are a death metal band now you guys know I usually like my death metal really filthy and grimy and blood-soaked I usually tend to stray away from the the really really produced stuff that sounds like plastic to me but oblivion eyes does a great job of not sacrificing any of their ugliness for the sake of getting flashy or musicianship in here it's impressive and offensive kind of like watching Evil Dead 2 for the first time you knows oh I never knew you could have that much fake blood spraying in every direction all at once listening to this thing is a little bit like getting dragged into a pit of mud by a family of alligators and then being torn to shreds as you suffocate on on wet dirt and rocks and little bugs I'm not doing a good job of making this sound appealing am i what do you think delicious all right I just applaud a Bolivian eyes because they just had that really dark grimy lens focused on them and still they use their technical ability to create a golf ball-sized hail storm of relentless drums guitars bass and vocals but the recording is also clear enough to the point where I can make out exactly what every single person in this band is doing sometimes the bass is a little hidden back there but whenever it be solo pops out it's right there in the forefront I hear every grinding chak chak chak know that it's so pumping out but I don't think this EP would be as stand out would be as memorable if it didn't have these accessible points to these four songs as well like the third track on here the opening riff is really slow and doomy and easy to get into and at the halfway point to the song these guitar leads pop in that are really really melodic but as much as I would love to get you guys into what I'm listening to on this thing I can't lie about it there's not much about the port evolution that is easy on the ears but that's what makes it so memorable the riffs are really pummeling the changes are just dizzying neck-breaking hard to digest all at once death growls they are rough they are coarse sandpaper rough and the vocals on this thing sometimes they double up with a higher pitch scream as well it gets kind of suffocating I just think it's great how tight these guys are and how natural they've been able to get that tightness to sound and I think with this EP they made something that leaves me wanting more yeah but once their album comes out and if it is good and I do like it I could still see myself returning to this on the downside this EP does sound like these guys are really sort of in a kind of fetal stage right now because they're yet to hammer out a completely definitive style for themselves but it doesn't take away from its intensity its memorability its potency I'm feeling a light to decent 8 on this thought it was really good maybe a little migraine inducing after all the times I listened to it for this review but but what do you think of it do you love it do you hate it and why and what should I be and maybe are reviewing next Anthony Fantana oblivion eyes

yeah friggin snow what October it is getting chilly hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd it's time for a mixtape review thing Milo I wish my brother Rob was here this dude is an up-and-coming MC this is not his first rodeo though he was an MC and a contributing member of the rap group nom de rap before he put out this mixtape which is hilariously titled after del the funky homosapien 'he's first album which I do enjoy quite a bit but also the title is in tribute to a friend of his who passed away so this is hip hop ever since the internet became a great kind of farming ground for hip hop artists to throw their mixtapes in every single direction it's really difficult to choose who I should be reviewing who I should review instead that kind of stuff I can only make so many videos and people tell me stuff like hey so-and-so could use some exposure I'm just trying to talk about some music that that I enjoy I'm not trying to be a musical Robin Hood here in this rapper Milo makes some music I enjoy and what I do like about Milo is that I think he has a lot of interesting qualities he raps over beats that I think a lot of emcees would shy away from because they're too electronic or silly or quiet he lifts from a handful of different producers on this mixtape including mad lib which is cool but what's interesting to me is that he uses beats from shlomo that bad feelings album I reviewed earlier this year another producer I reviewed gold panda and Flying Lotus as well a lot of these beats contains swirling electronics and ambient soundscapes and a lot of acoustic guitar there's very familiar and traditional jazz and soul samples here and there but for the most part the sounds on here are a little out there is out there is my love he's got this really funny and approachable personality that sidesteps the aggression and the unreal bragging that makes hip-hop 'unless for some people and his rhymes are littered with with nerdy stuff relating to the Lord of the Rings and Ghostbusters and sweaters and philosophy and Kurt Vonnegut and internet forums stuff like this has been wrapped about before especially by rappers who a lot of people have labeled as nerd Gore which is basically hip-hop tailored for nerves by nerds and artists and the style have their merits including guys like MC Chris and MC Frontalot but I feel like them and a lot of MCS in nerdcore or just people who get labelled as a nerd rap or whatever they take the nerd persona and they put it out there in a really kind of jokey cartoony way I never get that oh I'm so quirky I'm so nerdy vibe from this record and I like that Milo to me is just himself he's exposing what he's really interested in he's exposing his real personality for all of its strengths and its flaws he's smart and cynical and funny and knowledgeable about nerd culture he'd like to own a farm one day and he raps like he knows a thing or two about the antidepressants but there are plenty of spots on here where he has these moments that remind me a little bit of Kendrick Lamar in that he can't relate to anybody not people his age especially so he starts criticizing because everyone around him is drinking too much and giving him to advertising and giving in to social norms and to hip-hop stereotypes and being too conservative or being too liberal there's not much on this album he takes all that seriously except his own personal experiences which he paints all over this thing the end of the song just us where he uses that shlomo be he tells this kind of kind of eulogy to his to his past friend and it gets me a little it's sad even sadder but but kind of in a funny way that gets me a little you know also the track one lonely owl at the end they're all these lines about growing old but still kind of wanting to be a rapper and be cool there's even a lion where he tells his bed nurse at the nursing home that he swagged out I like mr. doubt writer which is kind of about writing rap songs but then abandoning them because he's a self-defeating introvert now as far as the students flow goes just as his rapping ability he reminds me a lot of MF DOOM guys like that with that very hypnotic repetitive low kind of deadpan delivery if I'm going to get into an emcee who's rapping like that I really need to be into what they're saying thankfully I feel that way about Milo I think even though he doesn't exactly he has a great ability to tell a story and and drop some clever wordplay as far as the negatives on this mixtape go some songs on here just feel just too silly for words especially super happy sunshine funk club there are a handful of tracks on here like that one and like the sixth track as well the final track to where the vocals are just recorded really badly just really muddy they just don't sound good at all the features on this mixtape just don't feel as strong as Milo when it comes to rapping and there are a few cringe-worthy lines here and there thing that Milo does definitely feeling a light eight on this but what do you think about it do you love it do you hate it why and why haven't you heard it it's free just download it just look for a having milk grounded milk hmm hey everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's most birthday music nerd it's my birthday today my birthday so I'm just going to chill out I'm just going to hang out just going to review something I want to review something I've been kind of anticipating since the day it was announced the new collaborative EP from Danny Brown and black milk black and brown Danny Brown's an MC Black Milk is an MC / producer both are Detroit natives and both carry a lot of weight in the underground underground hip hop I have reviewed both of these guys two before on the channel Danny Brown's xxx which came out earlier this year one of my favorite hip hop albums of 2011 and this is a pretty dark and personal album addictive depressing descent into drug addiction plus the lyrics bring a lot of cliche rap stuff to such an excess it becomes kind of hilarious in black milk's latest album album of the year I wasn't really big on it I'm not huge on the guy as an emcee but I like his beats he's got a really nice smooth soulful sound his production that he's worked with a lot of emcees I liked and he produced for that random acts album that came out earlier this year that I didn't feel like reviewing so I was pretty interested to see what Danny and Black Milk would do together what they would pull out of one another in this collaboration and sadly I can't really say there was any kind of AHA change on this EP between Danny or Black Milk it's not like Black Milk changes his style to accommodate Danny and Danny is pretty much the guy I met a few months ago when I listened to xxx but it's not like a change really needed to happen all the tracks on this EP just work without any major adjustments from Danny or Black Milk it's kind of like finding out that raisins taste good on a peanut butter sandwich seriously you should try it beat why's this thing has a lot of boom bappy drums guitar string piano samples vocal samples DJ cuts as well it's a transition from the weird electronic sounds that were on xxx but it's not like these kinds of beats or unfamiliar territory for Danny anyway stuff of this style has appeared on its previous releases the hybrid for this EP and surprisingly to me against the other songs on this EP that track is one of the better ones on here at the end of the day I feel like this EP feels more like networking as opposed to a the field looping looping looping looping hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review the new the field LP looping state of mind the field is and always has been the minimal techno project of electronic music producer Wilner he's from sweden I think it's really funny and interesting that on his third LP he quite literally comes out and suggests with the title the kind of listening experience that that you're actually in for with his music but there's definitely some advancement being shown on this thing I think the sounds on this thing are beefier lower frequencies higher frequencies more effects on some of these sounds more texture I love the beats the drums on this thing they've just got this really nice body to them they have a lot of push but they're not like you know bangers the beats on this thing I can really just grab on and just hold tight for the duration of an entire track and I'm just into it I feel like a lot of producers can throw four beats on the floor that's cool but very rarely does it actually feel like it grooves to me and that's how I feel with this album though and I think it's mostly because there's a lot of attention to detail on this thing these little rhythmic flourishes that surround the beats especially on the opening track it actually kind of reminds me of listening to for tetes latest LP there's lovin you yeah there's plenty of repetition on this thing but they're these very subtle subtle subtle embellishments that surround the rhythms that surround the melodic and harmonic elements of this album - the way the synthesizers in the background of is this power kind of swell very slowly as the song reaches the end on this LP a lot of the changes and the shifts just happen so slowly and subtly it really holds my attention because I'm just really locked into observing what's going on here it's kind of like putting life into slow motion while still being able to think in real-time it's kind of weird to me this album is equal parts mesmerizing and engaging so I I think my explanation as to why I like this album is is pretty simple and it can only be simple because this is a pretty simplistic album but not in a bad way I just think it's interesting that what is happening on this album to me seems kind of obvious and yet it works so well it sounds so good and for some reason a lot of producers overlook this kind of style this kind of aesthetic but that's not to say that I think this album is perfect or that I think it's without its lower points one of my least favorite moments is on the third track of this album burned out it's something that also happens on the last track of this album too and for some reason it just really rubs me the wrong way like I said earlier I find this album really mesmerizing and I like that feeling I like kind of feeling hypnotized by the repetition and the textures of this album but this third song there are these really disembodied vocals floating around in the air surrounding this track and I don't know they're just kind of killing my buzz they just don't feel like they fit into the song at any point for me whereas everything is locked into this rhythmic Tetris puzzle where everything has a place and everything has a purpose these vocals are kind of calling out and not really adding anything just kind of distracting like I said that happens on the last track too but I think I may like that track even less because the beat is a little off for me it kind of sounds like listening to a copy-machine make about 2000 copies non-stop it's not a traditional rhythm and that's fine I'm cool with that I think I actually would have liked the track a little bit more if I felt like that song offered as much progression as many of the other tracks on this album do sure I have a few reservations but the tracks on this thing that I loved I loved a lot and for sure I will be digging into the fields previous albums a little bit more now that I have listened to this and I liked it for the most part kind of feeling a decent too strong seven on this but what do you think do you like this thing do you hate it are you in a looping state of mind and if not why and what should I review next you have any Fantan out the field you

really really lately hi everybody Anthony Pham tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd yep and it's time for an album review Tom Waits that is me Tom Waits in my opinion is one of modern music's most eccentric and standout songwriters he's a guy who in a way I have to thank for kind of changing the way I listen to music change the things that I look for in music sometimes to his stuff over the years has helped me appreciate things like grit and abstract lyricism and darkness and odd sounds when I first heard of this guy it was when he dropped his album real gone in 2004 not his greatest LP but at that time my musical world was very very small so being introduced to Tom Waits was kind of like dropping a boulder in a kiddie pool he just didn't sound like anything I had ever heard before in my life so I became obsessed and learned his influences and read interviews and books and managed to get a copy of nearly every album he ever made between the time he put out real gone and then released orphans just two years later now when I first heard bad as me was coming out I was you know kind of afraid to listen to it not as a fan but because I knew I was going to have to review it and I was going to have to battle myself either in one direction or the other and try to either not be a fanboy or try to not be too negative because I'm so enamored with Tom's previous works but to be completely honest in my first few listens to this LP I was pretty disappointed and I still am to an extent I don't think bad as me as a terrible album but what made me kind of disappointed is that in my opinion every Tom Waits album up until this point especially everything that came after rain dogs has a particular feel to it that makes it different from every other Tom Waits album I think bad as me is packing that mule variations to me is very kind of worn and dusty I just kind of get this like this old-school hitchhiker kind of feel from it bone machine is loud and clanging and bending I just kind of feel like I'm like in some underground cave and it's really dark and they're monsters in there it's kind of freaky Alice is incredibly dark and depressing blood-money really barks with intensity it's just smothered in blood and cigar smoke it's a really kind of murderous album and real gone is so low fie and fuzzy really Tom Waits is most noisy album yet in my opinion and I think there are some common threads that run through each album like Tom Waits voice piano ballad screamers and singers bangers and clangers and on bad as me I don't feel like Tom is offering me a new style at least not for an entire album anyway I feel like for the most part bad as me is almost kind of like a retrospective of Tom looking back revisiting past sounds and just kind of looking at how bad he's been over the years the really slow bluesy feel of raised right men would have fit in really well with heart attack and vine if it wasn't for that screaming organ in the background payme is a really nostalgic waltz and New Year's Eve has the kind of storytelling that reminds me a lot of Frank's wild years especially since pay me has lyrics about Fame and the stage lasts leaf and face to the highway are kind of forlorn and and very subtle and quiet I could just hear the wind blowing and the tumbleweeds going by on these tracks and it really makes me feel like I'm listening the mule variations kiss me reminds me of these really long wandering love ballads that he used to write a lot more way back in the day on albums like Blue Valentine I could go on forever none of these revisits really bugged me except for the song satisfied which sounds exactly like the song big black Mariah from Rain Dogs you can pretty much sing the hook from one song over the other without any hitches overall I'm not really feeling a flavor from album or an overall style to me right now this album kind of feels like a mixed bag a lot like orphans was except you're only really getting one albums length of tracks only a few spots only a few here feel kind of new to me I love the song get lost because it's got this rockabilly feel to it and then it kind of struck me why haven't I heard Tom go down this direction more before the song bad is me goes nuts with his voice that Tom Waits kind of saves only for special occasions and the song hell broke loose man that thing is noisy as hell has these guitars in the background just pumping in a way that kind of reminds me of industrial music it bangs it screams and is an interesting reflection about war and paints a story about this military where Tom is singing from the perspective of a soldier talking about getting off meth and bringing up suicide bombs so because I feel like I'm hearing a lot of things on this album I've heard before I think what makes this thing enjoyable what it really comes down to is just the tunes the melodies the hooks the lyrics the song raised right men is is is pretty dark and and I think in a way funny it's just about how a good man is hard to find talking at the same time is kind of about how the problems of the world are being overlooked because everybody is talking at the same time Tom sings and this really creepy falsetto that I love that he doesn't do all too often in the woodwinds that come past the hooks on that track are really beautiful and on that track Tom drops a lyrical nugget that reminds me that he is kind of a lyrical double genius sometimes he says everybody knows umbrellas cost more in the rain but there are a good chunk of tracks on here that just leave me wanting more the song kiss me I kind of roll my eyes at some of the lyrics on that track I've never really known Tom to throw out that many cliches in one song and the song back in the crowd feels kind of just dry and empty in a way that leaves me underwhelmed it's one of the cleaner and more sanitized Tom Waits songs I've ever heard there's not a speck dirt insight in any direction I think there's kind of a funny metaphor in the hook but outside of that it's not really doing a lot for me and the song last leaf to me is a little kind of long-winded I guess the guitars don't do that much for me and the background vocals intertwine with the lead vocals in a really awkward way that's distracting more than it is complementing I mean if you're the last leaf on the tree who is that singing I think this LP is kind of a sidestep definitely not a step backwards in my opinion tom has not lost his musical flavor at all he's always really had obvious influences like Howlin wolf and Captain Beefheart and blues artists like Muddy Waters and jazz artists like Louie Armstrong of course he's really influenced by gospel music too but overall when Tom Waits makes a song it sounds like a Tom Waits song despite the fact that there's really no cohesive feel between these tracks for me I'm feeling a strong six to a light seven on this I thought it was really good and worth checking out but it's definitely not one of my favorites in his catalogue but what do you think of this thing do you love it do you hate it why and what do you think I should review next anthony Fantan Oh Tom Waits [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for an album review this artist name is Cueto the album is severence Cueto is the pseudonym for electronic music producer jamie Teasdale who I first heard of a couple years ago when I was looking up dubstep songs on the internet and I came across his insistent travels EP owned a vinyl copy of it too highly recommended three great tracks on that thing this dude is also one half of the dubstep duo vexed and they spent their last album yeah playing some dubstep but experimenting with ambient music - so now we have this new solo release from Jamie he's already released some EPS under this name one of which kind of takes the dubstep style and filters it through 8-bit sounds and you know I'm just kind of setting this up because I think it's funny that now the dubstep is kind of like this hot electronic music commodity um he's kind of taking a break from the style on this thing but in a good way but after listening to this thing again and again and again I kind of feel like Severin is is really limited definitely an intentional limitation and that's because Jamie has made a conscious decision to use these kinds of synth sounds and these kinds of drum sounds and execute them in this way instead of huge variations between tracks this album is more about taking a single idea and exploring every single nook and cranny of it but I have to talk about first what sticks out to me the most about this album is definitely the rhythms the drum machines they're really light tinny thin fast they've got this like rattling jittery quality to them that's commonly found in juke music or footwork music and it's like totally not uncommon for the snare drums or the high hats had a lot of points on this thing to just be going like rapid-fire like there are only a handful of songs on here like the intro reality drifts and salt lake cuts and a few kind of interlude tracks that ease up on the rhythms none of those tracks actually to me are the less exciting ones because without these rhythms in the background of these tracks I feel like this album loses a unique quality the drums on this thing are really dry they're clickety they're clackety and they shouldn't sound that way because they kind of sound like they're getting programmed on an old-school drum machine that old-school feel gets strengthened in the synthesizers on this LP because they totally sound like this instrumental soundtrack progressive synth music that would back up an old sci-fi movie you know something from the 70s something from the 80s there are newer artists who have championed this sound again and again and again like zombie or zombie members majore or steve moore and of course there's tons of older stuff like this to reference back to like jean-michel Jarre tangerine dream Vangelis of course that Blade Runner soundtrack you've basically got these really tense Juke and footwork rhythms working against these synthesizer sound scapes now this album synthesizer wise compositionally I just don't find as ripping I feel like a lot of the songs here are built on a really simple phrase or arpeggio and it's just repeated ad nauseam or it changes so subtly that it's hard to pick up and sometimes the sins just bleed over each other and layer over each other for a kind of hazy effect overall they just kind of end up being this side dish to the rhythms for me there are spots on here like truth flood which use this just really kind of tired chord progression that just doesn't really do anything for me and I just see myself ignoring it and just observing the rhythms instead some of these tracks to me just feel like they fall in the background they just feel unintrusive and and I guess that's the nature of the soundtrack style that that Jamie is embracing on this thing I get that maybe that is intentional on some level the reasons I like this thing is because I do like that combination these two ideas there are a handful of tracks on here where I think it's executed really really well and do kind of have a soft spot for these old-school synthesizer Odysseys they just feel so epic they feel so spacey to me they really put my head in a different place as a total package I think this thing is a little rough but artistically Janie really moved in an interesting direction on this one I'm feeling strong six to a light seven on this one definitely not one of my favorites of the year but if I didn't think there was an interesting idea going on here I wouldn't have reviewed it I would love for you guys to check this thing out let me know what you think love it hate it why and what should I review next yeah penny Fantana Cueto
